reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 世 is せ here, and not せい!

meaning.explanation: What do you use to get a person to participate in something? A carrot, of course. You've heard of "the carrot and the stick," right? So next time you want a person to participate, offer them a carrot.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 参 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're craving a carrot, but you can't seem to find any. You look in your fridge, in your garden, and even in the trash. Finally you give up your carrot search and sit down when... ouch! The carrot was in your jeans (じん) the whole time!

meaning.explanation: What location suits a situation the best? That always depends on the case or circumstance. You can't know the suitability of the location until you have all the facts about the circumstances.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You haven't learned this kun'yomi reading for 合 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  To know exactly what case or circumstance you're dealing with, you keep a close eye (あい) on things. Imagine your eye really close up to the circumstances, trying to figuring out exactly what's going on.

meaning.explanation: Your person status is where you, yourself, are a person. This is more than skin deep, though, this is your status after all. This is your character and personality. What's the status of your character? Good? Bad? Getting there?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji circumference, so it means circumference too.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You really want to measure the circumference of something but there doesn't seem to be anything round around. That's when you remember, "Mah Walnuts! (まわ)." The walnuts in your pocket have an easy edge to measure.

meaning.explanation: What is the greatest art a person can possess? It’s got to be the art of making people laugh. That’s why this means comedian, though it can also mean a performer or entertainer more generally.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When something is all perfect it is complete. Not only that, but it's perfect (because it's ALL perfect, not just partially so).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When something has become perfect it has reached completion.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A perfect finish is when everything is at total completion. Nothing is left over and all is done.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When you have gentle cooperation nobody has their way. You're very gently coming towards the middle, coming to a compromise. (Whether you like it or not.)

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You have to find the right tool to suit your condition or state. If you have a health condition, the tool is a pill, or exercise, or real life friends. But it always depends on the condition you're in.

reading.explanation: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 具 and the kun'yomi reading for 合. You've learned them both, so you should be able to read this word too!

meaning.explanation: Something that is near period like is very contemporary. But if it looks like it's from a period not near the one you're in... throw it away! It isn't modern enough to touch your hands!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: There is a reason for this fee that you have to pay to get in here. We are cooking cuisine for you to eat while you're watching the show. If we weren't cooking a dish for you, we probably wouldn't charge you this fee!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Cooperation power is your level of cooperation. It's how much collaboration or assistance you provide.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: If you follow the circumference of a period of time, you end up back at the beginning and it makes a full cycle. Events in history always repeat, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Things will be bright after the next day. Or you can think of it as adding an 後 in between your 明日. And what comes after tomorrow? It's the day after tomorrow.

reading.explanation: Unfortunately, the reading for this is a complete exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "What do you want to eat the day after tomorrow?", your mom asks you. You answer, "Ah, satay (あさって)?" You're not so confident because you never know what you want to eat the day after tomorrow, but you absolutely love satay, the Indonesian skewers. Ah, satay it is!

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji deep, so it means depth.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 深い so you should be able to read this one too!

meaning.explanation: The hope you request is your desire. Just imagine yourself hoping and requesting some higher power for something you really want. What is this? It's your desire or wish.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 言葉 means "language?" Well, the way you "attach" (付き) language to things is your diction. Everyone has their own 言葉つき when they speak. How would you describe your 言葉つき? 言葉つき refers to the characteristics of how one speaks, including the words they choose, how they say them, and their overall speaking style.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: There is fault in your hope. It breaks, and everything falls apart. You feel massive disappointment and despair.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You've seen the word 消す, I hope. This comes from that. You're extinguishing something with ゴム. ゴム is a word for either gummy or rubbery things. So, this is a gummy thing that extinguishes something. This is an eraser that extinguishes pencil markings.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 消す, so make sure you know that word so you can read this one!

meaning.explanation: Everyone (formal name ender). This is just a polite way to say everyone (and you want to be polite to everyone, because everyone > you).

reading.explanation: The reading for both kanji here are the same as the ones you learned with their kanji. Everyone can breathe easier now.

meaning.explanation: Someone with bad energy is someone who has evil intent, malice, or ill will. Hopefully you don't have too much 悪気.

reading.explanation: The reading itself has a lot of 悪気 with all the exceptions it has. The 悪 part is read like 悪い. Then, 気 is rendaku'd. What an evil reading. Just think "what's the most evil reading I can come up with?" when you see this word. Then you should hopefully be able to read it.

meaning.explanation: Example writing is a piece of writing that is an example for maybe a word or a kanji or something like that. This is an example sentence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something that's outside the example doesn't follow the rules. It's not what it's supposed to be (the example), it is the exception.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Someone who's of the woman gender is probably going to be female.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This has almost the same meaning as the kanji it comes from. Instead of just simply being "example," though, it's for example. It can also sometimes mean supposing that when talking about hypothetical scenarios. So, supposing that I start a sentence with this, I can be all like "例えば, I am using 例えば in a sentence."

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Using all kinds of "for examples" like this, you were taught (たと) many things throughout your life. For example, you were taught about...

meaning.explanation: The origin of your foundation is where you have to work from when learning something new. For example, the 基本 portions of WaniKani are the earlier levels, especially the radicals. They are the foundation you need to learn your kanji and vocab later on.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This word is pretty straightforward. You have fur and skin, making a word meaning fur or pelt, like the kind that can be used to make garments.

reading.explanation: This is a special case because both kanji use kun'yomi readings in this word. Luckily, you already know the kun'yomi reading from learning the vocabulary 毛 and 皮 previously. Just be careful with the rendaku on the second kanji, 皮.

meaning.explanation: An attempt to join together isn't just any get together. Imagine two people boxing. They attempt to knock each other out when they join together. That's why this word is game or match. Did you watch the 試合 today? No! Don't tell me what happened, I recorded it on the VHS.

reading.explanation: This word uses the on'yomi し for 試 and the kun'yomi あい for 合, which you learned with 場合. So you should be able to put them together!

meaning.explanation: The arts are performed by someone. Who is that someone? Well, think about the reading for this kanji. Do you recognize the word? It's geisha.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: A good like is something you like really good, if that makes any sense. This thing is a good and favorable thing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

meaning.explanation: You are a 疲れ (tired) 様 (honorific that kind of refers to whoever's being mentioned). You say this to people when they've done good work — at the end of a workday or after a hard practice, for example. I guess the idea is that if they're tired, they've done some good work. Tell your coworkers お疲れ様でした when they leave for the day, or just use お疲れ in more casual situations with friends!

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 疲れ and 様, combined together into one word.

meaning.explanation: The business of you graduating is your graduation. If you think about it, it's kind of a big business, getting you graduated from expensive schools. The graduation business focuses on graduations, and getting you there (hint: this business is a school, probably).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of hard? It's hard, firm, or tough.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need something really hard to put in your catapult(かた). Look around you for something hard and imagine putting it in your catapult!

meaning.explanation: What your thoughts request inside your head, nonstop like a crazy person, are your heart's desires.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Both your hopes and wishes are held within this vocab word. So, what is the meaning of this word? It is both hope and wish. Either will work.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You've hopefully seen 消化 by now and know that it means "digestion." If you know that, then you can see that the "digestion" is not good. When your digestion is not good, what do you have? Indigestion. Excuse me, I have to run to the restroom...

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 消化 and 不良 will help as well.

meaning.explanation: You have to pay a fee for the material you use to make food. Those are the ingredients you're paying for! Imagine making a list of all of the materials you need to make a stew, then making sure you have enough to pay the fees, so you'll have all the ingredients you need to make it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: One example is just an instance of what you're describing. Just one example.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The abilities you originally start out with are instincts. Animals have lots of them because they aren't very good at learning. They have to start out knowing them from the start.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You wouldn't put your idea in a diagram ~like format if it wasn't intentional. Doing that takes a lot of work. So you can only make diagram like things on purpose!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 図 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You intentionally stub your toe (と) all the time! If you hurt your toe on purpose you can get out of class and work! It's a really simple injury, but you can't do other stuff while it's hurt, so you always do it on purpose to get out of things.

meaning.explanation: The things you wear are your clothes. Oh, and Japanese clothes count too. We're talking kimonos. Way back when, these could just be called clothes because it's all people really wore, but nowadays we know they're specific to the stereotypical kimono you think of when you think "Japan."

reading.explanation: The reading is a bit strange using kun'yomi readings. Luckily, we taught you these already, so go put on that kimono of yours and relax at the 温泉 for a bit.

meaning.explanation: You write the word go on a line of text. See the word "go" on that line, and think about where you're going. This word can also be used for rows (horizontal lines in Excel and other spreadsheets).

reading.explanation: There are two on'yomi readings for this kanji, but when it's used to mean lines of text, it's pronounced as ぎょう. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that: You write out another line of text asking for some gyoza (ぎょう). You write out that line of text slowly and carefully, in your very best handwriting. Turns out you were going to a gyoza restaurant and you want to make sure you impress the gyoza chef, so that they give you a ton of gyoza.

meaning.explanation: Lumber trees are what you use to make lumber and timber. 材木 is typically for lumber or timber that's been processed — the stuff that's cut into planks and ready to use in your next DIY project, for example.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: One of the meanings of 本 is main (which is what we're using here). The main public building is the main building. Sometimes 本館 can also mean this building, as in the one you're in. I guess whatever building you're in sort of becomes the main one to you, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. For you advanced learners out there, you might want to know that saying that this word like Kyoko gets you the main building meaning, while saying it like Kenichi gets you the this building meaning! Isn't pitch accent fun? But you'll probably never have to worry about this — context clues will be enough to tell you which meaning is being used.

meaning.explanation: A man's gender is known as "male." Note that this can only refer to a human's gender; you're going to learn the word you use for animals, plants, etc. later on!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A person whose ideas are grounded in evil is a malicious, mean jerk!

reading.explanation: This reading is a combination of the on'yomi readings for 意 and 地, and the kun'yomi reading for 悪. You've learned them all already, but since 地 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: Malicious, mean jerks get sent to Jesus (じ) to sort them out. If anyone can sort out those malicious jerks, it’s Jesus!

meaning.explanation: You've hopefully seen how 登る means "to climb." So, if you're climbing a mountain what is that? It's mountain climbing. In case you're wondering what the difference is between this and 登山, they are essentially the same. The main difference is that 山登り is a little less formal, and is generally used as a standalone word, whereas 登山 can be used in compound words like 登山家 (mountaineer).

reading.explanation: The reading comes from combining 山 and 登る together to form one word, 山登り. If you know the readings of those two words you know the reading of this word too.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji move. So it means movement.

reading.explanation: This is the same reading you learned from the word 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

meaning.explanation: When it's bright around, things become more obvious, clear and evident.

reading.explanation: Since this is a word that consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it uses kun'yomi. Unfortunately, 明 is a little tricky and has a few of those. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember this one: It's obvious that all you need is a key (あき) to open this door. It's like, blatantly clear. The lock is right there. You really just need a key. Did you forget it? Of course you did…

meaning.explanation: One circumference is one time around, or in racetrack sports, one lap. How many times will you go around the moon? Just 一周?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the いち becomes いっ as it often does when being used in a counter (一階, 一回, etc.).

meaning.explanation: Opened and closed things are opening and closing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The remainder of time that you work at the ol' business is extra time that you're working (above the normal work hours). This is overtime!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The circumference that surrounds us is the perimeter of the area. Do not cross it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your gender and status are part of your personality. Think about what gender you identify as, and what your current status is (in relationships, residency, employment...). Now think about how all that affects your personality!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to think too hard.

meaning.explanation: The pine leaves are not really leaves, they're more like needles, thus making this word pine needle. 松葉 is commonly used in compounds, such as 松葉ガニ (snow crab) or 松葉づえ (crutches).

reading.explanation: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 葉 gets rendaku'd to ば though, so watch out for that.

meaning.explanation: This is a tricky word that doesn't really have a good translation. The best ways I've seen it done in terms of getting a meaning across are please and please help me. When you say this word you're kind of saying "please help me out and I'm relying on you and you're kind of awesome too." Anyways, please is a pretty good way to do it. So, when you see this word you'll notice it has the request kanji in it. You can guess you're requesting something. What is that thing? It's help (please help me) and you're asking very nicely too (please).

reading.explanation: You ask for help by saying please help me, and that person does try to help you... but the amount they do for you is so negligible that it hardly does anything to help you at all. Please try to help me again, this time better?

meaning.explanation: You know that 流行 means "trend", so "trend" language means a popular phrase. Yolo! It could also be a catchphrase, a popular word, or a buzzword.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You know that 流行 refers to a "trend." So, a "trend" song is a popular song.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A promise bundle is still a promise no matter how many you have wrapped up there. One promise is just another promise which is just another promise.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When your eye is on the target you know your purpose. You also have your eye on the goal (that's the target, after all!).

reading.explanation: The reading is a reading for 目 that's abnormal. You've seen this reading with 目標 and 目次, though, so hopefully it won't be too hard at this point. Just imagine telling someone your 目的, only to have them laugh in your face and begin mocking もく you for it. Now you're not so sure if your goal is going to work.

meaning.explanation: If you have reason in your nature, you have reason, sense and intellect. This is "reason" as in logical thinking.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This has the same meaning as the kanji. The little り thrown on there is just a little remainder sticking off the end of the kanji. No need to pay attention to that.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're waiting inside. The remainder of your forces are out there, fighting. You don't know who will survive... or if they even will. You have a secret knock (のこ), though, that you use to find out if it's one of the remaining forces outside or the enemy, broken through. You hear a knock. What is it? Is it your men or theirs? Imagine it out, focusing on the knock conversation that happens between you and the remainder.

meaning.explanation: A beforehand promise is a promise you've made beforehand. This is a reservation or appointment. Makes sense, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You know that 回転 is "rotation" and you probably know what すし is (gets rendaku'd in this word to ずし). So, what is "rotation sushi?" It's rotating sushi, also known as conveyor belt sushi. Look it up if you don't know what it is.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 回転, so be sure to know that to know this one. Also, it's just the readings of the kanji you learned too, so shouldn't be too hard.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 文化 means "culture?" Well add festival to it and you end up with a culture festival! These happen all the time at Japanese schools, so sometimes they're called school festivals too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned all of these readings already, good for you!

meaning.explanation: A gender sickness is one you catch from *ahem* doing things with those of another or the same gender. You only catch these sicknesses this way, meaning they're sexually transmitted diseases (save yourself some typing and just answer with STD).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You like the status of what's in front of you. It has an excellent shape and form to it. Imagine something that would be pleasing to you in terms of its shape.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be sure to note the かく reading, which gets changed to かっ.

meaning.explanation: The art ability world is the world of show business, or in other words, the entertainment industry. To get into show business, you need abilities in the arts, after all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A diagram everyone joins together to see is a signal or a sign.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 合 and the on'yomi reading for 図. You know them both now, so you should be able to read this too!

meaning.explanation: The status of your bones (aka how they're all arranged and put together) equals your skeleton. That bone status is lookin' good on you!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that こつ changes to こっ.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 運動 means "exercise?" When you meet with a bunch of other people to exercise it's called Sports Day! This is a day at schools in Japan where everybody does physical stuff together! It's fun and also very tiring!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: With 待ち you know you're waiting, but what's a ぼうけ? Turns out it's the long version of ボケ which means idiot. Basically, in this case you're a waiting idiot. Why? because you were stood up.

reading.explanation: The reading for 待ち comes right from 待つ. You know the drill by now.

meaning.explanation: A closed shop is when a store's status is store closed or closed store.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some strawberries to celebrate!

meaning.explanation: A hard stubborn person is very stubborn no matter how you look at them. Try to break through that hard stubbornness and all you'll find is more stubborn.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Water wear is a swimsuit, bathing suit, or swimwear.

reading.explanation: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with the vocab word 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

meaning.explanation: A person who has great talent and ability has quite the talent.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The four seasons are the four seasons. For some reason many Japanese people think that Japan's the only place with four distinct seasons. Obviously they haven't been to half the places on their latitude around the world.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 四 is read using the on'yomi reading, which you've seen a few times over the course of WaniKani. Think of し meaning "death" (like 死), and how with the four seasons there comes death every Fall and Winter.

meaning.explanation: When you arrange something with reason you're arranging it. That's why this is to arrange.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: There is an interval (of time) that you need "to suit" (合う). To suit that interval, you need to be there before the time in question. That's why this word means to be in time for, to make it on time or to be on time for.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading for 間 when you learned 間もなく. And the reading for 合う is just that of the word 合う. If you remember them both, you'll remember this word!

meaning.explanation: Hey. Drop yourself down and arrive back to me. You're going nuts over there. Lower down. Come back. Arrive. You need to do these things to calm down.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 落ちる and 着く. Hopefully you know these words so you can read this word as well! If you don't, just 落ち着く and everything will be okay.

meaning.explanation: The kanji itself means participate, so you'd think this word would mean "to participate" but it's a little more complex than that. Think of it as "to participate" but where you have to come or to go in order to do it. This is the humble way to say those things, so you're going to these places with your tail between your legs, just happy you can participate more than anything. By extension, this is also a humble way to say to visit, often used if you're visiting something sacred like a shrine or a tomb.  Historically, this word arose as a humble way to indicate visiting a person of higher social status. In a weird twist, this word has come to also mean to be defeated or to be at a loss. Think of it as what can happen when you're trying to participate while in an inferior position to someone or something.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You get to come to participate! "It's my (まい) lucky day!" you exclaim.

meaning.explanation: You know how 消化 is "digestion"? Well, The verb form of that is this word, which is to digest.

reading.explanation: If you know 消化 you should be able to read this. Also, it uses the readings you learned with the kanji anyways, so no problemo there.

meaning.explanation: You've seen that 消す is "to extinguish." So, this is another verb version of that. This time, you're not doing the extinguishing, it's just happening. Something is going to disappear on its own. How can you differentiate this from 消す? Well, える allows you to notice how the object disappeared into thin air (える). You know you didn't do it, so it disappeared on its own, making it to disappear.

reading.explanation: The reading is different from 消す, unfortunately, so you can't use that. Just think about how after the object in front of you disappears you use a key (き) to open an invisible door. That's where everything's disappearing to! You see all your disappeared stuff on the other side of this invisible door which you opened with a magical key.

meaning.explanation: Hopefully you know the word 期待 by now (expectation). This is the verb version, which makes it to expect.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 期待, so make sure you know that to know this one as well.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fold or break, so the vocab verb version is to fold something or to break something

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You fold your obi (お) really carefully and put it away with the rest of your kimono.

meaning.explanation: You know that the alternative kanji meaning for 合 is join, which is what we're using here. The verb form of join is to join together, and it can also mean to unify and to match.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 合う, so if you know that reading you'll know this reading as well.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wait so this word has something to do with waiting. Use the たせ as a hint. Someone "tossed" a ball off into a ditch, and then they had to find it. They made you wait for them to get the ball too, even though it's a cheap piece of crap. Feel upset about this. That'll help you remember that this means to make someone wait and to keep someone waiting.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading from 待つ, congrats!

meaning.explanation: You've seen 動く hopefully, and know it means to move. This is similar to that, but now you're moving something else. You know this because as you go to move something the thing you're moving starts to cuss (かす) you out because it's angry.

reading.explanation: The reading for this can come from 動く. If you know that word, you know how to read this word!

meaning.explanation: The remainder of your thoughts are very small. You've thought of everything you possibly can to solve this problem. In the end, the remainder of your thoughts is left with one phrase: "too bad." There's nothing else to think but the remainder.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The status joins together. Think of this like a bunch of status messages on Facebook, all coming together at the same time. A big government test has just finished. Everyone's status' are joining on Facebook together to say they passed, showing to pass a test.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Another verb for this kanji! Crazy! I know, I'm sorry. The previous ones were: 着る (to wear), 着く (to arrive), and now 着ける (to put on / to wear). At least it's similar to 着る, right? In this case, this word is like 付ける, which means "to attach." It's used for things you "attach" to your body to wear, like accessories, or a face mask. That's why this is to put on or to wear. Same sound, different kanji, similar ideas.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 着く's reading, but it might be easier to think it shares a reading with 付ける, which has a similar meaning. Put on clothes, attach on clothes, etc.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means remainder, so the verb vocab version is "to remainder." Let's make that sound better: to remain behind.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to remain behind. Everyone else leaves, and you think you're alone. Then, someone knocks (のこ) on the door. Your heart jumps in your throat. They knock again.

meaning.explanation: You know that 回転 means "rotation" or "revolution." So, what happens when you make it into a verb? It becomes to rotate and to revolve.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 回転 of level 10. Alternatively, you can just use the readings of the kanji as well. EZPZ.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stream? It's to stream (though it's also to flow, a very similar word). You can differentiate this from 流す because with 流す you flush something down the toilet, which causes it to overflow so you sue (す) the toilet maker. With 流れる you find a rare (れる) jewel trying to flow down the river. You grab it, and see it's a rare diamond!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 流す. So long as you know that you should be able to read this one as well!

meaning.explanation: You've seen 勉強 (study) by now, right? Well, this is the verb version of that. This is to study.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 勉強. It's also the readings you learned with these kanji.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surround so the verb vocab version is to surround or to enclose.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: People surround you. They circle around you, calling you a chicken. "Cacko! (かこ) Cacko! Cacko!" Wait, this isn't the sound a chicken makes, right? You laugh at them, thinking their way of making a chicken noise is weird. Go ahead and join in with them and say "Cacko" with them as well.

meaning.explanation: You've hopefully seen 旅行 by this point. This is the verb version of that. Instead of "trip" it's to travel or to take a trip. These are fun to do. You should do them!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 旅行, but it also happens to use the reading you learned with the kanji anyways, so you should be able to read it.

meaning.explanation: You've seen 起きる which is "to wake up." This is similar, except you are waking someone else up, which makes the meaning of this word to wake someone up. How do you differentiate between this and 起きる? Because of the す on the end. You wake someone up violently, wrenching their neck. They turn around and sue (す) you, making you wish you never woke them up. This can also mean to cause something. I guess if you wake someone up and they're not a morning person, you could cause something... like trouble.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 起きる, so as long as you know that word you should be able to read this one. Of course, you can also imagine them yelling "OH!" when you shake them awake too, if that helps.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends in an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 温 means warm. So the verb 温まる means to warm up or to get warm.  温まる is intransitive, so no direct object needed. Your cat warms up in the sunlight, for example. No direct object, right? A hint for this is that 温まる ends with okurigana that rhyme with ある, and those kinds of verbs tend to be intransitive!

reading.explanation: The kanji reading is the same as 温かい and 温める.

meaning.explanation: If you have a hope and you turn it into a verb, you'd think it would be "to hope." But what is really behind a hope? It's a desire or wish, right? That's why this word means to wish or to desire.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your one wish that you have is to have a bigger nose (のぞ). Feel your nose, it's too small. You wish it was two or three inches longer. Of course, if it helps to imagine you want a smaller nose or a nose at all, that's fine too. Just make sure you wish you have something nose-related.

meaning.explanation: You've seen that 旅行 is "trip." So who is someone who goes on trips? That is a tourist or traveler.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know the reading of 旅行 already.

meaning.explanation: The things you wear below your other clothes. That is your underwear. You do wear underwear, right?

reading.explanation: The reading for this one is all kun'yomi vocab reading, but you should know these by now. 着 uses the reading you learned with 着る, but this word employs that pesky rendaku, so remember that き becomes ぎ here.

meaning.explanation: Things that are targeted as Japanese are more than just Japanese, they are very Japanese. This word may be hard to understand at first, but there are many things the Japanese consider to be Japanese-only. These theories range from reasonable to ridiculous, but either way, you'll see them described as 日本的.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help if you know how to read 日本 as well.

meaning.explanation: The place you wait to join other people is a waiting room or a meeting place.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings, but it's like the hiragana that normally sticks out is stuffed in. 待ち → 待, 合い → 合 and is pronounced the same too. I know it's confusing, but once you get it down you'll never forget!

meaning.explanation: I with a ら on it makes it plural. It's less formal than 俺たち (if you've seen that word yet), but has the same meaning. It's we.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji's reading.

meaning.explanation: A well door is just a well. It's the door that goes into the well hole, making it a well.

reading.explanation: This kanji uses the kun'yomi readings for each kanji, for some reason. You learned the kun'yomi reading for both of these kanji as their primary readings already, just watch out for 戸 getting rendaku'd so it becomes ど instead of と.

meaning.explanation: What’s another word for a wolf man? A werewolf, obviously.

reading.explanation: You learned the reading for 狼 in both the kanji and the vocabulary word. The reading for 男 comes from the vocabulary 男. Put them together and you get おおかみおとこ. Awoooo.

meaning.explanation: A hope is really a wish that you have inside of you (though it can still be a hope too).

reading.explanation: What's your one big wish? It's to have a different nose (のぞ). Alternatively, you could think "nose on me" for のぞみ.

meaning.explanation: When there's nothing but folds and angles, you have quite a mess. This word means with trouble because you certainly aren't traversing along a nice, flat piece of space-time, are you? Nah, it's all angled and folded. 折角 is one of those tricky Japanese words that doesn’t have one neat translation in English. The nuance is that something has come about with trouble, either through someone’s efforts, or a stroke of luck. It often implies regret, and is used in situations where you want to express that valuable opportunities, advice, or hard work were in vain for some reason. It’s also used to underline a rare chance that shouldn’t be missed.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Watch out for the せつ changing to せっ, though. Another thing you have to go through with trouble, I'm afraid.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Wood that is lumber is lumber wood. Technically speaking, 木材 is used more for lumber or wood that hasn't been processed yet — less like planks, more like freshly cut lumber still lying on the forest floor. But it's not a hard rule or anything, so don't worry too much about the nuances.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Drinking as much as you want is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an all you can drink place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 放題 (ほうだい) and 飲む (のむ). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

meaning.explanation: When you eat as much as you want, you are getting an all you can eat deal.

reading.explanation: The reading consists of the readings of 食べる and 放題. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

meaning.explanation: A strange person is an eccentric. They are also an oddball.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The noun form of request (don't be tricked by the い on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to a request.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same like お願いします. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: You need art techniques to make art. Without art techniques, the arts and fine art simply wouldn’t exist.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, あき.

meaning.explanation: You compare examples, trying to figure out in which way they're being proportional. You know these examples you're comparing are in proportion to one another, you just need to figure out how.  Use 比例 when talking about how one thing changes in proportion to another. Like the price of a good in proportion to its supply and demand, for instance. Check out our common word combinations and context sentences for some examples!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The director who is above you is your boss or superior.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, so you can read this one!

meaning.explanation: The England country is where England is. This word can refer to Britain, the United Kingdom and England! Note that イギリス is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to Buddha. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm hot, okay?" (ほとけ). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off.  Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.

meaning.explanation: The buddha teachings are what you have to learn when you're studying Buddhism.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 仏 gets changed to ぶっ for this one.

meaning.explanation: When you measure and then calculate something, you are making a calculation. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Meow!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Neko neko neko! Kawaiiiii.

meaning.explanation: The account of a generation... this covers a whole generation, and considering how long Japanese people live, this account totals a whole century.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. In fact, this kanji's on'yomi AND kun'yomi are しき, so you can never go wrong.

meaning.explanation: Change and change equals even more change. 変化 generally refers to a natural or spontaneous change, like changes from growth or aging, alterations in weather conditions, or shifts in one's emotions.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: If you say something is going to clear up, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes this clear weather or sunny. Maybe because of those connotations, 晴れ can also be used to describe special occasions that are usually public. For example, a wedding or a big recital might be called a 晴れの場 (special occasion). Similarly, the special clothing you wear to such events is called 晴れ着 (formal attire).

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: You know how 器用 means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're not those things. When you're not dextrous, you're clumsy and when you're not skillful you're unskillful.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of 不 changes from ふ to ぶ. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of boo-boos (ぶ), get it?

meaning.explanation: What does the narrative origin have coming after it? Well, the way we've counted years for the past couple of millenia has a specific narrative at its origin, and everything that comes after it is the Common Era, aka AD, or anno Domini. Just in case you don't know what narrative we're talking about: it's the narrative of Jesus's birth, which is the year that we say the Common Era started.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When you believe in your self you have plenty of confidence (or self confidence). This is a good thing to have!

reading.explanation: How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: That feeling of courage is courage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: トランプ comes from the English word "trump", as in "a trump card", but it means deck of cards or playing cards in Japanese. The Japanese meaning probably comes from card games played by English-speaking Westerners back in the day. Japanese people heard the word "trump" a lot, and assumed it meant a deck of cards.

The earth district isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a district, area, or zone.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

meaning.explanation: When you can't (not) believe in someone, it's because you distrust them. Maybe someone discredited them and now you mistrust everything they say.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: English meeting and talking with each other. This is English Conversation. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an English and Japanese (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is English Japanese.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The English language is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the English language. It is English.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: England writing is English Writing (or if you want to be fancy, English Composition).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Every night is simply every night. What do you do every night?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: What you believe in your heart, and not in your head, is your faith. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all faith.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.

meaning.explanation: When you create beauty with your techniques, that’s fine art, or simply art.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: If you eat and find yourself in the middle of poison, you've probably got food poisoning. No fun when you get this :(

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Four small animals is four small animals. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The luck island wasn't actually too lucky. This is Fukushima where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.

reading.explanation: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.

meaning.explanation: A large Buddha doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the Great Buddha or Giant Buddha Statue.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This word is made of now and night with the hiragana は at the end. The は here is pronounced as わ (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying good evening. Just keep in mind that writing 今晩は is pretty old school. These days it's almost always written as こんばんは.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

meaning.explanation: The method of writing is how you write. You can have vocabulary words, but you have to be able to put them together using some kind of method. This method happens to be grammar.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほう changes to ぽう.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is usually used for clothing height and length.

reading.explanation: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with bamboo (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!

meaning.explanation: If you ride a horse, that's horseback riding or, in some parts of the world, simply horse riding.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 乗, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Know who loves horseback riding? That's right, Joe (じょう) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your husband even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's Otto (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the auto (おっと) shop.

meaning.explanation: A not law is something that's against the law. It's illegal or unlawful.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: An occurrence that causes change somehow can also be called an incident.  事変 is a formal word for big, unexpected incidents that are disruptive and chaotic. This can involve natural disasters, sudden riots, or other large-scale disturbances that need military intervention. It can also refer to unannounced warfare. You'll most likely see this word used in names for historical events, like the Manshuu Jihen (満州事変), or the Manchurian Incident. The 変 kanji suggests "change," so you know 事変 is only used for historical incidents big enough make things change!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When you get someone to transmit information, they're a type of intermediary, a go-between, if you will.

reading.explanation: When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  When the go-between gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him two takes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second. Little side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in ツテ, or hiragana, as in つて. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!

meaning.explanation: A child cat is an adorable kitten. D'awww!

reading.explanation: The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).

meaning.explanation: Yesterday's year was actually last year. Today must be New Years then!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When things are put in a row they end up forming a line. This can be a line of people or a line of random stuff.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at noon it's your lunch break! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a noon break instead.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to cooked rice, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself. This word has a slightly gruff feel to it so it's used mostly in informal situations.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a meal... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a Mesh (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

meaning.explanation: The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy. When it comes to food, it's nice to be those things. This has the same meaning as the kanji (meal) making it meal, but it also refers to cooked rice as well. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can be both "come eat your rice" and "come eat your meal." Really, since most Japanese meals come with rice, though, you can see how the overlap happens.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "hand" me another bowl of rice?

meaning.explanation: The way method or the method way is the method or way. This is a good word for talking about how to do something. What's the 方法? Well, first you...

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning pitiable and miserable.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: When you kill a person that's murder.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.

meaning.explanation: You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, someone who does murder is what? A murderer.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The sea army are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The navy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading here is the same as the kanji reading!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can also mean lunch, especially when used with the honorific prefix お, as in お昼.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji it comes from, so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: オノマトペ comes from the French word “onomatopée” which, as you can probably guess, means onomatopoeia. オノマトペ has a wider meaning than its English equivalent, and it also covers mimetic words, which are words that evoke ideas and actions rather than sounds.
What's the reason that something comes into being? Its origin, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a source, because it's always coming from somewhere.

reading.explanation: You didn't learn this reading for 由 so here's a mnemonic to help you: The best way to get close to the origin or source of something is to move into a yurt (ゆ). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 手 can mean a "doer"? Now, what do you think your mutual doer might be? It’s someone who shares the same activities or tasks with you. This person could be your partner, companion, or even an opponent in certain situations.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way:  Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: I (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."

meaning.explanation: If you take a ride as a guest (or a customer), that makes you a passenger.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You hopefully learned the on'yomi for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You notice a passenger getting on at your stop. Who is it? The distinct smell of barn animals and manure gives it away immediately: it’s Joe (じょう), the farmhand!

meaning.explanation: You need measurements and images to make a plan. You can't follow a plan without measurements and images to refer to, right? Any good plan has measurements and drawings.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is the same as the kanji's reading.

meaning.explanation: Poison Gas is a nasty thing. It is poison gas.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji it comes from. The ガス is of course "gas."

meaning.explanation: You're in the middle of poison, meaning you have poisoning.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When something has poison it is poisonous and toxic.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You gotta believe it will return. What are you believing in returning? The reply. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A finger ring is the kind of ring you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.

reading.explanation: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as ゆびわ.

meaning.explanation: A ring of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a rubber band.

reading.explanation: The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word わゴム.

meaning.explanation: A big change is a really serious thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a terrible event.  Also, in more recent history this has come to mean very as well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shallow? It's shallow.

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, making this あさい.

meaning.explanation: If you're moving towards (に) simple, you're saying simply, merely, or only.

reading.explanation: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your skill and ability are kind of similar things. That's why this word means either or. Your skill ability is your skill and ability.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as this one.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: An army person is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're soldiers.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A stubborn height is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially solid, firm, and stout.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The first time something reaches your ear, it's something heard for the first time. If it's never entered your ear before, it's news to you!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings, because 初 behaves more like a prefix here. You already know how to read 耳, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for 初 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Whatever it is, this something heard for the first time, be sure to hold onto your hats (はつ)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be news to me, too.

meaning.explanation: Your special skill is your specialty. So, what is your 特技?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Ah, the beauty of spring! Err... はる, I mean.

meaning.explanation: You've seen 夏休み and 冬休み. If that isn't enough, you can see that this is a spring rest of some kind. That would be a spring break or spring vacation.

reading.explanation: The reading for 春 is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. The 休み part is the same as the vocab word 休み, which hopefully you can read! If you know those readings, you can read this too.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is more the "strange" meaning though, not the "change" one. As in, you 変な猫！

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. How strange! Or not.

meaning.explanation: With the height of my husband, he's very firm. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and sturdy due to his height.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: You're making things in two different places be exactly the same for a period of time. You're in the middle of a process called syncing. You can see 同期中 a lot in computery contexts, or if you change your device language to Japanese. (Not that I recommend that...)

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something with a beauty taste is something that is really tasty or delicious. Mmmm, yum! While 美味しい mostly describes tasty food, you may also occasionally see it being used for a sweet deal or situation that benefits you.

reading.explanation: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something delicious. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "OI (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"
