meaning.explanation: When you big rule over a territory, you're probably a pretty great leader. A president, perhaps?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well

meaning.explanation: When you value status you really care about the price of things. And usually the higher the value, the higher the cost. 価格 refers to something's market value, or to product pricing in a broader sense. It's sort of a formal word, so you might see it on fliers or in business and economic discussions about pricing strategies, for example.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Things with value have prices. 物価 refers to the prices of goods and services in a place — the prices of commodities, a.k.a. the cost of living. It's used when discussing how expensive it is to live somewhere or when talking about inflation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ぶつ changes to ぶっ, though, so hopefully that doesn't change the price you're willing to pay for this vocab? Right? Please give me your money.

meaning.explanation: Anything that's privately managed is private and privately run.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Please present your plan in the form of a proposition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something that is publicly managed is something that is public aka government run. Compare this to 私営 which is private / privately run.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Please indicate this in a public way. How about a public announcement? This word refers to formal public announcements, like parliamentary elections by the Emperor or land price disclosures by the Land Appraisal Committee.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The region that is this ground is the region / area. Just think of each area of ground. Each area is each region.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You’re renewing something to become new again. We’re talking about a renewal or update to something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something that is managed by the city is run by the city, or city-run.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Prefecture managed things are run by the prefecture.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A side business is a side business.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Let's go view some sunlight! Oh wait, we can't do that here. We will have to go sightseeing to go see this amazing sunlight thing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You already learned the kun'yomi reading for this kanji, so you should be good to go!

meaning.explanation: Are you visiting a neat place? Grab some dirt and bring it back with you. Then pretend to give birth to it in front of your friends. That dirt is now a special souvenir! It's the best present you could ever give someone!

reading.explanation: These readings are exceptions, sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone asks you who gave you a souvenir, just say "Miya gave (みやげ) it to me." Who's Miya? No idea. But neither do they. You never have to remember who gave you anything ever again! Miya gave you everything you own. She's probably a great person.

meaning.explanation: A waiting machine is a machine on standby. This word doesn’t always apply to machines though. It could be a person who’s on standby, in which case you might also say they’re on call.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What is your main view? Your subjective view, of course! This can be your own subjective opinion, and also refers to the idea of the subjective in general (as opposed to the objective). It can be hard to step back and look at things without your own unique biases and perspectives.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Go ahead and present then exit. This will be your presentation of the materials. Perhaps it's the submission of your resignation, or the filing of a complaint, which explains why you exit so quickly afterwards. You could also just be handing in your homework, though.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The side topic is the subtitle or subheading, for example of a book or an article.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You must respond with aid in order to show your support for someone who needs it. You can usually show your support if you root for them.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: To support and aid is to support.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your butt tail is just your tail, though I wonder why they had to specify that it was your butt tail. Where else do you have a tail, I wonder?

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is a bit of an exception. You kind of already know the reading for 尻 from the kun'yomi しり you learned already. Here it gets shortened to しっ. The reading for 尾 is totally different from what you learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The animal with the best tail in the world is the polar (ぽ) bear. They're stubby and white and cute. Only polar bears have tails like that!

meaning.explanation: The soil that makes up your territory is your territory. Ain't nobody goin' set foot on my soil nuh'uh.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Some people have a difficult time saying thank you. But not you now that you know how! This is often written in kana, so you don't need to use the kanji when writing. But you'll sometimes see the kanji used so it's important to be able to recognize them! Did you know this is an abbreviation of 有難うございます? You can also spell it like this: 有難う.

reading.explanation: You've heard people say ありがとう before right?!

meaning.explanation: This one is a little strange. You have 混じる (to get mixed up in), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混む, to be crowded. It makes sense that when everyone's all mixed up it's going to be crowded, but how to differentiate between this and the other 混 words? Just think of how cows muuuuu (む) get all bunched up and crowded, which is why this word is to be crowded.

reading.explanation: Hey, come (こむ) out of that crowd of cows. It's going to be crowded in there.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, meaning that the piercing just happens, without emphasis on what makes it happen. That's why this verb means to be pierced, to get pricked, or to be stabbed. This is a tricky one because the English translations often end up being transitive, but in Japanese we always use this with the particle に, not を, so it's intransitive.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 刺す.

meaning.explanation: Know how 非難 is a criticism? Make it a verb and you have the word to criticize.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, it will be really helpful to know the word 非難 to start.

meaning.explanation: You know that 検査 is inspection, so the verb version of that would be to inspect.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 検査 already as well.

meaning.explanation: Know how 存在 is existence? Well, make it a verb and then you have to exist.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You've seen how 倒す is "to knock over." But this is when something gets knocked over by itself. You know that you're not doing anything here, because when you're not touching all these fine glass items, it's very rare (れる) that anything gets knocked over (because you're not touching anything, you clumsy dumsy). It's also when you or someone else collapses. You didn't push yourself over, you just kind of fell by yourself.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same like 倒す. If you knew 倒す you will know the reading of this one too.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means give up or abandon so the verb version is to give up or to abandon.

reading.explanation: You hopefully learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a reminder just in case: Just before you're ready to give up on something, you yell, "AKIRA (あきら)!". You don't know anyone named Akira, you just saw it in a movie once and it made sense, you know? So now when you've tried really hard on something, but you have to abandon it anyway, you shout AKIRA into the sky. I just did it while trying to write this mnemonic!

meaning.explanation: You know that 手洗い is "handwashing" (and also a not as polite way to mention a bathroom). When you add お you're suddenly making it polite. Why? Because you're talking about something a little more crass than handwashing. You're talking about the toilet or restroom or bathroom. Ewww. Poop goes there.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 手洗い, so if you know that you'll know this too!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means indicate so the verb vocab version is to indicate or to show. This is used in contexts like "a study shows that learning Japanese is fun" and "I demonstrated my willingness to learn kanji".

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Studies seem to indicate and to show that sheep men (しめ) are better than regular men in every way. The sheep/man combo is a powerful thing. Or so studies indicate.

meaning.explanation: 判断 is judgement. Make that into a verb and you have to judge, or to conclude.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 判断 before learning this, but if you don't I won't judge you (the Crabigator will).

meaning.explanation: Remember how 飛ぶ is to fly? Well this word is for when you make some thing fly. So, this word is to let something fly or to send something flying. It also means to skip over something, such as someone's turn or a question on a test.

reading.explanation: The reading is just like 飛ぶ, so if you know that reading you're close. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember the second part: You can use your strength to let something fly, and that something is a bus (ばす). You're that buff!

meaning.explanation: Like with 確か, which means certain, this is the verb version of that. So when you "do certain" you are going to make sure of something or you're going to verify something.

reading.explanation: This one is kun'yomi followed by okurigana. If you remember the reading you learned with 確かに, you should know this one!

meaning.explanation: The pressure used easily collapses whatever it's pushing against. That's why this verb means to overwhelm.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the あつ goes to あっ, as you'd probably expect.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surpass, but this verb is intransitive, meaning we’re not focussing on who did the action, but on the action itself. So this means to pass, as in “the storm passed”, to be over as in “winter’s over”, or to be too much.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order for the storm to pass you’re going to have to sue (す) it. Sadly storms won’t pass unless you take legal action these days.

meaning.explanation: You know how 経 means passage of time, right? Well, this is the verb form of that. What does time do when it passages? It passes. So, this verb means to pass or to elapse.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you say to time as it begins to pass you by? "Ta ta (た), Time!"

meaning.explanation: When you do a penalty to someone you are trying to punish or to penalize them.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Just remember that the つ becomes a small っ so I don't have to punish you.

meaning.explanation: When you put something you don't just put it, you have to put down this item or even (to) set down the item. Basically, you have to put something down with this verb. It's a little different from the kanji meaning you learned but not that different.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just imagine you're putting down Oreos (お). One after another. Each oreo that you try to put down say in your head "Hello Mr. Oreo, I'm going to put you down.. ooh yes, you like that don't you?" REPEAT.

meaning.explanation: If 在留 is residence, then the verb version of that would be to reside. Like 在留, this is also a more formal term. You might encounter it at the immigration office, but you probably won't hear it in everyday conversation.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 在留 so you should be able to read this one already!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means respond so the verb vocab version is to respond. 応じる is a formal word that describes acting favorably in response to a call, request, or demand. For example, 注文に応じる goes beyond just taking orders; it means adapting appropriately and fulfilling them.

reading.explanation: The reading is actually the same as the one you learned with the kanji! Not too shabby.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means manage, but when you manage something, what are you usually managing? How about a business? So this word means to run a business even though the kanji is manage.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to run a business. Your business is to make people eat who don't want to eat. "HEY, YOU EAT NOW!" (いとな).

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earthquake so the verb means to shiver and to shake, like you would if there was an earthquake happening right now.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You start to shake in an earthquake because you're really full (ふる) from eating lunch. Now your full belly is shaking and quaking with the ground! Ahh it's awful! You never want to be full again!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sleep or lie down, so the verb vocab version is to sleep or to lie down—just like what you do when you decide to go to bed.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. So, you can go ahead and lie down for a moment before moving on to the next item.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means suck so the verb vocab version is to suck, but it's usually used to talk about what you do to cigarettes, so a better translation I think is to smoke.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You smoke too much, and that gives you cancer. You decide to sue (す) the cigarette makers.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means view so what is the verb vocab version? It's to view or to watch.

reading.explanation: The reading here is actually the same as 見る. This is easy to remember because the meanings are so similar too, not to mention it has a 見 right inside the kanji itself!

meaning.explanation: When you transmit something that unites the people, you are probably pulling on tradition. Tradition is what unites us all and transmits who we are to everyone else. What is your 伝統? 伝統 means "tradition" in the sense of customs, practices, or rituals that are passed down within a culture or community. These traditions bring people together across generations and keep our shared culture alive.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something is a trouble (面倒) and it is smelly (臭い). So what is something that's smelly and a trouble? Well, something that's troublesome or a bother, I suppose. Basically you can ignore the smelly part. For some reason someone threw that back in, but smelly things are a bother, I suppose.

reading.explanation: The reading is the words 面倒 plus 臭い added together. Just make sure you know those words and you'll know this one too!

meaning.explanation: If you undress from clothes you are undressing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that happens outside the plan is something that happens unexpectedly.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When you unite and join things together, you get unification! This can also mean integration and consolidation, which are essentially other ways to describe things being united.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Unify them.

meaning.explanation: Bad feelings that you dislike are unpleasant feelings. These unpleasant feelings include things like hatred, disgust, revulsion, and fear. All of those are considered to be a part of the term unpleasant feelings.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already so you should be able to read this one too!

meaning.explanation: A value is a value, but only in the mathematical sense. Depending on the reading, this can also mean price.

reading.explanation: Imagine a numerical value written on a tie (あたい). Now imagine that it’s the price of a neigh (ね) from your favorite horse. It’s a pretty high price, but you’ll do anything to hear that horse neigh. Generally, あたい refers to a numerical value in math, while ね is a formal word for “price.”

meaning.explanation: A value and a value. Obviously this is something that has much value.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The someones (people) who incur damage are the victims. WILL SOMEBODY THINK OF THE VICTIMS HERE???

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 被害 as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned! Now you just have to make sure you know what a Wisteria is... This word is often found in names, like a lot, so look out for it in that way.

meaning.explanation: When there's a district in a region, it's called a zone or district. 区域 is a formal word for a kind of designated area, usually one defined by specific boundaries or characteristics. It's often used in urban planning, like for no-parking zones or residential areas. It can also apply to regions like postal districts, police jurisdictions, or restricted areas.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You suck something in and obtain it. Shhheewwwwww! When you suck something in and obtain it into your body, you have done absorption because it's been sucked inside of you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your performance skill allows you to be great at acting and doing awesome performances.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A superior haiku requires someone really famous and well known to read it... it's just on that level. Who is super well known and who deserves to read this superior haiku? A great actor, perhaps?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A man who is superior to us is an actor, or more specifically a male actor. Just a word of warning: over the years this word has taken on the connotation of "adult film actor" so most people would use 俳優 for "actor" now. You'll be learning that word very soon!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The present time is the time you're actually in. You aren't really in any other time, because that's not how time works!

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Swamps and mountains happen a lot in Japan. That's why we use this to mean many! Because there are many of them!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word is usually written in kana though, so keep that in mind when you're writing it to use kana and not these kanji!

meaning.explanation: You know that 建築 is architecture. So, someone of house architecture is someone who does architecture. They are an architect.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 建築 already.

meaning.explanation: A samurai who uses speech to defend people. This samurai does their battle in the court of law. This "samurai" is an attorney or a lawyer.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A book shelf is a bookcase or bookshelf.

reading.explanation: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading first. Technically this is the "New Tree Trunk Line" but you wouldn't realize this is the Japanese bullet train aka Shinkansen from that, would you? Maybe going to the reading will help you after all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Read this to be able to remember the meaning, too, which is Shinkansen.

meaning.explanation: You exit the building and stretch in preparation for your business trip. This is the routine you always follow for your business trips: exit, and stretch.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful about しゅつ becoming しゅっ here!

meaning.explanation: This is where the bus (バス) halts. It's the bus stop.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A door shelf is a shelf with a door on it. What kinds of shelves do you know of that have doors on them? How about cabinets? Or maybe cupboards?

reading.explanation: These readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Just keep in mind that 棚 gets rendaku'd to だな.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. In modern Japanese, this word is not commonly used as a standalone term. However, it is often found as part of proper nouns that refer to geographic locations that have a cape, as well as family names that are associated with capes.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A renew clothes room is a changing room or a locker room. 更衣室 is a room where people change their clothes, commonly found in places like gyms, swimming pools, schools, or workplaces.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: There are member(s) of a committee (委員) all getting together to meet. This is the committee itself.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course it will help to know 委員 as well, since it's 2/3rds of the word.

meaning.explanation: You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that ism to people who want to protect and conserve their country so it stays just the way it is (forever). That's conservatism and they're conservative people.

reading.explanation: This word uses the reading of 保守的 for the first half and then the regular kanji readings for the second half. Combine those things and you'll be a master of righteousness and / or kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  Demons are mean. This particular demon bites you on the knee, creating an "O" shape on your knee. He tells you he has cursed you with the "O" knee (おに).

meaning.explanation: When something escapes from the line it should be on, that's a derailment. 脱線 can refer to train derailments (no surprise there), but often gets used figuratively to mean a digression, like in speech or writing. Do you ever derail conversations with your digressions?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Divide and calculate? Why, that's just division!

reading.explanation: This is the kun'yomi reading for 割 and the on'yomi for 算. And the さん reading is rendaku'd into ざん. This is the same for all the math-ish words (addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division), so try to remember that, because you'll see it again!

meaning.explanation: A medicine expert is someone who knows a lot about medicine. Those people are (I hope) generally doctors.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: If you dwell in a house, that house is your dwelling, or residence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: 経済 is economics. So, something that has to do with economics is the economic or financial situation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

meaning.explanation: You know how 経済 is economics, right? Well, add study to that and you have the study of economics, aka economics.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 経済 as well.

meaning.explanation: When you make a task you're looking for a certain effect or action. What task can you make right now to get the effect of learning more kanji?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 作 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: What's the effect of a saw on yogurt (さよう)? What will the action of the saw on the yogurt do? Seems futile, but you're going to try anyway. For science.

meaning.explanation: When you have employment you are probably employed.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: If you carry out something and go, the result is still enforcement, carrying out, or implementation of whatever it is. There’s no point hanging around after you’ve enforced something! So you always carry out and go.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. You might sometimes see せこう as an alternative reading, but しこう is the more common version.

meaning.explanation: A public company is a government-run company or a government-owned company. In other words, it's a company that's run by national or local government in the interests of the public.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Take your finger and lead with it. Just point at things. Tell people where they need to go, what they need to do, all with your finger leading them. This is guidance you are providing.

reading.explanation: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

meaning.explanation:
A haiku paragraph is just a haiku. Haikus are little haiku paragraphs. You will learn kanji
The Crabigator watches
He feeds on reviews

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Just like its kanji, this word means house or home. By extension, it also sometimes means household. It can go after someone’s name to say whose house it is, as in 山田宅 (Yamada’s house), and after words that give more information about the house, such as 女性宅 (women’s homes).

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go home now.

meaning.explanation: Please enter what you've obtained in here. We'll divvy it all up later. But we have to enter it all here so we know our income.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Go ahead and carry out the task and establish the institution. To carry out and establish something is to institute it too. What do you institute? An institution.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You can guess this is an adjective from the い at the end. The meaning for the kanji is itchy, and the adjective version is itchy too.

reading.explanation: This word uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji: かゆ.

meaning.explanation: Ugh, time to request employment again. Time to go job hunting.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is one of those words that's easier to know if you jump to the reading first. Why? Because it's the name of a city. It's Kawasaki.

reading.explanation: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, making it Kawasaki.

meaning.explanation: Though there's no law about two kanji with the same meaning producing the same meaning, a law law is probably a law.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  Leather is the skin of a cow, right? How do you say "skin" in Japanese? Remember 皮 (かわ)? It has the same reading as that, and they're both skin, so hopefully that makes it easier to remember.

meaning.explanation: Skin leather is really just leather because leather is also skin. It's also hides.

reading.explanation: The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know them both already!

meaning.explanation: At  each  station someone keeps  halting the  car . What is this, a local train?! Yes, yes it is. You’re on a local train. People use it when they get on (or off) at the smaller stations. If you’re not used to train travel, just remember that a "local train" is one that stops at every station on a line.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You live in the most extravagant of swamps, which means you’re completely surrounded by luxury and extravagant things.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Cow milk is cow's milk, though most people just call cow's milk milk.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This word will be easier if you jump to the reading, since it's the name of a place, Nagasaki.

reading.explanation: The 長 is the kun'yomi reading, which comes from 長い. The 崎 part is the same reading that you learned with the kanji (though also kun'yomi). Combine those together and you have ながさき. Sound familiar? It should. This is the city of Nagasaki, one of the cities in which the A-bombs fell.

meaning.explanation: What is a milk neck? Think about where milk comes from. Now, think of what looks like a little neck on the thing that milk comes from. What is that thing? It's a nipple.

reading.explanation: The reading for this one is an exception, at least for the 乳 part. It's read as ち, and 首 is read as くび. You can remember the reading of nipple by thinking of a very special "nipple" you have on your face. A bee has burrowed into your cheek, and it squirts out milk from its butt, which sticks out of your cheek. You can't get it out, so you've decided to call this little cheek bee nipple your cheek bee (ちくび). Buzz buzz *milk*

meaning.explanation: An expert who watches over and defends people at all hours is the nurse. That's what nurses do, 24/7. They have to check up on people, defend their health, and watch over them, making sure they're okay. What a tough job.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your employment business is your occupation or profession. What is your employment business?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your self home is your own home. It's one's home.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You know that 主義 is "-ism." If you add that to being comfortable like you're in heaven then you have lots of optimism. You're sure you'll be okay in any situation! This is a noun in Japanese but, depending on the context, it's often translated into English as an adjective.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already know that 町 means "town" and that 外れ means "extremity" or "outskirts", and this is just a combination of the two. So this means the outskirts of town.

reading.explanation: You've already learned both 町 and 外れ, so just combine the two and you get 町外れ not only in meaning, but also in reading!

meaning.explanation: What's above the stage and involves acting? A performance! This word does not refer to an actor's acting on stage. Instead, it usually refers to a theatrical or musical presentation in its entirety, so is used in contexts relating to the act of staging an artistic or dramatic production, or features of the production itself, like its start time or running time (as in 上演時間).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you turn acting into art you get the performing arts. It is popular entertainment! Lights, action! Welcome to Broadway! This word is more traditional and isn't used very much these days.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The employment members of a workplace are the personnel or staff. Pretty straightforward! 職員 and 社員 are two similar terms, but have different meanings. 社員 generally refers to employees of private companies, while 職員 refers to employees who work in various fields such as civil service, education, government, non-profits, and more.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: It's both a law and a rule. This usually refers to something that is a physical law, but also can simply be a law, too. Anyways, lots of rules. Lots of laws. It's both, so the stronger one (law) takes precedence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your employment location is your place of work or place of employment. It's also your workplace. Are you using WaniKani at your 職場 right now? Wouldn't that be funny.

reading.explanation: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. That's all you have to remember, though, because you've seen both of these readings before!

meaning.explanation: When you halt electricity you experience a power outage. Makes sense. When the electricity stops you don't have any more power.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When you follow standard procedure to provide what's needed, you make the perfect preparation! Both 準備 and 用意 mean "preparation," but 準備 means preparing in advance for an event, whereas 用意 implies taking appropriate measures. So, 準備 is better for planning a party, while 用意 fits well when making sure you have enough snacks for your guests.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: In the present time we exist. What time is it? It's present and now. It is the current time!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: It was superior previously, so we need to go back there. That, amongst all the other things, is our highest priority.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

meaning.explanation: A purple color is purple. Simple as that!

reading.explanation: The reading for 紫 is different from the one you learned with the kanji. To remember this reading, think about how the previous village you went to was all purple. It was the "村先" (むらさき) that you went to. Everything. Absolutely everything was purple.

meaning.explanation: When you divide something into parts and join them back together, you are better able to evaluate the ratio or percentage of these parts in relation to the whole. Think of all these parts, neatly separated and then placed next to one another. It's only because you divided them that you get to see them this way. 割合 usually refers to the ratio of a certain part when compared to the whole, often expressed as a percentage. When used this way it's similar to 比率, but 割合 is more common in everyday language. Note that 割合 can also be used as an adverb, where it means comparatively or fairly.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this already!

meaning.explanation: The present is the truth. It is what's going on right now. It is reality.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: I obtain some territory, so I want a written record of it. How will I get a written record of my obtained territory? How about with a receipt? Emailing one will do just fine.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When people evaluate and judge you at every turn, it means you have quite a reputation, and indeed fame. Wouldn't this be terrible if people evaluated and judged you 24/7? Having that kind of reputation or fame would be difficult.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. This uses a slightly different reading from what you learned for 判, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your reputation is incredibly important to you, so don't let anybody know that you've been banned (ばん) on the WaniKani forums before. Wouldn't want anyone to find out. What, this is going to be published as a reading mnemonic on WaniKani?! What are you talking about? Oh sh-...

meaning.explanation: If you quit your place of employment, you are quitting, aka putting in your resignation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Leather's fate is in the hands of a revolution. It's the leather revolution! Off with these normal clothes and on with leather ones!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Let's divide the duty up amongst various people. Each person will have their own role in completing this duty.

reading.explanation: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. See how we divide up the duty of learning kanji into radicals and kanji and vocab? Makes it nice, right? Each piece is its own 役割.

meaning.explanation: Your present location is the scene of the crime! And you're on the scene to check out what's currently going on.

reading.explanation: The reading is a combination of the on'yomi and kun'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned already, so you should be able to read this.

meaning.explanation: 責任 is responsibility. If you add 感 you get a "feeling of responsibility." That's not really a thing people say. What people do say, however, is sense of responsibility. Do you have one?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A rain door is really just a shutter. In Japan, having shutters for rain protection is very common. When there were no glass windows, the shutters were simply like exterior doors in Japan, so "rain door" kind of makes sense as "shutter"!  This word is usually for sliding storm shutters. For other types of shutters, you can just say シャッター.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, but it actually uses kun'yomi for both 雨 and 戸. Additionally, the reading for 雨 is actually slightly different from what you've learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Have you ever thought a shutter is like an armor (あま) for a window? They're both protections, and are usually made from metal. Kind of makes sense, right?

meaning.explanation: A part of speech machine spits out speeches and words. It's all the machine is programmed to do.

reading.explanation: The reading for this is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you: The only font the machine can print speeches in is serif font (せりふ).

meaning.explanation: The foundation of your standard is where you place your standard. No more, no less. This foundation is where the standard is all based off of. This word generally refers to a quantitative "standard" that’s a basis for evaluation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Halt and stop. When something does this, it's in a stoppage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When something happens with a sudden nature, it happens... suddenly.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something that's superior will excel. It is superior and excellent in every way. This word is typically used to describe someone's superiority or excellence, often in comparison to others.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You're trying to escape from taxes? You scared of them? Huh? That's tax evasion, buddy. You're going to jail for that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A teaching expert/teacher is a teacher. 教師 is a relatively formal word for teachers. Unlike 先生, this word is specifically for people in the teaching profession and cannot be used as a name ender.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: One division is ten percent. You'll just have to imagine this in terms of tens going by. Must be some old Japanese percentage system that carried over or something. Just remember that one wari is ten percent, two waris are twenty percent, and so on.

reading.explanation: The readings are the same as what you learned with the kanji. You know much more than ten percent of this word's reading already.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means appear, so this word means to appear or to emerge.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: It looks like something is going to appear in front of you. You are so scared and surprised you can't even speak properly: "Are what??" (あらわ) you ask, trying to figure out what's appearing in front of you.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji 加 means add, and this verb means to be added to or to join in. It is an intransitive verb, like most verbs ending in わる. That means that it happens by itself, or at least the cause of the adding is not you. Something gets added to something else, perhaps by magic?

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 加える. To help you distinguish between the two, remember that most verbs ending in わる are intransitive.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 埋める means "to bury?" Well this is something that is being buried, maybe even you! Either way, you're not the one doing the burying. It means to be buried. 埋まる can also mean to be filled, like a pond being completely filled by dirt from a landslide or seats being filled at an event.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means build so the verb vocab version is to build.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think about what happens when you build something. What are you doing? You're standing it up. How do you say "to stand" in Japanese? たてる. That's the reading of this word as well. If you think about it they're similar!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call so the verb vocab version is to call or to call out. As in "HEY, YOU!"

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji, so you should be good here. Just imagine yourself calling out to someone: "YO (よ)! You!"

meaning.explanation: 確認 is confirmation. When that's a verb, you have to confirm or to verify.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help immensely if you know the word 確認 already as well.

meaning.explanation: To preserve and defend something is to conserve and to protect. I won't let you destroy this land I'm trying to protect!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: 批判 is criticism so the verb version of that would be to criticize.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will be much easier to read this if you know 批判, as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cut off so the verb vocab version is to cut off. This is often used metaphorically to describe cutting off things that tie us down mentally or societally. This includes ending bad habits, so it also means to quit doing something. Don't confuse this with 断る which means "to refuse." You know this is to cut off because of the つ, which hints that you have had two (つ) too many chocolates, and it's time to cut you off.

reading.explanation: URGH! The reading isn't even the same as 断る, how frustrating. to cut off is read as たつ. Instead of eating too many chocolates and getting cut off, maybe you're eating too many tater tots (たつ). Don't eat so many of those, it's unhealthy. You have to cut off tater tots from your diet so you don't get fat.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means divide so the verb vocab version is to divide or to split something. It can also mean to break something, as in ワイングラスを割る (to break a wine glass). After all, you’re technically dividing the object into parts if you break it, right?

reading.explanation: The reading you learned with the kanji is the one you'll use here. It's the わ one, though, making it わる.

meaning.explanation: Election is 選挙 so when you make that word into a verb, you have to elect.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Also, the reading just comes from 選挙 so if you know that you know this as well.

meaning.explanation: You escape and run the hell out of there. Basically, you're trying to escape, to flee, or to break out. Pretty simple. 脱走する specifically refers to escaping from a controlled or confined environment, like escaping from prison, a military base, or a guarded facility.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The だつ changes to だっ, though, so be careful of that.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means excel so the verb vocab version is to excel.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "He-e (ひい) is going to excel," you stutter. "He-e is!"

meaning.explanation: Remember 済む and how it means "to come to an end." This is like that, but slightly different. This is to finish something or to settle something, because this is when you're doing the coming to an end action. You can remember this because you're coming in to finish the score uno mas (ます) time. This is the last time.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with 済む, so if you know that you'll be able to finish this vocab.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. If you obtain something, you'll want it to fit inside your bag. Otherwise how can you take it home? When talking about problems or emotions, this verb can also mean to settle down and to be finishedlike a dispute settling down or someone’s anger calming down. Like most verbs with まる as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something fit inside, or settle down.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't fit inside your bed anymore. I guess you've grown? Better get out the trusty old saws (おさ) and chop off your footboard.

meaning.explanation: This one is a little strange. You have 混む (To Be Crowded), 混ぜる (to mix), 混ざる (to get mixed), and now this: 混じる, To Get Mixed Up In. It makes sense because it has to do with mixing, but how to differentiate from the rest? Well, for this one just imagine Jesus (じ) getting mixed up in a pot of soup. He's getting mixed up in this giant pot of soup because someone thinks that if they eat him, they'll gain his powers.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as (almost) all the other 混 verbs. All about mamamamama!

meaning.explanation: The kanji is descend, but this verb vocab word is to get off, as in, to get off the train, or to get out of the car. If you think about trains back in the day, you had to descend down to the platform to get out of them, which is how this word became what it is. You know that this word is the "to get off" word because once you get off the train, you enter the real (りる) world, where hardships are real and not as comfy as the train. Figuratively, this word also means to step down, as in "to give up" or "to resign” from something. For example, you can say ニュース番組を降りる (to step down from a news program) or ゲームを降りる (to drop out of a game).

reading.explanation: The reading is unlike anything you've seen with this kanji. Just think about how you have to get off at O-station. None of the other letters are your stop. Just O-Station (お).

meaning.explanation: Remember how 増える is "to increase" (as in, something just increases, you aren't doing the increasing yourself). This one is that one, where you're doing the increasing. So, this word means to increase something. You know you're doing the increasing because you said "yes" (やす) to increasing something, and did it yourself.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same like 増える. If you know that vocab word you probably can read this one as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means judge so the verb version is to judge.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you go to judge people, there are different types. The one you truly hate the most, however, is the sobber (さば). "The Sobber" is the worst kind. They just sob and sob and sob and it's really hard to move on to your next judging.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 心得 means "knowledge"? Well the verb version of that is to know. (You know it deep in your heart.)

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lead so the verb vocab version is to lead.

reading.explanation: The reading for this one is a bit difficult, but there's a hint in the kanji. See the 道 in there on the top? What's the reading for the vocab version of that kanji? It's みち. That's the first part. Now, who are you leading? Let's say you're leading a bee back to its nest, via the road. It's a 道 Bee (みちび)!

meaning.explanation: If 演 is performance then the verb version of this would be to perform.

reading.explanation: The reading looks weird, but it's actually just the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means provide so the verb vocab version is to provide.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to provide your friends with their own sauna (そな) because they don't want to use your shower. This requires you to go out and buy a sauna for your house (very expensive) just so you can provide your needy friends with what they want (a sauna). Feel angry you have to provide this.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means raise, and this verb is when you do that to something. It's transitive. So this means to raise something. It actually has a pretty wide meaning, and can also mean "raise" in the sense of to cite something, like an example. It can even mean to hold something, like an event.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 挙がる, so if you know that reading you should know this one as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means solve so the verb vocab version is to solve. You know this verb is for when you are doing the solving because you think it's super coo' (く) to solve things.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 解ける, so if you know that you can read this one too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch, and the verb version means to stretch over something, to spread out, or to be taut, not to be confused with the type of stretching you do after a workout. This word is both transitive and intransitive. When it follows を, it emphasizes the physical act of extending something over an area, like stretching a canvas over a frame, unfurling a sail on a ship, or roping off a crime scene. When following が, it expresses the resulting state of having been stretched or spread, like a bloated stomach, a swollen muscle, or a spider web.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Imagine yourself trying to stretch your favorite toy figurine, seeing just how far you can stretch it. With every stretch, you start laughing uncontrollably, HA (は) HA HA HA HA HA. Seems a bit cruel. Are you okay?

meaning.explanation: 理解 is understanding, so the verb version would be...? How about to understand or to comprehend? Well, do you?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Of course, if you know 理解 already this one is easy to comprehend.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  When you cut the tree down to produce a tree trunk, out jumps Mickey Mouse. "WHY YOU CUT DOWN MY TREE BRO?" he yells. I'm Mickey Mouse and I don't stand for this.

meaning.explanation: You're going to get judged times two. Judge and judge again. Once by the judge and another time by the jury. This is a whole trial here.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You hopefully learned this on'yomi for 判 with the word 評判, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: After your ban (ばん) on the WaniKani forums, you now face trial before none other than Judge Koichi. He's going to decide whether your ban will be lifted or not. Good luck, there's a lot at stake.

meaning.explanation: What seasons should you keep an eye on? The seasons that are turning points in your life. Keep an eye on those seasons, because you don't want to miss the critical junctures and milestones.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi of both kanji. You haven't learned that yet for 節, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: The real turning point in your life was when you got yourself a few sheep (ふし). Owning a few sheep was a true milestone for you. Now you have all the wool sweaters and cheese you could ever want!

meaning.explanation: When you've finished solving something, you've come to a point of understanding.  了解 is less about deep comprehension and more about understanding something on a practical level. It's used to acknowledge receipt of information or instructions, similar to "Got it" or "Understood."

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When the status of your employment is "nothing" then you're probably unemployed. You're experiencing unemployment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A demon that sucks blood? What mythological creature can you think of that sucks blood? How about a vampire? Them Sparklzzzz!

reading.explanation: 吸血 should be easy for you to read. The 鬼 part uses the reading you already learned with the kanji, き. Easy, no?

meaning.explanation: The superior person wins. They will win the championship and be able to claim victory over all others.

meaning.explanation: An element of clear up (like the sky clearing up!) is so wonderful and splendid. Sort of a weird word, but very useful. Just think of that wonderful feeling you get when the sun breaks and things clear up and it's awesome.

reading.explanation: The reading is a bit weird, too. Luckily, you've learned both of them already. 晴れる is はれる. That's the reading you use here, though は goes to ば.

meaning.explanation: Above mentions are above mentioned. Look above to see where I mentioned it, okay? Note that 上述 is a word commonly used in formal writing such as reports, academic papers, or business documents.

meaning.explanation: The angle of the touch is important with an antenna. Think about antennae. An ant's antennae wiggle around and move in different angles, touching things, to understand the world around them. Imagine their tiny bug antennae touching your arm to figure out who you are. Note that 触角 refers to the antennae of insects, crustaceans, and certain other arthropods, rather than to TV or radio antennas.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. しょく goes to しょっ.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 誕生 is birth? If you add day on there, you have a birthday. Happy birthday!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji, but with this word 日 uses the kun'yomi ひ, which is turned into び due to rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Transport of blood. Only time you do this is during a blood transfusion.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: You walk up to the boundary. You're there to pick something up to take it across. This thing you're smuggling across the boundary is a sockeye (さかい) salmon. You take it across the boundary and sell it for a big profit.

meaning.explanation: This is a build thing, or perhaps a building thing. In other words, a building or structure.  建物 is a very general word that can refer to any kind of building, including residential buildings, commercial buildings, or public facilities.

reading.explanation: The reading might look a little strange, but makes sense once you get it. You already know that the verb 建てる means "to build", and that a もの is a "thing". Now just remove the る part from the verb to make it a noun, combine it with もの, and we get たてもの! Just remember that it’s all kun’yomi since it comes from the verb 建てる.

meaning.explanation: You lose. Because of that, you have to carry this burden and responsibility.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Possible to burn ゴミ (garbage). This is burnable garbage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your special quality is your characteristics or your traits. This is a formal word that refers to special properties that only a certain thing possesses, like the properties of steel as a material, or a certain person’s nature.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A child servant is a child. Children are basically like little servants anyways, what else are they good for?

reading.explanation: The readings for this one are the kun'yomi readings of each kanji. 子 is こ, like the individual vocab word. 供 is ども, however. Remember this by thinking how much children love domo-kun (ども). Also, 子ども is kind of more "politically correct" with the kana hanging off there. 子供 is still used in a lot of situations, usually stiff ones. The second kanji means servant, and some people don't like that. The second version pops up a decent amount, so it's good to be familiar with that as well.

meaning.explanation: If intimacy expands to something, that thing is confidential. Try visualizing intimacy as a sort of gooey liquid, expanding and covering a letter, and making that letter confidential. 親展 is generally written on the front of envelopes to indicate that only the intended recipient should read its contents.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Your versus plan is to attack back. They've already attacked you once, so now it's time for your counter plan.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you'd think it's probably an adjective. However in this case, it's a noun. What's the noun form of different? It's difference.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Not different at all.

meaning.explanation: You make a distinction between people and based off that you separate the people. This is terrible! Why so much discrimination?

meaning.explanation: A determined amount is an amount that is fixed, aka a fixed amount, a fixed sum, or flat rate.

meaning.explanation: You previously learned this kanji with three different meanings. In vocabulary form, it just has one of these meanings, framed picture! Similarly, it can just mean picture or frame too.

meaning.explanation: A material you can burn is called fuel!

meaning.explanation: When you're renewing what you're saying, you're adding onto it, which makes this furthermore or further.  This is one of those good paragraph or sentence-starting essay words, which is how you'll often see it used!

reading.explanation: The kanji stands by itself with a particle, meaning that this uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you: You know a person that starts every other sentence by saying "Furthermore," and that's... Sarah (さら). Really feel yourself getting annoyed with this Sarah for starting every other sentence with "Furthermore, ...!" Just note that 更に is often written in kana, as さらに, especially in casual writing!

Like when a stock is hitting highs, or goods are sold for higher than the average market price, or something can fetch a high price at auction.

meaning.explanation: The time distinction is how you tell apart time zones. It is the time difference.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You know that 援助 is assistance or aid. So the verb vocab version is to assist or to aid.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 援助. It is also just the readings you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deliver so the verb vocab version here is to be delivered or to arrive. You know this one is "to be delivered" (aka it's just getting delivered, you aren't doing the delivery) because when this item arrives at your house you say "coo'" (く), it arrived.

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji: とど!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means different so the verb vocab version is to be different... and of course, to be different is also to be wrong in Japan. Don't be different!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. It's not different at all.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. It's also an intransitive verb, meaning the action happens on its own, you don't do it. The kanji itself means place on, and this means to be placed on. 載る is also often used to refer to something being included in a written document or publication and so can also mean to be recorded, as in 新聞に載る (to be recorded in a newspaper) or 教科書に載る (to be recorded in a textbook).

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  A reporter asks for your conversation to be placed on record, to which you respond "NO (の)!"
