meaning.explanation: Rescue in a hurry using this car. What kinds of cars can do this? How about an ambulance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: When someone determines something, it's probably okay. But, when the model determiner determines something, that is the best determination ever. That is the appraisal of someone with an expert opinion.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Scatter around the ground and walk. When you walk in a scatter all around, you're going for a walk or a stroll.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほ goes to ぽ, though.

meaning.explanation: Something that's flat and equal to everything around it, all those flat things around it, are average. They're the mean (same as average).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: ハチ is a bee. Buzz buzz. Just imagine "eight bees" combining into one bee, making it a "hachi." Then, there's a nest. What is a nest for bees? A beehive.

reading.explanation: 巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

meaning.explanation: Who do you know that will use a pole to stop someone from breaking your heart? Your bodyguard! He's there to make sure no one hurts you, and for some reason he really likes using a pole to do it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A grave ground is an area with lots of graves in the ground. This is a cemetery, or graveyard. 墓地 is the standard word for a designated and organized cemetery.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 中国 is China, right? That's what this 中 represents. And, of course the Chinese are known for being super showy, which is why you have showy there.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Sweep and exclude all that dirt from the floor, please. When you do this a lot, it becomes cleaning.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For this one though, you have to remember to read the 除 part as じ. Just keep in mind that cleaning (cleanliness) is next to godliness and so is Jesus (じ). So, Jesus is like cleaning. Easy.

meaning.explanation: A big land is the biggest types of land on this earth that there are. That is a continent.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A corridor is below. What do you call a corridor that's below? Well, really it's still just a corridor or hallway.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The thing that will pass through freight is currency. Why? Because when you want freight to be your own, you have to put money through it and to the person who owns it. When you do that, it becomes yours. Use that currency!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: It was previously decided, which means it's been decided and settled.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A child who is the grandchild of someone else is a descendant of that person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Fix the diameter. It is the wrong diameter and must be a new diameter. Test it now, what's the diameter?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Untie and scatter everything. This will cause the dissolution the breakup, and indeed the breaking up of whatever is being untied then scattered.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Detach from your marriage. This is a divorce.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Knit and gather everything back together, which you knit. When you do this to fix things and bring it back together, this is an edit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A knit someone is one who knits words together and makes them better. This someone is an editor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is equal and that is equal. They're both the same, amazing! They carry equality, uniformity, and evenness.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Exclude this one and put it outside what we're considering. This is the exception.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A feeling where you sigh is one in which you're surprised by something, and can't believe it, so you sigh. Ugh, *sigh*. What token represents this in writing? An exclamation mark!!!!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Something that previously existed is probably still existing now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji fear, so it means fear too.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: Dissolve your resources, because you need to pay back your financing and loans now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The way of the flower is flower arrangement.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A thing that could break easily, is a fragile thing. Be careful with things like this.

reading.explanation: The reading is 壊れる and 物 put together.

meaning.explanation: Freight things is freight or cargo.

reading.explanation: The reading is the 物 reading that's もつ. You can know this because you have to carry the freight and cargo (持つ it!).

meaning.explanation: Dissolve and then join together again to create a reaction, a fusion reaction.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If something has showy beauty then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as gaudy. Too much is too much.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: How many? What? In this area of study, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is geometry, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?).

reading.explanation: The 学 is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The 幾 and 何 is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with か. So, it's like, "何か????" and that's why it becomes か. Then, for 幾 think about how the key (き) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the keyか?"

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You are the grandchild of your grandfather. His favorite thing is to call you a maggot (まご). Your grandfather was in the military and is very hard on you, maggot.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: When you finally have a grave and you're dead and buried, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the Haka (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.

meaning.explanation: The flower powder symptoms are when you start sneezing from flower powder, aka pollen that comes from all sorts of flowers, which is pretty much all plants. This word, however, refers to the most common version of this sickness, which is hay fever.

reading.explanation: The reading is all on'yomi readings, which you learned for all but 花. Instead, 花 is か, and to remember that you can think about how the only way to escape the hay fever is to jump in your car and turn on the filter. Sweet, sweet relief.

meaning.explanation: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how many meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "つ." This can also be used to ask how old someone is, but generally only for children's ages. This word is usually written in kana in modern writing.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.

meaning.explanation: How many occurences is just another way of asking how many times. This word is more literary and formal than 何回 or 何度.

reading.explanation: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

meaning.explanation: This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the how much meaning. To remember this, just think about how Ra, the Egyptian God, is always asking "How much will it cost to build this pyramid?" Ugh, too much, let's hire some slaves.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: When you inquire about a problem, you tend to do interrogation-style questioning to get to the bottom of it. Why is it like this? What happened? Is it bigger than a breadbox?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The land army is the land army, also known as the plain old army.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you stand up out of the nest, you're getting ready to leave it. Your mother may be sad about this, but this means it's time to leave the nest and become independent.

reading.explanation: The readings are from the words 巣 and 立つ put together.

meaning.explanation: Oh wow, that is exceptionally showy! Whatever that thing is, it is luxurious and splendid and I want one.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means male and this also means male. It's used for animals, plants, and the like. Note that this is often written in katakana, as in オス.

reading.explanation: Male animals can be kind of pushy, always trying to push (押す) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.

meaning.explanation: A male dog is a male dog. It's worth mentioning that you'll see this most often written in katakana, as both オス犬 and オスの犬.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi readings, which is probably A-Okay for 犬, but for 雄 you'll want to think about how a male dog is probably pretty pushy, always trying to push (押す) other dogs around, being male and moody and all that.

meaning.explanation: An outside tasks minister (大臣) is someone who is tasked with dealing with things that are outside the country. This is the minister of foreign affairs.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The way of virtue is the way you take if you have morals. Hopefully you have some.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mountain vein is a vein that extends across the land, and is covered in mountains. This refers to a mountain range.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Did you know that the mountain that is rich in samurai happens to be Japan's most famous mountain? It makes sense considering samurai are probably Japan's most famous thing as well. Combine the two most famous things and you have Mt Fuji (or Mount Fuji if you'd rather write it that way).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher: You may know of Dora the Explorer. But have you heard about her dirty, muddy brother, Doro (どろ)? They're like a team. And because of all the exploring he does, Doro is always covered in mud.

meaning.explanation: Mud water is muddy water. Don't step in it, if you can help it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. There's another way to read this word that uses both on'yomi readings (でいすい). It's mostly used in more formal or technical situations though, so we're focusing on the どろみず reading here!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can refer to all kinds of things, like a spider's web or a mouse's burrow or a bee's hive, etc. Basically, it's a place where animals live, not necessarily just a nest as in a bird's "nest," etc.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: You pass through like completely normal. You are normal. You do things normally, normally.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are the same, except that this isn't just any type of belt. It's an obi, a wide cloth belt worn with traditional clothes like kimono and yukata.

reading.explanation: The reading is obi (おび), so if you know the meaning, you know the reading as well! If you need an extra reminder, ask yourself "What is the first letter in belt?" Hmm, I can't remember. OH! "B" (おび)! I remember now.

meaning.explanation: Something that obstructs and also does damage is an obstruction. No obstruction is ever good and if left too long it really will cause damage and interference as well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You learned that 我が means "our", so our country is simply our country. Just like 我が itself, this expression is somewhat old-fashioned and stylized. It comes up a lot in political discourse and other formal contexts.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading for 我 when you learned 我が. Just watch out for 国, which you might expect to rendaku here, but doesn't!

meaning.explanation: An image corridor is a corridor in which there are images hanging on the wall. This is a picture gallery. Note that 画廊 generally refers to a physical art gallery, where artworks are exhibited for in-person viewing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also mean flour.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Just imagine there’s powder all over Conan’s (こな) hands and face. Detective Conan, that is. Conan has been investigating some kind of bakery murder. He had to dig through sacks of flour to find the hidden murder weapon (rolling pin, naturally) and now Conan is just covered in the white, starchy powder.

meaning.explanation: Something that is in a powder condition is something that has been powdered. Puff!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You look for things and you spy on people. Your job isn't as glamorous as it sounds. You're a private detective.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A fear rock (らく) will probably come straight at your face. It's pretty likely.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: Half a diameter is a radius.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Inside spying is when you get inside enemy territory and spy on them. This is scouting and reconnaissance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A seal model is the best kind of seal, but it's still just a seal.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you divide and detach things from each other, you're creating separation between them. Makes sense, right? 分離 is a word you might hear in science when discussing how different substances, like oil and water, don't mix and separate from each other. Additionally, 分離 can also be a formal term used to describe separating groups of people, often in discussions about serious topics like social segregation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that is showy is showy.

reading.explanation: For the reading, think about something that's showy... in particular, 花s (はな). Flowers are super showy, always showing off their colors and stuff.

meaning.explanation: A sigh breath is a sigh.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: クモ is a spider. Add a nest to it, and you have a spider nest. What do spiders call their nests? They call it a spiderweb (that is, if they can talk).

reading.explanation: 巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means storehouse, and the vocab is also storehouse! Wondering what the difference between 倉 and 庫 is? Long ago, 倉 were places to store grain, while 庫 used to be associated with places to store vehicles, as the kanji composition suggests. These days, they're both used for general storage, but also refer to places to store goods and merchandise. Between the two, 倉 is much more commonly used.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 庫. They're basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).

meaning.explanation: 詰まる is "to be stuffed." So, if your nose is stuffed, then you have a stuffy nose.

reading.explanation: The reading is 鼻 and 詰まる put together. the 詰まり is rendaku'd, probably because you're trying to say this word with a stuffy nose.

meaning.explanation: Things are equal in how they're arranged. They have perfect symmetry and balance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 壊す is "to break something." 壊れる is when something just gets broken or is broken, and you're not doing the breaking. This is to be broken.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 壊す, so try not to break any of your memories and remember this.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means to be extended, to be delayed, or to be prolonged. If you know the word ビル, you can think about how building work is always prolonged or delayed, to help you remember that this is intransitive. We never know why it's delayed, it just happens all by itself!

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 延ばす.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rich so the verb vocab version would be to be rich in. 富む is a formal word that's commonly used in writing. While it can refer to material wealth, it's more commonly used figuratively to describe an abundance of qualities, a place rich in nature or specific resources, or emotional richness or fulfillment.

reading.explanation: Think about the richest person you know. That person is Tom (とむ). Imagine Tom as being super rich. If you don't know a Tom, think of a famous Tom, like Tom Cruise, who definitely is pretty rich.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scatter so the verb vocab version is to be scattered. You know that this verb represents when something is scattering (you're not doing the scattering), because you would never be so rude as to scatter someone or something yourself. It only happens when it happens on its own.

reading.explanation: Think about something scattering. That something is cheese (ち), scattering all over the floor, going everywhere, getting in everything. Ugh, you hate how cheese scatters, don't you?

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means surprised, so the verb vocab version is to be surprised.

reading.explanation: What are you so surprised by? Your friend's odor (おどろ). Think of a friend that you wouldn't expect to be so smelly. Then, be surprised by the odor. Eww, bro, you have to take a shower.

meaning.explanation: 詰める is "to stuff in." If you're really stuffing in your thoughts (think), you're thinking very deeply and seriously. So this is to brood, to dwell on, or to take something to heart. 思い詰める suggests you're pondering deeply over something serious or distressing, bordering on overthinking.

reading.explanation: The reading is 思い and 詰める put together into one reading.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means exclude so the verb vocab version is to exclude.

reading.explanation: You would like to exclude your nose (のぞ) because you don't like your nose. Imagine your strong feelings about your nose as you decide to exclude it.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fear so the verb version is to fear.

reading.explanation: The reading is shared with 恐ろしい, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means illuminate, so this means to illuminate or to shine light on something. But don't get it confused with 照れる, which is "to feel embarrassed" — that would be embarrassing. You know this is "to illuminate" because you get a rash (らす) every time something shines on you too much.

reading.explanation: Speaking of things that illuminate, your hands (手) illuminate all the time for some reason.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inquire so the verb vocab version is to inquire.

reading.explanation: I'd like to inquire about a few things. Wait, what? You won't cooperate? How about I just taze (たず) you with this tazer then? BzzzbbzbhhhAHHHHHH!

meaning.explanation: 絶える is "to die out." 絶やす is "to kill off." You know this because if something is to die off, you'd say "no." But if you're the one doing the killing off, you'd say yes (やす).

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 絶える.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means knit so the verb vocab version is to knit.

reading.explanation: When you start to knit, you always end up with the same thing every time when you're done, no matter what you're trying to make: The letter "A" (あ). It's so frustrating that you can't knit anything else.

meaning.explanation: This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the Tokugawa family name, also known as the Tokugawa Shogun. They ran Japan for a while, you know?

reading.explanation: The readings are 徳 and the vocab 川 put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one.

meaning.explanation: The virtue island prefecture is Tokushima prefecture. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture."

reading.explanation: The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is Tokushima Prefecture.

meaning.explanation: When you sigh, you feel a certain type of emotion. A type that makes you feel sad and causes you to lament and to grieve.

reading.explanation: For the reading, just think about this feeling you're having (this lamenting grieving one). Then, decide you're done with it. 投げる (throw) it out the window. You don't want these feels anymore!

meaning.explanation: The word 迷う means "to go astray" but this word is to lead astray. You are doing the astraying to someone or something else. You know this because the other person was (わす) just fine until you came along to lead them astray.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 迷う, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look for and the verb version of the kanji is to look for. Curious about the difference between 捜す and 探す? While there is some overlap between the two, 捜す is typically used in official, thorough searches for something or someone that is thought to concretely exist and has disappeared or cannot be easily found. In contrast, 探す can also be used for personal searches for things that one desires or is looking for.

reading.explanation: You are looking for a sagger (さが) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go to search for them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.

meaning.explanation: 積もる is "to accumulate." Now you're doing the accumulating, and in order to do that you must go to pile things up. More and more and more. How do you know that this verb is when you're doing the accumulating? It's because you are piling up cows (む). Wow, a cow piler.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 積もる, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rescue so the verb vocab version is to rescue.

reading.explanation: The すく in the reading is a lot like the scue (すくう) part of to rescue, don't you think? Hopefully you do, so you can make the connection.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means resemble so the verb vocab version is to resemble or to look like.

reading.explanation: You should have learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic to help you, just in case: What are you trying to resemble?? Is that... oh no. A knee (に) face resemble surgery, where you make your face look like your knee and vice versa? Do you know how dangerous that surgery is?

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means detach, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it to separate and to leave. This refers to when something separates on its own. You aren't doing the separating. You know this because it's rare (れる) to see things separate, but sometimes you do see them. Also, whenever you see れる usually it's a safe bet that you're not the one doing the action, right? Think about it.

reading.explanation: For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the 花s (はな) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.

meaning.explanation: If 主催 is sponsorship, the verb version of that would be to sponsor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 主催 already as well.

meaning.explanation: When you really stuff in (詰める) what you are seeing, you're really looking at something, causing you to stare at whatever it is you're stuffing your seeing into.

reading.explanation: The reading is 見 and 詰める.

meaning.explanation: 緊張 is stress. So, the verb version is to stress out.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sweep so the verb version is to sweep.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you sweep you laugh. "HA (は) HA HA!" Just imagine yourself doing this, or do it for real if you want to clean up a bit.

meaning.explanation: If 催促 is urge, then the verb version would be to urge.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 催促 first.

meaning.explanation: An underground (地下) street isn't as underground streety as it sounds. A lot of the underground streets and areas in Japan tend to be underground shopping malls, though. That or subways/trains, but underground shopping centers are way more interesting.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The normal steps are the ones that are totally usual. They're the ones you usually do, unlike those weird not usual steps.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A field vegetable is still a vegetable, whether it comes from the field or not.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you eat vegetable food you are on a vegetarian diet.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A storage warehouse is some kind of warehouse, or some kind of storehouse. Curious about the difference between 倉庫 and 庫? While 庫 refers to traditional Japanese storehouses, 倉庫 is used for modern warehouses and storehouses, both the commercial kind and the ones for personal use.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. Someone who is rich has wealth and riches, right?

reading.explanation: For the reading, think about the person you know with the most wealth. It is Tommy (とみ) Hilfiger.

meaning.explanation: If you're rich and abundant, you are super wealthy, affluent, and rich.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This earth belt is the area within the belt, which holds this area of earth in. It is separate from the rest of the earth, making it its own zone or district.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your achievements and exploits are your achievements.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It has become that we agree. We have agreement!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: When you have the ambition to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say 心ざし (こころざし), which is how this word was written in classical Japanese. In modern Japanese it's always 志, but the reading is exactly the same. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!

meaning.explanation: Your previous ancestors are your ancestors. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes そ to ぞ！

meaning.explanation: I have a food want. When I want food (or when I don't want food), it has to do with your appetite.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A kindness person is a very kind person. This person is a benefactor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your blood fluid is your blood.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The ゆで comes from the verb ゆでる, which means "to boil." So this word means boiled egg.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A fire wound is a burn or scald you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch!

reading.explanation: The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a burn (on your arm) being caused by a yakky dodo (やけど) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.

meaning.explanation: If your back is wide, you need a nice business suit to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now!

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.

meaning.explanation: Your meat wants are your deepest desires, your carnal desires.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A cherry tree can create a cherry. This is what this word is.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the kanji.

meaning.explanation: If 騒ぐ is "to make noise," then a big version of this is even louder. It's a clamor and an uproar.

reading.explanation: This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!

meaning.explanation: You push things to make them enter the closet or cupboard.

reading.explanation: The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also mean money more generally.

reading.explanation: The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is ぜに. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."

meaning.explanation: The idea of everyone together sharing property between them comes from which party? That's the Communist Party.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: There are duplicates of everything, not to mention the duplicates are random. Nothing makes sense, and everything is super complicated.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: For this word, the 便 comes from 便所, which you know as "toilet." A toilet secret is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is constipation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."

meaning.explanation: A sickness that can transmit and then dye into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a contagious disease. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you make a duplicate copy you are copying things. Especially if you're making a photocopy or a carbon copy. It's like a copy of a copy!  複写 is a pretty formal word for copying documents, text, or images. It's still often used to talk about carbon copies. But for photocopies, most people just say コピー(する) these days.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji decorate, so it means decoration.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: Your intention for your hope is what you want. It's not just a hope. You have intention behind it. This is your desire. This is your ambition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Dirty water is dirty water. Gross. Could also be sewage. Even grosser.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: English translate is an English translation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is just a little more technical than 目.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!

meaning.explanation: An eyeball sphere is an eyeball. Eww.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An elderly eyeball is one that can't see things close up. That's why this word means farsightedness. But this is the kind of farsightedness that only comes with age. So you have to be an elderly oldey to have 老眼.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Eternity is a long time... as in forever. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like an "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An eternity that is far away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's forever, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's 永久, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You become exploits... as in, your exploits become a thing you can actually see, and you can see them in the form of grades. Ouch, some of your exploits weren't all that amazing...

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your ancestor father isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your grandfather.

reading.explanation: The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a fool (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.

meaning.explanation: Your ancestor mother isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your grandmother.

reading.explanation: The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your grandmother had a boat (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.

meaning.explanation: A wound of your heart. That could be many things, but in this case it's heartbreak.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Strangely, cherry tree meat isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's horse meat. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji.

reading.explanation: The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.

meaning.explanation: In defense of life, you have to remain clean. If you are dirty, you will die earlier (think: plagues). So, to defend said life, you must have good hygiene.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The feeling of dye, covering your body, is the feeling of nasty germs and diseases penetrating your skin, getting inside of you. This is an infection, and it's gross.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who has a wound is someone who is wounded. They are an injured person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I have an interest in the flavor... You do? Yes, I have a very deep interest in it.

reading.explanation: As a jukugo kanji, you can guess the reading is the on'yomi kanji readings, which it is, so you should be able to read it.

meaning.explanation: If you let words pass through you, and as they do you translate them, you are doing interpreting.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 和 represents Japan? Now, take that and add translate to it. With that, you have Japanese translation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The individual peoples party is the political group that believes in each individual of the people (or something?). The translation doesn't really get hinted at in this meaning, but this group is the Liberal Democratic Party, aka the LDP.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Things that have a fluid body are made of liquid.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of long time? Well, it's long ago, or can mean for a long time.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Long ago, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "Heesa (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!

meaning.explanation: If 結婚 is marriage, then a marriage ceremony is a marriage ceremony or wedding.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Random expenses are miscellaneous expenses. Not actually random, but they feel that way.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.

meaning.explanation: The duplicate numbers are when you duplicate the numbers into more numbers, representing multiple.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Random noise is still noise, though more specifically it is random noise, like static.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 撮影 is photography. 禁止 is prohibition. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a no photos or no photos allowed rule in place.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.

meaning.explanation: The middle of your back is one's back (or your back).

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.

meaning.explanation: The acid element is oxygen. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “Säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck. Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A party member is party member of a political party.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your person veins are all the veins you have going out to all the different people you know. These are your personal connections, your network.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A cherry blossom color is what color? Kind of a pink, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be ピンク, if you want it to be.

reading.explanation: The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji play, so it means play or playing!

reading.explanation: You learned this reading when you learned 遊ぶ. It's the same one!

meaning.explanation: A politics party is a political party.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A dirty dye that's all throughout the sky and makes things gross when it touches them is pollution. If it's bad enough it really is like a dye, too, making your white clothes brown, yuck.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 貧乏 is poor, so a poor person is a poor person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

meaning.explanation: Preface writing is the preface.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Gather the money and then calculate how much of it you have. Oh, nice, looks like you have a profit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Give a coin and get hot water. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a public bath.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the public bath, you're in Tokyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.

meaning.explanation: If 出版 means publishing, then a company that does said publishing is a publishing company.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.

meaning.explanation: If 押し is push, and a ボタン is a button, then you have yourself a push button.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 押す.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 生 can mean raw? Well, it does now. So, a raw egg? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means raw egg.

reading.explanation: The reading is the vocab 生 and 卵 combined into one なまたまご.

meaning.explanation: This word takes the reason meaning of the kanji, making it reason. What's the reason for it having two meanings? I have no clue, but there must be a reason. While 理由 is the general term for reasons, 訳 tends to be more focused on the underlying reason or cause of something. It's also used when explaining a situation or when there's an implied need to justify or clarify something.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's your reason to wake (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?

meaning.explanation: A kindness prize is one that someone gives you out of kindness. Perhaps you've done something nice, which is why they are giving you a reward. Note: this is an older word, so you'll probably only see it in history books, but it's important to know anyway!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A defense star isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a satellite, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion canons and video and things like that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know them both already, so you should be able to read this word!

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? Scary or frightening. It can also mean I'm afraid or I'm scared too.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You know what's really scary? Koalas (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.

meaning.explanation: Something that has secrecy is secret and private.

reading.explanation: Think about that really secret and private dude. He so (ひそ) secret...

meaning.explanation: Secret and secrecy. Combine the two and you have quite the secret.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: In secrecy you must announce this information. It's not for anyone to hear, it's secret information.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.

meaning.explanation: A secrecy meet is a secret meeting. You know the password?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that みつ changes to みっ.

meaning.explanation: Self defense is when you protect yourself. It's self defense.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The order of things is the preface to the entire sequence and steps we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you decorate your spirit with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just showing off. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations.

reading.explanation: Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary. The second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: At the height of showing off, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a kettle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.

meaning.explanation: This the noun version of the kanji for smell. It also means smell, or scent! Although 匂う often implies something smells unpleasant, 匂い is more neutral and can refer to any kind of smell.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

meaning.explanation: A secrecy transport is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to smuggling.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The society (社会) party is the socialist party.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The taste of something with acid is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a sour taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word.

reading.explanation: Something was so sour that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to sue (す) the maker of this nasty sour thing.

meaning.explanation: A dirty point is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a stain or smudge.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone's back height is their height. It also refers to their stature.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of strict? It is also strict.

reading.explanation: The most strict creature in Japan is the key bee (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!

meaning.explanation: Something with strict prohibition is strictly forbidden / strictly prohibited.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the words 背 and 高い put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a tall person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.

reading.explanation: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!

meaning.explanation: You illuminate some food, then bake it. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is teriyaki, though I have to warn you it's quite different from the teriyaki you get in the west.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 照る and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.

meaning.explanation: If 冷やす is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling error (える). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.

meaning.explanation: 浮く means "to float," and 浮かれる draws on that metaphor of "floating" to mean to be happy, to be in high spirits, or to be elated. We have the same metaphor in English — think of being "on cloud nine."

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going to be happy and you won't have a care (かれる) in the world!

meaning.explanation: If you secret something, you are trying to keep secret something. That, or you're trying to conceal it.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing to conceal about this reading, you gots it.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dye so the verb vocab version is to dye.

reading.explanation: You need to dye something that you just sewed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.

meaning.explanation: If fire illuminates your face, you're going to feel hot. Sometimes you start to flush when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing: When are you going to feel hot? When is your face going to flush? When I ask you to go to a hotel (ほてる) with me!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gather so the verb vocab version is to gather.

reading.explanation: When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: とる.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dirty so the verb vocab version is to get dirty. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's rare (れる) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.

reading.explanation: Things seem to get dirty easily around here, which is why you go (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean. Note that the reading よごれる is generally used for getting physically dirty, whereas けがれる is more figurative, so more like “to be defiled”.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wet, so the verb version is to get wet.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond so the verb vocab version is also to go beyond. This is very similar in meaning to 越える. Both can refer to overcoming some physical object or passing beyond a certain amount of time. However, 越す tends to sound a little less intense, while 越える really focuses on the physical or emotional challenge of overcoming a certain milestone. For example, while 山を越す simply refers to crossing a mountain, 山を越える gives the impression that crossing the mountain is a difficulty you've overcome.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 越える. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic: To go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is domesticate. When you domesticate an animal, you get to keep a pet of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something.

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of cat!

meaning.explanation: You learned 漏れる means "to leak." 漏らす is the transitive version, which means it takes a direct object. So this means to let something leak or to leak something. The reason you let something leak is because you rushed (らす) the job (because you did it yourself)! Even though it's transitive, 漏らす often implies an unintentional leak, as in おしっこを漏らす (wet one's pants) or 水を漏らすな (don't let water spill). It's also used figuratively, like 秘密を漏らす (leak a secret), 不満を漏らす (express dissatisfaction), or ためいきを漏らす (let out a sigh).

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deposit, and this word is for when someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you to look after, to take care of, or to hold on to it. Remember that 預ける is used when you leave something with someone else to take care of temporarily. 預かる, on the other hand, is used when you're the one receiving something to look after. You can remember this because you're great at taking care of cargo (かる). You're always looking after everyone's cargo, but you're happy to hold on to it for them. Also note that even though 預かる ends with かる and kind of looks intransitive, it's actually an exception! It'll pretty much always have a direct object to specify what you're looking after.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case: You need someone to look after your kids for the day. Hey, I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at a zoo (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your cars (か) for the day!

meaning.explanation: 結婚 is marriage, so the verb version of that would be to marry or to get married.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means welcome, but the verb version is to pick someone up or to meet someone. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going to meet someone too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.

reading.explanation: To pick someone up you are going to drive your moo car. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.

meaning.explanation: If 延長 is prolonging, then the verb version is to prolong.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 出版 is publishing, then the verb vocab version is to publish.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.

meaning.explanation: If 購読 is a subscription, then the verb vocab version would be to subscribe.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It resembles you! It suits you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf to suit you, you know?

reading.explanation: The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw away so the verb version is to throw away.

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need to throw away that bit of knowledge just yet!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means translate so the verb version would be to translate.

reading.explanation: The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.

meaning.explanation: A translated bit of language is a translated term.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who translates things is a translator.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I gather things and use them. The things I've gathered, are the things I use.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When people gather and decide things, they decide together, usually by voting.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of want? It's also wanted.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A hoe (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.

meaning.explanation: What you want and request are your wants, your desires, perhaps your craving. You want these things so you request them. I wants them!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of warm? It's warm as well! Though this is for a warm weather or temperature, not some warm food or something like that, that would be 温かい, a different あたたかい. Confusing, right?

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 温かい, which also means warm. But while that 温かい refers to a warm thing, this 暖かい refers to a warm temperature or place. Just like with 温かい, people often pronounce this as あったかい in conversation. But when it comes to kanji exams or typing out the kanji, remember to use あたたかい!

meaning.explanation: Warm warm is warm.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A white flag is a white flag. It's one for surrender. I give up! Too many kanji!

reading.explanation: You'll have to be careful about this one, as it's actually read with the two kanji's kun'yomi readings put together, making this しろはた.

meaning.explanation: If you have an idea of what you want already, then that's good! You have will, desire, and ambition. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have an idea and you have intent to carry it out. This is your will and volition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: To remember this reading, just think about what your mommy did for you when you were little and you got yourself a wound... she would kiss (きず) the wounds better. Of course, that never worked and was a total farce, but try to forgive mommy this one time, okay?

meaning.explanation: When something differs from normal it's called abnormal or strange.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It differs from the normal condition of things, making it weird. It is an abnormality. There is something wrong.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A loyalty announcement is the kind of announcement you give to someone who you're loyal to. To this type of person, your announcement would come in the form of advice or maybe admonishment, if you're upset with what they've done.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A backside street (or "avenue") is a street that's not a main street... it's hidden and behind everything, making it an alley.

reading.explanation: The reading is 裏 and 通り put together into one word.

meaning.explanation: The year that is next is coming up. What will you do in the year that is next that you did this year too? What do you do that is annual? 年次 is a formal term typically used in business settings, such as in 年次報告書 (annual report) or 年次休暇 (annual leave).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The most important part of your military attire are your arms (not the ones attached to your body, your guns and stuff). Arms are what make you a real military person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: An ash plate is a plate you use for ashes. That's an ashtray.

reading.explanation: The reading is the two vocab words, 灰 and 皿, put together.

meaning.explanation: If something does not shake, it’s probably in a slump. If nothing’s shaking, things must be sluggish. 不振 is used for times when things are slower or worse than usual. For example, 業績不振 is when a business isn’t doing as well as it usually does, and 食欲不振 is when you don't feel like eating as much as you normally would.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This looks like it's an adjective, but it's just a tricky word. It's a noun, and it means the same thing as the kanji, making it attire.

reading.explanation: "Yo, so, oh, you gonna wear that attire today or what?"

meaning.explanation: Your clothes which attire you is your attire. It's how you dress.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who is an author is an author.
