reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The backside mouth (think: entrance) is the back door or rear entrance.

reading.explanation: The reading is 裏 and 口 put together into one word.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji as well.

meaning.explanation: From the backside you cut someone. Wow. What a jerk. What betrayal and treachery.

reading.explanation: This word is 裏 and 切る's readings, put together.

meaning.explanation: Take your body and manipulate it around for exercise. This is Calisthenics or gymnastics.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This takes the second meaning of the kanji you learned, chastity.

reading.explanation: Who is doing the chastity thing? That missa, oh (みさお), yes she is.

meaning.explanation: Ripened languages are words that have taken some time to come into their form. They ripened up, starting with just one kanji, but then became two, or three, or more. That is a compound word or compound kanji. You know that "jukugo" thing I talk about so much? That's this!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The groin interval is simply the groin or crotch.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The emperor's fat child is the crown prince, not because he's fat, but because he's the emperor's child.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: No! I will not determine that. In fact, I deny it. This is my denial.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who differs in gender from you is of a different gender. This is often used to mean the opposite sex in the sense of men as viewed by women and vice versa.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: My idea of righteousness is different from yours. Really, it's just a different meaning.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Change your attire to look like someone else. This is a disguise.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An edit is 編集. Someone who does those edits is an editor!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the readings from 編集 should help you.

meaning.explanation: The Japanese emperor is supposed to have come from the heavens, so that just makes this heaven emperor the emperor of Japan.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 皇 is read as のう here. You just found out you can never be the Emperor of Japan because you aren't Japanese. NOOOOOOOOOOOOO~ (のう).

meaning.explanation: Go ahead and extend it and stretch it. That's how we'll do this enlargement, expansion and extension.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Of course, just to be dirty, the people who made up this word decided to use a kanji that read as かく. Dirty old monks that could see the future and speak English, ugh.

meaning.explanation: This attire is put inside this equipment, where it's changed into something else. This attire device is strange and interesting. Imagine something that it does to your attire.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 除く is "to exclude." This is the te-form, and it means "except." So, something like "please get everything except broccoli," because who wants broccoli?

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 除く. It's just the te-form of it.

meaning.explanation: I have loyalty to you, so I always tell you the truth. I am very faithful and devoted to you!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: You already learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

meaning.explanation: To stay alive in some climates, some have no choice but to be a freeloader. That is, a lodger who pays nothing. If you live somewhere with an inhospitable climate but you can't afford to pay rent, your only option is to live with someone for free.

reading.explanation: This is a slightly unusual case because both kanji use the kun'yomi. You haven't learned that reading for 候 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What? You've become a freeloader? I can't believe you've gone so low (そうろう)!

meaning.explanation: A freight things ship is a boat that freights things. It's a freighter.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The 物 takes its もつ reading, which makes sense since it sounds like 持つ, which is "to hold." What is this freighter doing? It's holding freight! So, that's how you can remember that bit.

meaning.explanation: A fruit sugar is the type of sugar that's more commonly known as fructose. Mmm, delicious fructose.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is generally used in the names of gardens, like エデンの園 and 桜の園. It's also used in phrases like 学びの園, which means "school" and carries the connotation of being a haven for learning.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Which garden is the Garden of Eden? その garden! That garden right next to you is the Garden of Eden! It can also use the on'yomi, though, which you've already learned. When it takes the on'yomi and is used as a standalone word, it usually refers to some kind of institution, like a 幼稚園.

meaning.explanation: My various buddies! Wait, that didn't come out right. Gentlemen! My friends! There we go, much better.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 華やか is "showy." Now we're doubling it, making it doubly showy. If you make something showy enough, it becomes gorgeous, but it also becomes pretty flamboyant. So, so, so flamboyant.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 華やか. Note the second はな becomes ばな, to be はなばなしい.

meaning.explanation: A grave location is a place where there are graves. It is a graveyard. This word is more direct and informal than 墓地, so using 墓場 for an actual cemetery might come off as disrespectful. It's commonly used in phrases like ゆりかごから墓場まで (from the cradle to the grave) or 墓場まで持っていく (take a secret to the grave).

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji, which is fairly unusual, but then graveyards are unusual and special places. You've learned both of these readings before, so you should be able to read this on your own, but here's a reminder for 墓 just in case: When you're finally dead and buried in a graveyard, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the Haka (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.

meaning.explanation: Ash color tends to be a kind of gray color, wouldn't you say? That makes this word gray (or grey, depending on where you're from).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Did you know that your crotch is connected via various joints? That makes this word your hip joints or, more generally, just your hip.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Respect language is what you speak to someone you respect and want to elevate. You can do this using this type of Japanese, which is known as honorific language.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your house rent is your house rent, though it can be your apartment rent too.

reading.explanation: The reading for 家 is an exceptional one. It is や, because when your landlord asks if you paid your rent, you always say yah (や), whether you did or not.

meaning.explanation: You already know that 理屈 means "theory". So what's flatulence theory? It's an illogical argument, a far-fetched argument, or sometimes a lame excuse. It's all just hot air!

reading.explanation: You've already learned all these readings. You should be able to read this on your own. And no, that's not a far-fetched argument, or a lame excuse for not writing a mnemonic.

meaning.explanation: You're taking reality and trying to resemble it. To do this, you have to do an imitation, mimicry, or an impersonation.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 真 and an irregular reading for 似. You've already learned the reading for 真, but here's a mnemonic to help you with 似: What are you doing an imitation of? A horse! You gallop around neighing (ね) at the top of your lungs! That's a pretty good imitation.

meaning.explanation: The emperor's tribe is his family. This family is known as the imperial family.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The emperor's room is where the Imperial Family gathers. Note that 皇室 refers to the Imperial Household as a family unit, rather than a physical space.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The ground storehouse refers to a person's name. It may be easier to learn this one reading first because of that. Anyways, this person is Jizo(u), a Bodhisattva, and protector of children.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What do people usually scatter in a rush (らし)? Leaflets and flyers. Handing them out takes way too much time, so if you just scatter them all over the place your job will be done so much faster!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the 散る, so you should be able to read it already!  Note that this word is almost always written in kana, and チラシ is much more common than ちらし.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. OH HAI THERE LUNG. OH HAI THERE YOU.

meaning.explanation: 肺 is lung, がん is "cancer," I suppose because you want it gone (がん) from you. That makes this word lung cancer, which, with all the smoking in Japan, happens a decent amount.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A lung sickness is bad for those lungs of yours. It means you have lung disease.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Random magazine is pretty much all magazines. Just a bunch of random stuff inside, making it a magazine.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When a warm temper is applied extra thick, it leads to a person having a mild-mannered or gentle personality. Note that this is a more formal term, so you'll usually encounter it in writing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You already know the on'yomi for 温, but not for 厚, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: The most mild-mannered Tofugu staff has to be onion こういち. It's an onion that jumps in for こういち whenever he's not at the office. He's the most gentle soul you could imagine, never yelling at anyone. The ideal boss, really.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word share the meaning of swamp, but this word is primarily used to mean mountain stream. Think of it this way, the water for a swamp has to come from somewhere right? It starts out up in the mountains and drains out into a swamp in the valley. The life cycle of a mountain stream into a swamp!

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: The beginning of the word swamp is actually pretty similar to this word's reading. さわ = "swa"? I'd say it's close enough to make a mnemonic out of in your head.

meaning.explanation: Your muscle meat is your muscle.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something of heaven's nature is indeed natural, with no human intervention involved. Although this word is technically a noun, it's often used as an adjective. That's also what distinguishes it from 自然. So you'll often see 天然 used to say that something is "natural" or "of nature", while 自然 will often be used to talk about nature in general, like saying that nature is beautiful.

reading.explanation: You know the reading for 天, but 然 uses a different reading from what you learned. So here's a mnemonic to help you: One thing that definitely isn't natural are nendoroids (ねん). Remember, the little plastic figurines? Have you ever seen an anime figurine growing naturally in a field before? Yup, me neither. Not very natural.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that 否  ( いな ) is very formal and somewhat archaic. Today, it's most commonly used in the expression  〜か否か  (whether… or not).

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Instead of saying "no" you say "na," and instead of saying "na" you say いな.  Note that 否 can also be read いや, which is a common way to say “no” in modern Japanese, but that reading is almost always written in kana.

meaning.explanation: If you manipulate the things you make, you are in operation of said things. This can not only refer to the operation of devices and machinery, but also the manipulation of various elements, such as markets, stock prices, and more, with the intention of furthering one's own interests.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you enter your supply into the machine, that is your payment for the day. Every day you have to enter your supply, otherwise they crack down on you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You proclaim things by saying them. This is a proclamation or declaration.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: All the things the leader proclaims are transmitted to the people. It's all propaganda, which is why you transmit it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A muddy bog is a way of describing a quagmire. It’s a bog with almost no water left, having become all muddy and sticky. Gross (and dangerous)! This word is typically used figuratively to describe a situation where a conflict becomes messy and difficult to resolve, or a problem from which it is difficult to extricate oneself.

reading.explanation: The readings are the vocab readings of the two words, 泥 and 沼.

meaning.explanation: A cool storehouse storage is a place you put things (like food) to keep them cool. This is a refrigerator.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: "No" is the decision I've made. Sorry, but this is rejection.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means author, but if you think about it, what do authors do? They write about remarkable or marked things, whether it's fiction or nonfiction.

reading.explanation: Something is so remarkable you let out one jeer (いちじる) at the opposing team. Just one, because you're not that mean.

meaning.explanation: Rent it and I will lend it to you. This thing that is being lent and rented? It's a rental.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You just have to remember that 貸 is read as たい for this one. What is your rental? It is a tie (たい) fighter. Sweet.

meaning.explanation: You are revered and you have my respect. This is respect.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of revered? It's also revered!

reading.explanation: You are revered because of your Toe toe (とうと), which is a toe on your toe. It's weird, but people seem to like it.

meaning.explanation: To become ripe(n) is to ripen and mature.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I don't know why a mud pole is a robber, but for some reason it is. Just imagine a robber covering himself in mud and standing behind a pole to hide, then jump out, then rob you of everything you've got.

reading.explanation: The reading is 泥 plus the reading for 棒 put together.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

meaning.explanation: It has simplicity and is easy. Whatever it is, it is simple and easy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Simplicity is simple, making this simple as well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Steam energy is steam or vapor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you obtain supply, you have to put it all together somewhere. You have to put it in storage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Curious about the difference between 蔵 and 倉? Traditionally, the 蔵 kanji was used for sturdy buildings that stored important items. This is where samurai kept their valuables! On the other hand, 倉 originally referred to places to store grain, and usually weren't as robustly made. They're basically interchangeable now, but the 蔵 kanji is more commonly used.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 倉 and 庫. They're all basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (くら).

meaning.explanation: A sand sugar is just sugar. Nom nom nom, sugar.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something with not sugar is something that is sugar free or unsweetened.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A hometown potato is a taro. In Japan, taro is the kind of potato that everyone has in their hometown, because it's been around for such a long time and it'll grow anywhere.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, at least on the tendon side of things.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You get a horrible tendon injury, making it so you can't walk anymore. You're so upset that you blame it on Jesus. So, you go and sue Jesus for this tendon injury, and win in court, amazingly.

meaning.explanation: A window mouth is where you go to buy tickets out of the window. You know how there's those windows with holes in them, or the window is the hole itself? That's the kind of ticket window I'm talking about.

reading.explanation: The reading is the readings for 窓 and the reading for 口.

meaning.explanation: If you cut someone from the backside you're doing a backstabbing, making this word to backstab or to betray.

reading.explanation: The reading is 裏 plus 切る put together into one word.

meaning.explanation: 掃除 is cleaning, so the verb version would be to clean.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, it'll help to know the word 掃除 as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dangle so the verb vocab version is to dangle or to dangle something. You're doing the dangling.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What are you trying to dangle? You're dangling a taco (た) in front of a hungry person. He just wants the taco, and you keep dangling it like that.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means differ so the verb vocab version is to differ.

reading.explanation: Look at your coat (こと), now look at mine. They are different. If you look at them, they are going to differ.

meaning.explanation: 乾く is "to be dried." This is the version where you're doing the drying, making this to dry something.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 乾く.

meaning.explanation: 編集 is edit, so the verb version is to edit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means extend so the verb vocab version is to extend. Does the kanji look familiar, kind of like 広い, perhaps? 拡がる is the less common and narrower counterpart of 広がる. It's used to describe the enlargement or extension of the size, area, or range of something.

reading.explanation: This word shares the same reading as 広い. That means 拡がる is read as ひろがる.

meaning.explanation: Anywhere with lots of steam is going to get hot and sticky, so this word means... to get hot and sticky! With 蒸れる, something gets hot and sticky due to trapped heat and moisture, like sweaty armpits under a shirt on a humid day, or a sticky bottom after sitting at a desk for a while. Additionally, 蒸れる can mean to be steamed, like what happens to rice as it softens in a rice cooker.

reading.explanation: What is making things get hot and sticky? Not many people know this, but it’s actually all of the cows going moo (む). With how much they moo, they create so much steam that everything is turning hot and sticky. Who could’ve known?!

meaning.explanation: 散歩 is "a walk." Make that into a verb and you have to go for a walk or to go for a stroll.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 散歩 as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means heaps, so the verb vocab version is to heap up. It can also mean to serve food, as in you're heaping on food onto someone's plate.

reading.explanation: Please keep heaping up the food. I want more (もる), more, more.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means livelihood. The verb version is to live. It's not really "to live" literally, though. It's more like to live one's life, rather than just to live.

reading.explanation: If anyone is going to live one's life, it's gotta be the great Kublai Khan (く). He conquered most of the world and was super badass.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means manipulate, so the verb vocab version is to manipulate.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: A guy using eye arts (あやつ) isn't a great guy, it's the type of guy who might try to manipulate you via hypnosis of the eyes.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obstruct, so what is the verb vocab version? It's to obstruct.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You try to obstruct a woman coming your way (see kanji). As she gets close, she roars, "I am Sama(n)tha!" (さまた) You shall let me pass!" You don't argue with Samanthas. Get out of her way!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means ripen so the verb vocab version is to ripen.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If something starts to ripen too much, it gets all gross, and you're all like, "ew (う), that's gross."

meaning.explanation: 散る is "to be scattered." This is when you're doing the scattering. You know that because you're causing a ruckus (らかす) from all the scattering of money you're doing, down on the people below.

reading.explanation: The reading of the 散 comes from 散る. So, go ahead and scatter more memories around your brain, you got this already.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 離れる is "to separate," where something is just separating and you're not doing the separating? Well, this one has the same meaning, but now you're doing the separating. This word is 離す, and you know that you're doing the separating because if you don't, that person will sue (す) you for grabbing onto them and not letting go.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 離れる.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means supply so the verb version is to supply.

reading.explanation: So you're supplying something... let's say nuclear warheads... to Osama Bin Laden. You gonna be in soooo much trouble, especially since it's zombie Osama Bin Laden.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 驚く is "to be surprised"? This is when you are surprising someone else, doing the surprising, making this word to surprise or to shock.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 驚く. Don't be surprised if you remember the reading of this word because of your past knowledge.

meaning.explanation: A field of livelihood is so lively! Look at everything jumping around. It is so fresh and new and awesome! That being said, being so lively and fresh and new, it's pretty unrefined and rustic.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that has not yet ripened, is, well, unripe. This is often used figuratively to say that someone is either immature or inexperienced, so you'll often encounter those usages!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A cleaning (掃除) machine is a vacuum cleaner. Suck that dirt up!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "various _____."

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well.

meaning.explanation: Something is dangling in front of you, so you fix it so it's straight and not moving. It becomes perfectly vertical, perpendicular to the floor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Small wheat powder is wheat flour, or flour.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of all three kanji. The 小 and the 粉 both use kun'yomi that you haven't learned yet, but luckily they are both the same! Just think about how "small" things are like 子 (こ), and "powder" is also small. So both 小 and 粉 are read こ.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

meaning.explanation: An author makes writing in an activity known as authorship. Note that this word isn't a general term for writing! 著作 has a more specific nuance — it's mostly used to talk about a work or the writings of a particular author.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Extend the lens nice and big to zoom in on the subject, please. That's magnification, enlargement, and expansion.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that is pure fur is pure fur... but what kind of fur? In this case it's wool, making this mean all wool.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To run alongside the line (referring to the train line) means along the train line. What's along the train line? All kinds of things if you look carefully.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I recognize your consent. It is an approval and recognition of what I'm doing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You've got some deep red leaves. You'll usually see those during autumn, which makes this autumn leaves. Just red leaves is fine too, though. Note that this refers not only to the leaves themselves, but also the process of them changing color, so this can also mean leaves turning red.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. As you haven't learned this reading for 葉 yet, here's a mnemonic to help you: Your favorite pastime during autumn is sitting there admiring the autumn leaves while eating some yogurt (よう). There's no better combination than autumn leaves and yogurt. Note that there's also an additional reading, もみじ, used to refer to the Japanese maple tree, or its leaves, but we'd like you to focus on こうよう for this one.

meaning.explanation: It is a delight that you come so I welcome you. This delight welcome is a welcome.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Small beans refer to a type of bean known as azuki beans. It will help if you've heard of this delicious popular bean, because there's not really anything effective we can do with the meaning mnemonic from this point on. Just know that small beans are azuki beans.

reading.explanation: The reading doesn't make sense either. If you know that small beans are azuki beans, then you know that this is referring to a thing known as azuki (あずき). Other than that, there's not much else to do.

meaning.explanation: A government behind a curtain is the bakufu. They didn't let anyone know their government secrets so they would hide behind that curtain and keep everything to themselves.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 幕 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you try to peek through the bakufu's curtain you'll only see someone's back (ばく). They all huddle together to discuss things so a row of hunched backs is all you'll get out of the shogunate. That's not helpful.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: You want your beans, but you're also super lazy, so you call for your mom, yelling: "MAMEYYYYY, MAMMMEEYYY!" (まめ).

meaning.explanation: A cow rice bowl is a bowl of rice covered in beef, making it a beef bowl. Go get some Yoshinoya.

reading.explanation: This word uses the same readings that you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The holy writing is the Bible.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A deep red tea isn't a deep red tea... it's a black tea. If you think about it, a lot of black tea is really deep red, which is why a deep red tea is a black tea instead.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your blood fluid type is your blood type. This is a very important thing to know in Japan for some reason.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, at least the 血液 part. The 型 uses the kun'yomi reading, probably because it's an add-on word.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though it adds a few more meanings as well, like nail or talon or hoof or really any hard thing on the ends of fingers or feet.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The run alongside coast basically just describes the coast.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The run alongside sea is the sea that runs alongside the land, making it the coastal waters aka the coast.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Take your finger and brandish it to command the troops.

reading.explanation: The readings are the on'yomi readings, so if you know those you may take command of this vocab word.

meaning.explanation: The things you pass through on your way to work are the things you see and run into during your commute. Note that you can only use this word for commuting to work. You don’t use it to go to school unless you work at a school or something!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You consent and know everything that's going on. You consent and know about all this. You're aware of it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When something rots and eats away at something, that is corrosion. Not a good thing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means crotch and the vocabulary also means crotch or groin. This word is a little less specific than 股間, which you already learned. It can even be used to refer to the thigh, though in that case the reading is usually もも and it's mostly written in hiragana or katakana. This can also be used for a fork in a road or path, which makes sense when you think about it, doesn't it?

reading.explanation: You learned the on’yomi for this kanji, but like many kanji it takes the kun’yomi when used by itself. You haven't learned the kun’yomi yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you:  You’ve spilled something on your crotch again (また, get it?) but your pants are so stained at this point that it doesn’t even matter (また).

meaning.explanation: When a person goes into a place (then another person goes into the place, and then another person and another person), that place eventually gets filled with a crowd of people. Note that this word is more commonly written 人混み.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 人 and the kanji 込. Just keep in mind that the こ changes to ご and you'll be fine.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck.

meaning.explanation: Your loss comes from damage done to you. This is damage. This word is usually used as a noun. It can occasionally be turned into verb by adding する, but this is very rare!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Rot and failure lead to decomposition and rotting. This word also has the related meaning of corruption, similar to how "rotten" can mean "corrupt" in English.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A loss will give you a disadvantage. So, try not to get any losses... or you'll be at a disadvantage.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the kanji, so you aren't at a disadvantage... this time.

meaning.explanation: After you use it you throw away it, making whatever it is you used a disposable item.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 使う and 捨てる, combined into one.

meaning.explanation: You’re doing a 飛ぶ and 込む at the same time, or you jump into, meaning you're diving in. Picture yourself standing somewhere up high, and then jumping to dive into a deep body of water. Alternatively, this can also refer to doing something, or joining or going somewhere without an appointment, announcement, or prior registration, which is where the dropping by meaning comes in. For some use cases of this, check out our common word combinations and context sentences below!

reading.explanation: As long as you remember that we're combining the kun'yomi readings of the verbs and then turning them into a noun, you should know how to read this.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  Some dude... he did it two times. Yah, two (やつ) times. This can seem kind of derogatory, if you say it the wrong way. But as long as you're duding to your dude friends and not your no-dude boss, you should be a-okay to dude-bro it up!

meaning.explanation: The earthquake origin ground is where the earthquake started from. It is the epicenter.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You’re doing a bit of inferring while you determine something, which means you’re not 100% sure, making this an estimation. 推定 refers to an estimation that’s generally based on some evidence or reasoning. You’ll often find this used in statistical or scientific contexts, where it refers to an educated guess or estimation based on available data.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You say a reason for your actions, but really it's just an excuse.

reading.explanation: The reading is 言う and 訳 combined.

meaning.explanation: Normal work is work you do all day long, 8-hours a day, 5 days a week. That is full time employment or full time.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The origin family name is the original dude. The original dude comes from the original and first novel ever written, the Tale of Genji. These kanji represent Genji, good ol' Genji. Perhaps hopping over to the reading will help you to know the meaning of this kanji.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An eyeball mirror is something that refracts and focuses light into your eyeball in a different way so you can see better. Really, these things are glasses, not eye mirrors, but same sort of things when you get down to it. Just imagine someone wearing mirrors on their eyes, and when you ask them what those are for, they just say they're glasses.

reading.explanation: The reading for 眼 is the same as the vocab 眼. The reading for 鏡 is an exception, totally different. It shares a reading with 金 (gold), though, so think of the mirrors on the person's eyes being made of gold. What nice glasses! This word can also be read as がんきょう, but usually only on official/written documents. If you're speaking and not reading a government document, you should say めがね!

meaning.explanation: You know that 祖父 is grandfather and 祖母 is grandmother. This is both combined. Is it some hybrid grandmapa monster you've created in your lab? Hardly, it just refers to your grandparents.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 祖父 and 祖母, which are exceptional readings on their own, so you'll need them in order to be able to read this one too.

meaning.explanation: The heart internal organs is the heart, of course.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A big loss is a heavy loss.

reading.explanation: The reading is the おお reading of 大 coupled with the on'yomi reading for 損. Just keep in mind that the そん changes to ぞん and you'll be good here.

meaning.explanation: Everything that happened since you descended some stairs, is hereafter. It's all after the stairs thing you did, since you did it already.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: God is holy. Everything about a holy god is full of holiness.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Holy ground is holy land.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 真似 is "impersonation." Actually, this word is too. It's also impersonation. 物真似 is very similar to 真似, but can be used in slightly different contexts. 真似 is used for general acts of mimicry or imitation, and can also be used to refer to the way someone does something. On the other hand, while 物真似 also describes acts of mimicry and imitation, it's additionally used in performance or entertainment contexts to refer to people who do impersonation acts.

reading.explanation: The reading is 物 plus 真似 put together.

meaning.explanation: Not pure things are impure.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Inside internal organs are your internal organs, though you'd think the second kanji would give a hint to that without the 内.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A thin body type is called lean or slim. These days this is usually used in the context of slimming salons and massages you can get that may or may not work.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

meaning.explanation: Vertical and side (horizontal). That means you have the length and width and the vertical and horizontal.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that usually uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note however, that there is a less-common on'yomi reading,  じゅうおう, which is used in some idioms. It's good to know this reading exists, but you probably won't come across it very often.

meaning.explanation: This is kind of a "set phrase" in Japanese, though we're going to treat it like a vocab word here (because it's so common and useful!). You know that 久 means "long time" - so now let's pay attention to the kana: しぶり. Just imagine that she buried you alive, then a few days later came back to dig you up. The first thing she says is "LONG TIME NO SEE!"

reading.explanation: You learned this reading when you learned 久しい. It's the same one!

meaning.explanation: The lung internal organ is the lung.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A magnet stone is a magnet. Magnets look like little stones, right?

reading.explanation: The 磁 reading makes sense. The しゃく reading for 石 is an exception. To remember this, just think how you are using a magnet to find this shack (しゃく) full of other magnets. It pulls you towards the shack, and when you find it and open it, all the magnets fly out and crush you because of magnety reasons.

meaning.explanation: A magnet location is an area with a magnetic field.

reading.explanation: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Magnetic energy is when magnetism occurs.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji welcome, so it means a welcome or a greeting, but it's usually used for someone who's coming and meeting you!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: A mistake in what you calculate is a miscalculation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mistake in what you solve... wow, sorry, I thought I was supposed to solve this, not that. What a terrible misunderstanding.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mistake in use is a misuse.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you cut your claw you use a nail clipper.

reading.explanation: The reading is the reading you learned for the kanji 爪 and the word for the reading 切る.

meaning.explanation: A supply of beans is when you take a bunch of beans, mash them up into a supply, and then ferment them all together to make them into natto (also known as fermented soybeans).

reading.explanation: The reading is an exceptional one. 豆 is okay, and is the on'yomi reading from the kanji. The 納 part is weird though. Instead of being のう it's なっ. But, if you can remember the meaning of this word, you can just think about how you do not (なっとう) want to eat natto. At least a lot of people don't want to eat it. It's quite the acquired taste.

meaning.explanation: 興味 is interest in something. If you do not have (がない) that interest, then you have no interest or you're not interested.

reading.explanation: You learned that the word 興味 uses the on'yomi readings for both kanji, so all you have to do is add が + ない and you've got a new expression!

meaning.explanation: The older brother is valuable to you. But, no matter how valuable he is to you, he's still just your older brother.  P.S. You'll often see some gangstah thug call a higher ranking gangstah thug (one that acts like an older brother to all the other gangstah thugs) this. It's like family within the gang.

reading.explanation: The reading is 兄 on its own plus the reading for 貴. ANIKIIIII.

meaning.explanation: The origin is the origin, but it also refers to the ground springs, where the origin of water comes from.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Think of how this ground spring is everyone's (皆) origin (元). Everyone can use it, it's the 皆元!

meaning.explanation: You know that to 飼う is "to keep a pet." If you're the master that is keeping a pet (飼う), then you are the pet owner.

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi readings for both. You'll need to remember the words 飼う and 主 to be able to remember the reading of this word.

meaning.explanation: The delight and comfort street. Sounds nice. Sounds like the "pleasure quarter." You'll see these most often in samurai films, or in sketchier areas.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 複数 is multiple, and 形 is shape, then when something is in a "multiple shape," it has more than one version of itself. It's the plural, or the plural form.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 複数 as well.

meaning.explanation: The electricity origin is where the electricity comes from. It is the power source.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that's valuable and heavy is extremely precious and probably even more valuable than your less heavy things.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 重 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Keep things precious to you very close, because the evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will come and steal it away if you don't. She'll take every valuable you have and destroy them.

meaning.explanation: You're pure and that's stylish, which makes you even more pure, somehow. But your purity also makes you genuine, unlike all the people who aren't pure trying to be stylish.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It releases and shoots out of the bomb. It's not fire. It's radiation, and it sticks around a long time once it has been released.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To infer reason is to have reasoning.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To infer and recommend something is to give a recommendation. What do you recommend?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Shrink what you have into something small. It was big, now it's small. This is a reduction.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You shoot yourself at a mirror, and it is the anti-you. It is your reflection.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. To be exact, 丼 refers to a chinaware bowl that's bigger and sturdier than your ordinary rice bowl. It's often used for one-bowl dishes like katsudon, gyūdon, poke, but also noodle soups like ramen!

reading.explanation: You learned the どん reading for this kanji. This reading is just an extension of that, coming out to どんぶり. You can remember the ぶり part because you know what your favorite rice bowl is... it's a brie (ぶり) cheese rice bowl. Slightly unorthodox, but quite delicious!

meaning.explanation: As for myself? I recommend this product. It is a self recommendation. You make it of yourself!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A deep carve is very serious and grave. Just imagine getting cut with a sword. If the carve is deep, well, that's serious.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you shoot something into someone that you actually have to pour (aka a liquid), you're shooting them up with a needle, giving them a shot / injection.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Simple and pure. This is simple.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Some dude who is a slave is just a slave.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of 染. A dye would seem like the right answer, but what else is a dye? If you get it on you when you don't want to get it on you, it becomes a stain.

reading.explanation: The reading is unlike what you learned with this kanji before. Just think about how you have this stain on your shirt, all because you were trying to dye some sheep (し) and they didn't like it. So now you have a big dye and sheep poo stain. How were you supposed to know sheep don't like being dyed?!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you haven't learned yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You are stylish. Since you're stylish, you avoid icky (いき) clothing at all costs. You won't even be seen in the same room, that's how stylish you are.

meaning.explanation: A curtain of letters that goes on your screen are subtitles. Sometimes they have black bar backgrounds too, which are like curtains!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I am going to descend my participation in this conflict. I am going to descend all my weapons to the ground. I am going to surrender.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: People of a valuable tribe are part of the nobility. Unlike our tribes, they are valuable.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you take the time and carve it onto a surface, then you've made a timetable or schedule. 時刻表 generally refers to a timetable or schedule for transportation, such as trains, buses, or flights.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The 賛成 portion means "agreement", "approval", or "support", so the verb version would also be to agree, to approve, or to support!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I must say humbly that I want to get into this position, so I'm planning to apply for it and to submit an application. 申し込む isn't just about applying, though. It's about officially communicating desires, whether you want to propose marriage, challenge someone to a game of tennis, or even offer a donation to a good cause.

reading.explanation: The readings come from the word 申す and the kanji 込, stuck together... humbly.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means wound, and this verb is intransitive, so it means to be damaged or to go bad. After all, fruit with a wound on it is going bad, isn't it?

reading.explanation: This shares the same reading as 痛む. The meanings are similar too, so that should be easy to remember, unless your brain was damaged by these mnemonics or something.

meaning.explanation: If 染める is "to dye," then this is to be dyed. You aren't doing the dying, because you know that if you did it you would have done things right, unlike the other person who dyed your hair. This person marred (まる) it up really bad.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 染める.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is work which means this verb has something to do with working. It's not straight up "to work," instead it's "to work for" or "to be employed at."

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the other word that means "to work for" (務める). Remember this and you'll be able to remember the reading for this word too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve so the verb version is to carve.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't have a knife for your steak, so you have to carve it using the key zag (きざ) technique. You take a key and zag it through the steak repeatedly until you're able to cut up some zaggy bite-sized pieces.

meaning.explanation: Departure and brandish this thing. This means you're sending something out to show to everyone. That's why this is to exhibit or to demonstrate (because when you brandish, and send it out to show, you're demonstrating it!).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The はつ becomes はっ, though.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thin so the verb version is to get thin.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to get thin, just join the Yankees (や). They run their players around those four bases so much they all get thin quicker than you can throw a ball.

meaning.explanation: To do loss to something means you are doing something to make something have loss. This is to harm or to injure.

reading.explanation: In order to harm your opponent, you go way overboard. You soak (そこ) them in acid. Soaked head to toe. Too far man, too far.

meaning.explanation: You worship only the things you see. So, in order to see if something is worth worshiping, you'll go to have a look at that thing. And just so you know, this is a very formal word used when you're trying to be polite. So keep that in mind, please!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Giving consent to someone is similar to humbly listening to and accepting their words. So this word means to humbly hear and to accept. 承る is a humble version of 聞く. Its past form 承りました is commonly used in professional settings to respectfully acknowledge and accept requests, information, or tasks.

reading.explanation: You received (受けた) some information. Now, you are going to take that information that you received and then revolve it (回る) around in your head to think about it. Hmmm... hmm... Ok, I like what I'm hearing. I am going to accept what you said. Thank you.

meaning.explanation: You つける (attach) a wound to someone or something. In other words, this means to hurt someone, or to scratch or to damage something.

reading.explanation: The reading is 傷. If you remember the reading for that you got this too.

meaning.explanation: Departure and shoot something off. If you do that to something, you are going to launch it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 汚れる is "to get dirty." This is when you make something dirty, aka "to make dirty." You know that this is the version where you make things dirty yourself because when you make someone dirty with all that poop you're flinging, they sue (す) you immediately. This happens a lot.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 汚れる, so if you know that you can read this. Note that the reading よごす  is generally used for making things physically dirty, whereas けがす means making someone or something impure in a figurative way.

meaning.explanation: 越す is "to go beyond." Now you're going beyond your home and pulling everything with you to go to another home. You are trying to move / to move homes.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 引く and 越す put together. Careful of that っ.

meaning.explanation: 越す means "to go beyond." 追 is follow. If you are following someone, and then you go beyond them, you have overtaken them. That's why this word means to overtake or to surpass.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 追う and 越す put together into one. You can overtake this word now that you know that.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means throw up so the verb version is to throw up or to puke or to spit.

reading.explanation: The reading is from the reading you learned with the kanji. HA HA HA! Barf.

meaning.explanation: You know the kanji 込 means into. This verb is transitive, meaning you are doing the action. If you “do something into something” you are putting it into that thing. So this means to put in or to load something.

reading.explanation: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here. In case you need a hand with the okurigana, here’s a mnemonic for you: You always try to put in your emotions into the mail (める) you send. You don't just load your mail with words, but also with emotions, to make it truly heartfelt mail.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means recommend so the verb vocab version is to recommend. This word is often used in a positive context for recommending things, actions, and people by implying or pointing out their charms, merits, or both. Although 薦める and 勧める are similar, there are subtle differences between the two. 勧める is often used to suggest that someone perform a specific action, often as friendly advice or encouragement. It can also be used when offering something, such as a drink. On the other hand, 薦める is used to recommend a person or thing as suitable for a particular situation, with a focus on endorsing the subject rather than a specific action.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as 勧める, since they mean almost the same thing.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rot so the verb vocab version is to rot.

reading.explanation: Remember the word 臭い, which means "stinky"? When something rots, it becomes stinky, and all くさい.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means run alongside so the verb vocab version is to run alongside.

reading.explanation: Imagine yourself on a path designed to run alongside an endless array of soap (そ) bars. As you walk alongside the soap bars, you enjoy their delightful scents. It's a "scent-sational" promenade with soap bars that leaves you feeling squeaky clean!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shrink so the verb vocab version means to shrink.

reading.explanation: Jesus couldn't cause the monster to shrink. He had to transform into cheese jesus (ちぢ), a more powerful version of himself, in order to shrink the monster down to size.

meaning.explanation: You know that 詰める is "to stuff in" and the kanji 込 is into. When you’re stuffing something into something else, you are going to stuff or to cram it in. Just as in English, this word can also be used in a figurative sense, like cramming knowledge into your head.

reading.explanation: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. If you remember your kanji readings, you'll be fine here.

meaning.explanation: An all loss is when you lose it all. It is a total loss.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You throw and throw away something. That's why this means to throw away.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 投げる and 捨てる, combined into one garbage inducing dump of a word.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worship so the verb vocab version is to worship. 拝む generally means to pray to a deity, spirit, or revered object while assuming a worshipping position, such as bowing or clasping one's hands together in prayer. Additionally, 拝む can also mean to see with a sense of respect and reverence.

reading.explanation: You have to worship the ogre (おが), because if you don't it'll eat your face off.

meaning.explanation: You know that 書く is "to write" and the kanji 込 is into, so this means to write in, to fill out, or to jot down. 書き込む focusses more on the physical action of writing than 書く on its own. This is because 込む stresses that you’re putting words INTO some space, either on paper or on computer.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 書く and the kanji 込 combined into one.

meaning.explanation: A mistake in letters is a typo.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of valuable? It's valuable.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What is most valuable to you? Of course it's your toe toe (とうと). It's your big toe (the long とう) with another small toe growing out of it (short と). Imagine your toe toe, and then imagine how valuable it is to you. So valuable! You can also think about 尊い, a similar word which means "revered." It's a similar idea, and it has the same reading.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

meaning.explanation: Vertical writing is vertical writing. That's when you see Japanese and it's written top to bottom instead of sideways.

reading.explanation: The readings are the reading you learned with the kanji 縦 and かき (changes to がき), though the き gets smushed inside the kanji, because it wants to be confusing like that.

meaning.explanation: Just imagine a black curtain off in the background. You don't know what's behind it, but you know what's in front of it. Thing is, the thing in front of the curtain is controlled by whoever is behind the black curtain. This person is the wirepuller or mastermind of the situation. Like the Wizard of Oz, or something.

reading.explanation: The reading is the vocab readings for 黒 and 幕, though the vocab reading for 幕 is the same as the on'yomi reading, making things easy for you.

meaning.explanation: A valuable formal name ender. It's like saying something like "the valuable great you"... or something. Anyways, this means you, but it isn't as nice as it sounds. Probably a lot of irony and sarcasm going into this word, because if you use きさま to say "you" to someone, you're probably not pleased with that person, or you're just trying to be rude.

reading.explanation: The readings are the reading you learned with 貴 plus the vocab reading for 様.

meaning.explanation: You mix, then you go mutual, then you mix, and then you go mutual. Alternately, you could go mix again?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You've got a very elemental person. They're so elementary that they're quite an amateur, really. Maybe a little too elemental.

reading.explanation: Unfortunately, the reading for this is a complete exception, so you'll just have to memorize it. Here's a mnemonic to help you: "You're an amateur!", she wrote (しろうと). A little harsh, isn't it? But that's what she wrote. Gotta do a little better to impress her, pal.

meaning.explanation: If someone tears all your property it'll lead to bankruptcy. With all your property torn, you're going to go bankrupt. What mean person did that?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A soldier cottage is a place where the soldiers stay. This is the barracks.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: I will supply and you will acquire. Does that sound good? Do I have your consent? I can see that you're understanding and being convinced. You're planning on accepting my proposition, aren't you?

reading.explanation: The reading is a bit weird for 納. Just imagine asking the consent question from the meaning, then have the other person say "Nahh! (なっ), no consent!"

meaning.explanation: A slow carve is so slow. If you carve something slowly, it will take you a long time. You will be late with a slow carve like that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 編む is "to knit." When you knit in threes, you are knitting in a braid style. What do you braid? Hair. That makes this braided hair.

reading.explanation: The reading is the み from 三つ and つ and 編む combined into one (or should I say three?) braids. Just watch out because this isn't みっつあみ, it's just みつあみ. Listen to the audio a few times to make sure you remember how it's spelled and pronounced!

meaning.explanation: Blue copper is bronze. Bronze gets a bluish tint to it, which is why it's a blue copper.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. This will be particularly useful for names, as there's a lot of names with 杉.

meaning.explanation: When you infer and measure, it’ll lead to some sort of conjecture, speculation, or guess about something. 推測 means guessing based on known facts or information, while using reasoning to fill in the gaps.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: In a copper mountain you go in and make a copper mine.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. The 山 reading is ざん instead of さん because of rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A copper statue is a copper statue.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 著作 is "writing" or "authorship." The rights that writing has is what's known as copyright. Note that 著作権 refers to copyright for anything, not just writing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 著作 first, too.

meaning.explanation: A rice paddy and a cottage. This is the image of the countryside to me. This is rural. Just cottages and rice paddies...

reading.explanation: The reading doesn't really make sense for the kanji, and is an exception for sure. Just think about how when you're in the countryside you're in 中 (いなか) of nowhere.

meaning.explanation: The original oil is oil in its original state. That is crude oil.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you're mud drunk, you're so drunk you're rolling around on the ground. You are dead drunk.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't seen the on'yomi reading for 泥 yet (でい), so here's a mnemonic to help you out:  You'll probably get dead drunk if you start drinking in the middle of the day (でい). Just try to wait until the day is over, like maybe after work, you know?

meaning.explanation: You go for the sake of others. You are constantly doing deeds like this for others.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I was too slow, so we'll have to prolong the time in which this product will come out. This is a delay :(

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I am too slow so things have really begun to stagnate. What a delay.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sand desert is just a desert.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Tear and break everything, taking it all down. Destruction! Demolition!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of shame? It could be ashamed or even embarrassing.

reading.explanation: When you're ashamed it's even worse when someone laughs at you: ha (は) ha ha!"

meaning.explanation: You're making your escape from prison . So this means... escape from prison. Or jailbreak if you're feeling a little fancy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same!
