reading.explanation: Ho nooooo (ほのお), there are flames everywhere!

meaning.explanation: You move towards the sake. When you move towards it, you are doing something for the sake of. But why use fancy language like that? Let's just leave it as for.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For the sake of public safety, you will need to tame (ため) the wild beasts loose in our city. Now go, tame them!

meaning.explanation: Fruit soup isn't really a soup, it's more of a fruit juice.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You take your salary and buy oil. When you are doing this, you are fueling something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A government office cottage is the place where the government office is stored. That's the government office building.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Luck for your whole lifespan, that's a life of happiness and longevity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The earth prison is a prison down inside the earth. What prison is under the earth? That would be hell.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have the same sound with a different meaning (異義), and it's a part of language. Same sounds... different meanings... that sounds like a homophone, or a homonym.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. All I know is there's probably not a homonym for this word, for it is huge.

meaning.explanation: 尊敬 is respect. A respect language is honorific Japanese (or honorific language, though usually this refers to Japanese).

reading.explanation: The reading is 尊敬 plus 語 put together.

meaning.explanation: If it’s a steaming hot day, it means the weather is hot and humid (or you can just say humid, because that usually implies hotness too). This is a useful word for summers in Japan, since you'll complain about this all the time.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 暑い. Know those and you know this too.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.  This is generally used to count single-family detached houses, but it can also be used to count individual units within a residential complex, as well as shops or restaurants.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: When you enter prison that's imprisonment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you let someone cut off your oil supply, it's probably because of your inattentiveness. You let your guard down.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you have flame symptoms that's when you feel like you're filled with fire, which is inflammation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you're inside prison you're in prison.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your crotch and what's below it is called your inseam. It's that line that goes down the inside of your pants. Depending on your variety of English, you might call this your inside leg instead!

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun’yomi reading of both kanji. You learned また from the word 股, and you learned した from the word 下 a lonnnng time ago. If you didn't remember either of these, hang your head in shame and look at your またした!

meaning.explanation: I jammed in myself and entered your personal life. Because I care, you know? I don't want you to be addicted to My Little Pony anymore, so this is an intervention.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: My introduce was jammed in there for you to hear. That is my introduction. Jammin' it in.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The path of the sword is known as kendo. You could also say Japanese fencing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Bear origin prefecture is Kumamoto Prefecture. Probably best to learn this meaning via the reading. Also, you should look up Kumamon of Kumamoto-ken.

reading.explanation: The reading is 熊's reading, the alternate "origin" 本 reading, and the reading for 県.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is crazy long, but also crazy easy! You know みず means "water," and うみ means "sea." So, you have a "water sea" which is a lake, which is a みずうみ.

meaning.explanation: The mountain middle lake is lake Yamanaka, a famous and very nice lake in Japan. It's also a lake that will help you to learn the lake kanji reading better.

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of 山 and 中, then the on'yomi reading of 湖.

meaning.explanation: Perform your lecture. This is your lecture. This is your address to the people.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Lecture of righteousness is still a lecture.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A lecture expert is a lecturer or instructor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 暮らす is "to live" or "to live one's life" then the noun version would be simply life.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 暮らす.

meaning.explanation: Your lifespan is your fate and will show you how long your lifespan is.

reading.explanation: You did learn the reading of 寿, but the reading for 命 is an exception. When you think of a lifespan, think of how that affects everyone. Me, you... well, just those things. Combine them both into myou (みょう). That is who the lifespan affects. Myou!

meaning.explanation: A long lifespan is a long life.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A flavor that makes foods boisterous is a great flavor. In this case, it's the flavor of miso, which goes in a lot of Japanese dishes, and certainly does make the flavor of things boisterous.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Mutual and mutual is mutual.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Despite it looking like an adjective, this is the noun version of the kanji, making it mutual. It also means each other and reciprocal and together, too.

reading.explanation: Let's help each other. Maybe if we work together we can get rid of this tagger (たが) tagging graffiti all over our neighborhood.

meaning.explanation: 否定 is denial. Remember how 形 sometimes refers to grammar tense / type? Well, with a denial type grammar, you have a negative form, making it a negative sentence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: View and measure what you are watching. This is observation. It is no mere viewing, it is more than that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Oil that has stones in it is from the ground. It's not olive oil, it's petroleum!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: You need to apply oil to a bra (あぶら) because it's stuck on you. You can't get it unhooked, so you have to slide it off. Problem is, it's too tight, which is why a bra needs oil to slide off.

meaning.explanation: An oil rice paddy is really more like an oil field.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 田 yet. Just think about how you walk into the oil field and you see a bear den (でん), filled with oil.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also means myself and I.

reading.explanation: As for myself? I'm not Bob. oh no, Ray (おのれ), Ray is my name.

meaning.explanation: A white bear is a polar bear! They're the only white bears in the whole world!

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A beforehand measure is when you make a prediction or estimation about something. While 予想 often refers to a subjective prediction, 予測 generally refers to forecasting future events based on objective evidence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The prime minister's (総理) government is where he does all his governmenting. It's where the Japanese Prime Minister's Office (aka the Cabinet Office) is located as well. 総理府 was actually renamed 内閣府 in 2001, so you'd generally only use 総理府 to talk about the Cabinet Offices from back in the day.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 総理 beforehand as well.

meaning.explanation: You see the kanji for rain being followed by the 天 kanji from 天気 (weather). This word means rainy weather. This has a formal nuance to it, and is often used for event announcements (whether to postpone it in case of rainy weather, etc).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, so you use on'yomi readings. You should be familiar with the on'yomi reading for 天 already, but not for 雨. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember: The rainy weather won't stop you to go catch some uni (う). You would get wet anyway diving into the ocean to collect uni, the rainy weather doesn't affect you. You can also sell them for ten (てん) bucks a piece! The rainy weather isn't at all a problem for a uni hunting if you're making ten dollars for each, you know?

meaning.explanation: What exactly are your parent relatives? Your own relatives! You're all kin, after all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you exit from prison you are getting your release from prison. But, before you move on, let me tell you one thing: Hope is a dangerous thing. Hope can drive a man insane.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Wake up from your bed and get up. You are rising or getting out of bed. 起床 is a relatively formal word that is commonly used in writing. It's also used as a command to wake up individuals in settings like military bases or prisons.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Just remember that rising and getting out of bed early is the key (き) to the Shogun's (しょう) heart. He doesn't like lazybones, so make sure to get out of bed at a reasonable time.

meaning.explanation: You carve then you carve again. So much carving until, wait, wow, it looks like something! All that carving became a sculpture!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sea turtle is a sea turtle. Cowabunga!

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of these kanji, put together. I suppose it's because it's like two separate words put together into one. That makes this word read as うみがめ, where the かめ gets rendaku'd.

meaning.explanation: Your self oneself, is your oneself or self.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A self photograph is exactly that: a selfie.

reading.explanation: This word uses the on'yomi of 自, which you learned with the kanji, and the kun'yomi of 撮, which you learned with the word 撮る. Though it's a bit of an unusual combo, you can probably guess the first one since it's such a common reading, and the second one because of the り on the end. Just watch out for rendaku, which turns とり into どり.

meaning.explanation: The reality of the sword is that it will cut you right in half and kill you, easily. The fact that this is true is a very serious thing. Very serious.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You can rejoice because your lifespan has reached this special point. That special point is your seventy seventh birthday. So many sevens, lucky!

reading.explanation: The readings are the on'yomi reading. You've seen the on'yomi reading of 喜 before, though it may be hard to remember at this point. Maybe you can think about how when you reach this seventy seventh birthday, all you want is a key (き) to the city so you can do whatever you want.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This is also the reading you learned. How nice! But if you don't remember it, what a shame. What an embarrassment this must be for you.

meaning.explanation: A tear in your ship will cause it to wreck, making it a shipwreck.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Soy sauce oil is soy sauce, or as it's called in Japanese, shoyu.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you have an idea, it means you are important. You have significance. Those without ideas are just big jokes and can't do anything at all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have one muscle, therefore it only does one thing. That's it. It is single mindedly doing that one thing. It is intently and earnestly doing that one thing.

reading.explanation: The reading is a bit weird. It's the kun'yomi readings, where 一 is ひと and 筋 is すじ. Look back on the vocab words that use these readings to remember this one.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You are given some soup. You take a bite and your mouth is cut clean off. That is because you're eating sheer (しる) soup.

meaning.explanation: The lifespan of a director depends on how much sushi they eat.  Okay, the kanji in 寿司 aren't actually related to the meaning of the word, so this one's kind of tricky. Just try to think of sushi as the secret to a long lifespan for directors. Imagine all those directors wolfing down a bunch of sushi because they're desperate to lengthen their lifespans.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It might also help to know the kanji in 寿司 are 当て字 (remember those?). They have nothing to do with sushi, so they're just being used here for their sound.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word covers all types of swords and sabres, though it was originally used mostly for double-edged swords.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading! This word can also be read つるぎ, but in that case its meaning is limited to Western-style swords only. Because of the meaning difference, we only accept the けん reading (but you'll get another try if you enter つるぎ).

meaning.explanation: Your teardrops are also known as your tears.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher: Your teardrops are like little waves. What are they? They're 波だ (なみだ).

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drunk so the verb vocab version is to be drunk. This drunk feeling also happens to some people in boats and cars. But we call that to be seasick or to be carsick. You aren't actually drunk, but you feel like you are (and you're probably gonna puke, yuck!).

reading.explanation: I'm not drunk, yo (よ). YO. I'm not drunk, yo. YO. Yo, I'm not drunk. Yo.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means courage so the verb version is what happens when you have lots of it. Someone with courage is probably the kind of person who is able to be in high spirits in the face of something! 勇む means to be eager to face something or to face it with bravery and determination. It often indicates proactive and enthusiastic engagement. You'll find it in written expressions like 喜び勇む (to joyfully and eagerly undertake something) or 勇んで出かける (to go out with determination).

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who is the one person who always seems to be in high spirits? Isabel (いさ)! She's so positive and eager, even in the face of a challenge.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means model, and the verb version means things like to be in light of something or to take something into account. If something is your model, you're taking it into account, and it's in light of it that you make your decisions. This verb is transitive, meaning that it can take a direct object, but you'll probably see it used more with the particle に. It's a pretty formal word so you'll mostly come across it in official, written contexts.

reading.explanation: This verb uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that yet, so here's mnemonic to help you: If you want to take something into account, you'll need to 考える (かんが) about it really hard first. Please think about it really, really carefully, because it's bound to be in light of something, and we need to know what that something is.

meaning.explanation: If something or someone is slow, and they "do slow" they are going to be late.

reading.explanation: What is slow and probably going to be late all the time? A big oak (おく). Oaks have trouble moving, and are slow, and therefore are always late, too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stagnate, and the verb vocab version is to be overdue. After all, if something stagnates, it's not advancing, which causes it to be delayed.

reading.explanation: Your work tends to be overdue, so you get a lot of to-do calls (とどこおる) from your boss, reminding you to do your work. These calls are pretty annoying, but at least your work is less delayed.

meaning.explanation: When you calculate and determine (the calculation), you are determining the calculation. That's why this word is to calculate. Unlike 計算する, which means “to calculate” in general, 算定する is a formal word that focuses more on the final value of a calculation, instead of the process of calculating itself.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chat or talk so the verb version is to chat or to talk.

reading.explanation: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

meaning.explanation: If 垂らす is "to dangle something" then this is to dangle or to drip. You're not doing the dangling, which is rare (れる), because usually it's you who's doing the dangling.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 垂らす.

meaning.explanation: If 否定 is "denial," then the verb version would be to deny.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 否定 as well.

meaning.explanation: If you go to attire yourself, you're covering up who you are and trying to be someone else. You are trying to feign. You are trying to wear a lie. You are trying to pretend.

reading.explanation: While you go to feign that you're someone or something else, someone calls you out on it: "you so (よそお) much a liar!"

meaning.explanation: You've been so busy with your livelihood, you didn't even notice it's started to get dark outside. When you're doing lots of living, days and seasons just seem to end rather quickly like that. Alternatively, think about how rare (れる) it is to get dark. It really only happens once every 24 hours. A pretty rare occurence if you ask me.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 暮らす, so if you can remember that, you should be able to remember this one too!

meaning.explanation: Remember how 傷 is "wound"? Now a wound is つくing to you, or in other words, is getting attached to you. If you get a wound attached to your body, you are probably going to get hurt.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the word 傷.

meaning.explanation: 盛る is "to heap up." If you "raise" (上げる) what you heap up, well, that comes with heaping something up, making this word to heap up or to pile up. This word is also used when you want to liven up some things. Heap up that energy and stir things up!

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 盛る and 上げる. Know those words and you'll be able to read this one too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means measure so the verb vocab means to measure. This word generally has to do with scientific or medical measurements.

reading.explanation: Remember another word that means "to measure?" It is 量る, and has the same reading as this word. That should make things easier to remember.

meaning.explanation: If 宣言 is a "proclamation," then the verb version will be to proclaim.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You steam something to return it to its previously warm state. This is when you go to reheat something. But we usually use it to talk about bringing something up again and again in conversations or arguments. That's why it means to rehash or to bring up again. You're bringing up memories from the past and steaming them up again.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 蒸れる and 返す. Combine this knowledge to reheat your memories.

meaning.explanation: If 尊敬 is "respect" then the verb version would be to respect.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 納める is "to supply" or "to deliver," then this word is when things have been delivered: so it's to settle into or to be satisfied.  納まる means something or someone has found its right place and settled there. It often implies that there was a prior state of uncertainty or dissatisfaction, but now everything is in its right place. Like most verbs with まる as okurigana, this is an intransitive verb. That means it happens by itself, with no emphasis on the person or thing that's making something settle or be satisfied.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 納める.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tear so the verb version is to tear.

reading.explanation: You start to tear the cloth. You don't know if you're supposed to or not. The crowd isn't sure either. You hear kind of a yah boo (やぶ) reaction going on, making you unsure if you should continue or stop. Yah! Boo. Yah! Boo!

meaning.explanation: Someone who backstabs (裏切り) someone is a traitor.

reading.explanation: The reading is 裏切り and an exception reading for 者. Just think about how you'd think of a traitor as a "thing" (物) and not a person.

meaning.explanation: The misfortune is just getting jammed in there. So much misfortune leads to very troublesome trouble. 厄介 describes something or someone that is troublesome, or the trouble itself. It's very similar to 面倒, but 厄介 is often used for more challenging or complicated situations.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The やく gets changed to やっ.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. BURN BURN BURN.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Something with a vague nature is also quite vague.  Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have various various things. They are various. You have all kinds of them.

reading.explanation: The reading is a bit weird. Just think about how when you have various things, you probably have a lot of things. What do you want? You want more (もろ) of those things. More more more!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji!

meaning.explanation: A vinegar thing is a thing that has been vinegared. This is a vinegared food or a pickled food.

reading.explanation: The readings are the readings for 酢 and the kun'yomi reading for 物 which you've seen quite a bit by now.

meaning.explanation: It is obsolete so we must stop it. No more of it anymore. This is abolition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I will accept and I have agreement in the matter. I have come to acceptance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: We are of the same alliance. We are in an alliance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An aunt feels like a mother sometimes, but she's still an aunt after all.

reading.explanation: The reading for the 母 part is just the first は in はは, rendaku'd. You can also think of your aunt as a sheep, too, if you'd like. Baaaah!

meaning.explanation: A bad example is a bad example and is something you don't want. This is a formal expression and less common than 悪い例 (bad example) or 良くない例 (not good example).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: I would like to offer my blood to someone else in the form of a blood donation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A debt ticket is a bond. You buy it from the government and then they pay it back to you with interest... in theory.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This very common food is parent and child rice bowl, aka a parent and child rice bowl. The parent is a chicken. The child is an egg. This can also be called chicken and egg rice bowl, or simply oyako-don.

reading.explanation: The reading is 親 and 子 and 丼 combined together.

meaning.explanation: A same window meeting is a meeting with people who spent a long time gazing out of the same classroom window as you. Who are those people? They're your former classmates, and this is a class reunion. It can also mean alumni association, which is still something you do with former classmates, so it makes sense.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 窓, so here's mnemonic to help you: If you have a class reunion coming up, you'd better work on your soul (そう). You want to make a good impression on all your old classmates, right? Well get to work on your soul right now, otherwise they might not be impressed.

meaning.explanation: The master commander is the commander of all commanders, the commander in chief if you will... or, even the team captain.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 指揮 is "command" or "lead" then someone who does those things is a commander, or conductor. Usually the kind that conducts an orchestra!

reading.explanation: The reading for this is the reading of 指揮 plus the on'yomi reading of 者.

meaning.explanation: You have my consent and agreement. This is my consent, agreement, or acceptance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Do we have agreement or no? Which is it? consent or refusal? Yes or no? Choose!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you change something then exchange it, you are making a conversion or a change. 変換 generally refers to converting something from one form to another, like data conversion, energy transformation, or even converting hiragana to kanji.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You leave behind your body to join the spirit realm. This body remainder is your corpse or remains.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your debt rights state that you have a certain amount of credit with your bank. And if they try to say you don't have that credit you can file a claim against them!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  People think you're dancing, but you're really jumping from the mice (まい) running on your floor. You don't want the mice running up your legs so you have to hop from one to the other, making it look like you're dancing.

meaning.explanation: You dance, you step, you dance, you step. Good job! Now you're doing dancing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  You're staring really closely at this deer, but something looks off. You get closer, slowly, and you realize it's a sheep in a car (しか) shaped like a deer. The sheep car deer suddenly turns toward you rushing forward, legs raised. Ahh, get outta there! (The lesson here is to never get too close to a deer. You never know its true form until it's too late.)

meaning.explanation: Tooth science gives you the science of dentistry, simple as that! Note that when used by itself, this word solely refers to the scientific field of dentistry. You'll often see it used in combination with other medical words, so have a look at the common word combinations if you wanna know more!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 歯 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know who benefits from great dentistry? Sheep (し)! Have you seen one smile? Their wool makes a great, endless source of dental floss. That's their secret. Just think of the sheep and their perfect teeth and you'll never forget this reading!

meaning.explanation: Being reliant on something in order to exist is dependence or reliance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When something reaches normal, it has finished diffusion. Normal things aren't all bunched up and concentrated. Normal things are spread out nice and evenly, via diffusion.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the adjective form of 汚, which is dirty. This word is the adjective dirty, but you can also use it to say things like filthy, foul, or unclean.

reading.explanation: The reading is different from the other kun'yomi readings you've learned so far with this word. It is きたない. Think of it like you're saying "来た、な", as in "it came, huh?" What came? A really dirty looking monster, and it's coming for you.

meaning.explanation: I'd like to offer money, no strings attached. It's free. It's a donation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A branch bean doesn't mean a whole lot this way, but you probably know the food that this describes anyways. This is edamame, a food made from steamed soybeans, usually with a bit of salt added for flavor.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, unfortunately. That's the vocab words 枝 and 豆 combined into one.

meaning.explanation: An unagi rice bowl is an eel bowl, and it is very good.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A 磁場 is a "magnetic field." An electricity version of this is an electromagnetic field.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings for the first two kanji and the kun'yomi reading of the third. You should be able to read this on your own. Will of course help to know 磁場 as well.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Using your animal fang you are able to eat kibble (きば).

meaning.explanation: Your former surname is just that: your former surname! This is often your maiden name, as in the name you had before getting married.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your surname and your name put together create your full name.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The commander will come in the future. Not anytime soon, but in the future. 将来 generally implies the nearer, more concrete future. You’ll probably use it when discussing your career plans or a company's growth strategy, and not what the Earth will be like 100 years from now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The big commander is the general or admiral (or head or leader). Basically, they're big stuff.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: One generally does things... in general. It's more common this way.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the はん changes to ぱん for 般.

meaning.explanation: What I leave behind and transmit to you is your heredity. You have my genes, even after I'm gone.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, which you've already learned.

meaning.explanation: A horse deer is a stupid idea. You're an idiot for thinking about it, really. It's quite dumb.

reading.explanation: You learned both of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you leave behind property it's known as your inheritance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Do you know how suspicious I get if I have an injury? I start suspecting everyone around me of having given me the injury. It was you, wasn't it?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. It also uses the less common reading け, which you learned with 怪, so here's a mnemonic to help you recall this reading: Remember the suspicious soul and its kettle (け)? Yup, turns out this exact kettle is responsible for the injury. Suspicious souls and their kettles...

meaning.explanation: An elephant tusk is the material known as ivory (or just an elephant tusk).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Rope writing was used during the Jomon period, a time in ancient Japanese history when people decorated pottery with rope.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A song dance deed is a deed you do that involves singing and dancing. This is the traditional form of stage deeds, known as kabuki. Watch it on YouTube if you want a taste.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The deer child island prefecture is Kagoshima Prefecture.

reading.explanation: The readings are part on'yomi, part kun'yomi, but you should know them all if you look at them one by one. Just remember that 児 is read as ご here. Go, Kagoshima Prefecture! Go!

meaning.explanation: The god Nara river Prefecture is Kanagawa Prefecture.

reading.explanation: The か of 神 is used here (losing the み). Then, everything else should be self explanatory.

meaning.explanation: Something big in width is large. In fact, it's of a pretty substantial size. This word is used to describe a large magnitude or degree of change, increase, decrease, or difference in a given situation.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If we take along our alliance and move it forward to something better, we have a league or federation. It's like we're one group now!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mouth deep red is a deep red you put on your mouth. This is lipstick.

reading.explanation: This uses kun'yomi readings for both of the kanji. You already know this for 口, but you haven't learned either of the kun'yomi readings for 紅 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you memorize the one you'll need for this vocab: Your favorite lipstick is one called Benny  (べに) by... Benny. There's a guy called Benny that makes really pretty lipstick, he's just not great at naming things, so it's all just Benny.

meaning.explanation: The thing we leave behind at a fault is a loss.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Maintain what we have and put it on hold. We need to keep it up to date and fixed, so we need maintenance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: I reached the ordinal number prefix that represents a passing score on my test. This means I was able to make the grade! Wow, passing an exam feels great. 及第 is an old-fashioned term that you might see as part of the word 及第点 (a passing grade), especially if you read a lot of classic Japanese books.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Cure and heal me. That is medical therapy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A medicine can heal. This is medical treatment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji mistake, so it means a mistake or if it's on a computer, an error.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you make a mistake, you need to admit to it. When someone asks, "Who's responsible for this mistake?" You say, "I am (あやま)."

meaning.explanation: Nara is good and it is Nara (the place, we're talking about).

reading.explanation: The reading for 奈 is good, the reading for 良 is pretty off in terms of what you've learned. But, if you know that the meaning is Nara, you know the reading is なら as well.

meaning.explanation: A country's debt is the national debt. It can also be bonds, like the ones you buy from your country.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This throw up energy you feel inside of you… could it be… nausea?!

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 吐く and the (irregular) reading of 気 put together.

meaning.explanation: A nucleus experiment (実験) is a nuclear test.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Nucleus arms (へいき), aka weapons, are nuclear weapons.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word can also mean core because that's where the nucleus is in a cell, and nuclear because we like to blow ourselves up nowadays...

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned.

meaning.explanation: The open sea is where the sea joins together to be the open sea.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi readings that you learned when you learned the kanji. Just remember that this time 合 takes the あい reading.

meaning.explanation: When you arrange things in the way that nature intended, you're doing things in a quite orderly fashion. This is the natural state of things, nice and arranged and natural. Orderly! Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: I will permit this, and you have my agreement. Both of these things combine to be my permission and my consent.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An alliance promise is one that's made with a pledge or pact. Imagine making an alliance with someone, pledging your support.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Take your finger and pluck out the one thing out of all the things that needs pointing out or identification. Yep, that's the one. Pluck that one.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: 放射 is "radiation." Add the ability of radiation and you have radioactivity, for some reason. I guess things don't have radioactivity until you have given them the ability of radiation, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 薦める is "to recommend," then the noun version would be a recommendation or some advice. This generally refers to a recommendation of a person or thing, not an action.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 薦める. Might I make the recommendation to learn that word first?

meaning.explanation: I believe I can trust you. That's why I put so much reliance and trust on you to do well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I am reliant on you and I trust you. Therefore, I have a request for you that I'd like to entrust you with.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: We must maintain the new and get rid of the old. It's time for a restoration of policy! This also refers to the Meiji Restoration too. In fact, it probably mostly refers to this, though you'll learn a more full version of this later.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Restore to the former self. This is restoration.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Please hand me the rope, right now (なわ), otherwise I will fall to my death!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. But! Some explanation about when to use さけ versus しゃけ. They're both technically right. But, typically when you refer to the living animal, you use さけ, and when you refer to salmon as a food, it's more likely to be しゃけ (but it can go either way). There might be some generational and regional differences, though.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you walk around on the beach, you'll get sand in your shoes sooner (すな) or later.

meaning.explanation: The commander of the army is the shogun. Do you know the shogun? He ran Japan, and was like the ruling general over the states. You can also call him the general or commander, if you like.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sick bed is a sickbed. If you're in that bed, you're probably sick. 病床 is a relatively advanced word found in written phrases like 病床にふす (to be in sickbed). It can also formally refer to a hospital bed.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Well up water is spring water. Kind of makes sense, right?  Note that 湧水 is a formal word generally encountered in written language.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A dance machine isn't really a machine... a 台 is a large machine thing counter, so in this case it's talking about a stage. A dancing stage is a stage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 台 is read as たい here, not だい.

meaning.explanation: I will inherit at your consent. It's not just given straight to me at birth, though it kind of is. I get succession, but only if people say it's okay.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that is ultra natural (自然的) is supernatural. Too natural! Super!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sweet? It's sweet.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The sweet group is a group of people who love sweet things. They really have quite the sweet tooth.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the readings you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Remember 源氏? He has his own 物語. This is the very first novel ever written (that we know about). This is the Tale of Genji.

reading.explanation: The reading is the combination of 源氏 and 物語 which you have learned before so you should have no problems with this one.

meaning.explanation: If a 奴 is just some dude or some guy, adding a ら on there makes it plural. Now it's those dudes or those guys.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 奴.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means trust, but the verb vocab version is to ask for or to rely on or to request. When you trust someone you can 頼む them, but only when you trust them. You put it in their hands. You trust them, after all.

reading.explanation: But, you're entrusting this task to your friend not because you are busy, but because you want to go have a 楽しい (fun) time at the waterpark. Sucker!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obsolete and this word means to become obsolete.

reading.explanation: Everything has to become obsolete. Even the biggest most fiery things, like a star, for example, will go obsolete at some point.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means wound, and this verb is transitive, so it means to damage something or to injure something. You can use it to talk about parts of your body, so you'll sometimes see it used interchangeably with 痛める. The difference is that it's objectively focussing on the damage, not the pain. That's why 傷める can be used for objects like cars and furniture, too, whereas 痛める is only for people and body parts.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading when you learned 傷む. Yay!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance, as well as to flutter.

reading.explanation: Who is the greatest dancer of them all? China's previous ruler, Mao (まう).

meaning.explanation: The kanji is exchange, so this verb is to exchange. If you exchange one thing for another thing, you are going to exchange it, after all. This word refers to exchanging one thing for something different. Wondering about the difference between 替える and 換える? 替える means swapping one thing for another of the same kind, whereas 換える means exchanging or trading one thing for something different, often of similar value. So, you use 替える when switching out light bulbs, but opt for 換える when trading jewelry for cash.

reading.explanation: I don't like this car. I would like to exchange it for another car (か).

meaning.explanation: This is the verb version of the kanji fry, so it means to fry, more specifically to stir-fry or to sauté.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go!

meaning.explanation: Bean rot is when you take soy beans, let them ferment, and then you make tofu out of them! Yep, that's what tofu is. Rotten beans.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stretch and the verb vocab version is to grow longer or to be stretched. You know that this is the version where you aren't doing the stretching, because you're letting someone stretch you on a torture rack in order to win a beer (びる). You're that desperate.

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inherit and the verb vocab version is to inherit.

reading.explanation: You not only inherit one fortune, but two! You're lucky both sides of your family "accidentally" died at the same time. TWO (つ) fortunes! TWO! HAHAHAHA. Also, you can think of it like the つ of 次, because you are the "next" successor when you inherit something.

meaning.explanation: When you see something as sweet, you're just looking at it like it's some little sweet kid with sweet flavoring. You are not taking it seriously, or you are taking it lightly. So sweet! That's why this word is to not take seriously or to take lightly.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 甘い and 見る. Don't take this word lightly and you should be able to learn it no problem.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pickle, so the verb version is to pickle something or to marinate something. 漬ける is specifically used to describe the process of pickling or marinating foods, such as vegetables, fish, or meat.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pluck so the verb vocab version is to pluck or to pick or to prune, like with plants.

reading.explanation: You are going outside to pluck two (つ) of your favorite flowers.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means reach and the verb version is to reach or to amount to . This is like "x reached y" or "x amounted to y."

reading.explanation: Oh, yo, if you want to reach that number, you'll have to try harder.

meaning.explanation: If 吐く is to throw up, and if 出す is to remove or hand over, then if you throw up and hand that throw up over to someone via your throwing up, you are going to spit out at them, or to spew out, or something gross along those lines. Then again, this word can be used to be like "spit the info out already!" too, so it's not all spitting for reals.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 吐く and 出す.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means step and the verb vocab version is to step on. So, not quite "to step" like you might expect, but at least you're stepping still, though it's on something.

reading.explanation: You want to step on that bug? You fool (ふ)! That's a killer shoe stabbing bug, it will cut right through your sole and poison you via your foot! Fool!

meaning.explanation: 降参 is "surrender" so the verb version would be to surrender.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading is the same as 降参 as well, of course.

meaning.explanation: To pluck off someone's mask and departure it off somewhere away from their face, that is to unmask or to expose someone.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji itself means well up, and this is also to well up or to gush out. Remember us talking about courage welling up in the kanji mnemonic? This word can also be used for that kind of figurative welling up, like of emotions, which is where the meaning to arise comes from.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You're fishing in a hole in the ice when suddenly the water starts to well up and to gush out of it. A huge walrus (わ) splashes out and jumps on you. No wonder there weren't any fish! This is a walrus hole.

meaning.explanation: Trade is easy if you like trade and commerce.

reading.explanation: The 貿 reading is okay, but the 易 reading is different from what you're used to. Just think about how a lot of the trade that comes in will come into the train station (駅). So if you want good trade, you'll want to be at the えき.

meaning.explanation: A harbor wave is a wave big enough, it could easily submerge an entire harbor. What could you call such a wave? Perhaps a tsunami, or a tidal wave.

reading.explanation: The reading is the 津 and 波 kun'yomi readings, combined together.

meaning.explanation: This has the same meaning as the kanji. Stick this onto another word and you have "ultra _____."

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: An ultra sound wave is an ultrasonic wave.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that the は changes to ぱ for 波.

meaning.explanation: An uncle feels like a father sometimes, but he's still an uncle after all.

reading.explanation: You already know the お reading for 叔, but じ for 父 is new, so here's a mnemonic to help you: One thing nobody knows is that your uncle is none other than Jesus (じ)! That technically makes God your grandfather. Don't tell anybody about this, though.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 貴重 means "valuable?" Well valuable products are your valuables!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that will exchange energy is something that pulls in air, takes out the bad stuff, and then outputs good air, exchanging it for the bad. That is ventilation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: If 勤める is "to be employed at," then the noun version of this is work. I mean, I really hope you're doing work at the place that employed you... if not you'll probably be fired.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 勤める.

meaning.explanation: レントゲン comes from the German word "Röntgen" meaning X-ray, named after their inventor Wilhelm Conrad Röntgen. If that’s news to you, here’s a mnemonic to help you remember:  You’re planning to rent a Genji (レントゲン), but you ask Genji to get an X-ray first, just to make sure he’s in good health before signing the rental contract.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When 陣 means army camp, it's mostly used in historical contexts to refer to troop formations or encampments. It's not used for modern army camps, but you'll probably see it in connection with samurai battles. It's even used in dodgeball to talk about the enemy's side of the court. In modern Japanese, 陣 is commonly used as a suffix to mean a corps or group of people engaged in some activity together, like 報道陣 (the press corps) or 教授陣 (a group of professors, i.e. the faculty).

If not, just imagine a bullet being grabbed out of the air by Tamara (たま), the local ball girl. She heard there was a たま and mistook it for a ball, and now her hand is kinda messed up. Try not to repeat her mistake.

When it indicates a kind of brushing off or brushing away, it appears in words like 足払い (sweeping an opponent's legs in judo) or, more figuratively, せき払い (clearing one's throat).

Depending on the context, it can also refer to matters that fall under criminal law, like 刑事事件 (criminal case).

meaning.explanation: The machine gulf isn't what you'd expect. In fact, looking at the reading will probably help the most first, since this word represents Taiwan.

reading.explanation: The reading is たい for 台, which is a little different from what you learned, but not the end of the world (especially if you can get the meaning down). The わん is however what you learned, so even if you arrive to だいわん, you'll probably realize that this is たいわん.

meaning.explanation: Look to time to see how much longer this will last. It's not forever, it's temporary, which is why we must look to time to figure out how much longer it'll be around.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is recruit, so this verb vocab version can also mean to recruit. However, its primary meaning is to appeal for something, like a job position or donations. This verb can also be intransitive (oh my!) and mean to grow stronger, usually in reference to some sort of feelings or emotions. Make sure to check out the common word combinations for some example usages!

reading.explanation: You'd like to appeal for two, no (つの), three things! Three!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means afflicted and the verb vocab version is to be afflicted with or to suffer from.

reading.explanation: I was afflicted with an ancient Egyptian disease that turned me into sun god Ra, but now I'm okay. I was a Ra (わずら), but now I'm just me again.

meaning.explanation: Being in the versus yonder (the opposite side) means you are in one yonder and someone is in the other yonder, and you are coming towards each other. So this means to be oncoming or to come towards.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 恥ずかしい is "embarrassing." This is the verb version. What happens when someone is embarrassed? They become shy and bashful. That's why this word is to be shy or to be bashful.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 恥ずかしい.

meaning.explanation: Weird that this kanji means bullet but the verb vocab version means to bounce. Just imagine someone shooting a bullet. What does it do when it hits the right materials? It's going to bounce.

reading.explanation: If you're going to bounce something off that wall, it has (はず) to be made of rubber, otherwise it will just go right through. It has to.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means burial, so the verb version would be to bury or to inter.

reading.explanation: We're going to bury you, so this is your new home (ほうむ) now, friend.

meaning.explanation: To make reparations is to compensate for or to make up for something. You're going to atone for your sins. This word is mainly used when someone is taking responsibility for a mistake, a wrongdoing, or a loss by providing compensation or otherwise making things right.

reading.explanation: When you try to compensate for everything you've ever done wrong, you become too good for your own britches. You are too good now (つぐなう).

meaning.explanation: The kanji means dispatch but this word is to consider or to make use of. Just think about how if you have people that are on dispatch for you, you can send them information to consider and to make use of.

reading.explanation: This has a similar meaning to 使う, and has the same reading too. If you remember that, you can remember this word's reading.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is crumble, so what happens when you crumble something? You are going to demolish it. You are going to break it. You know you're doing the crumbling / demolishing because someone's going to sue (す) you for what you've done here today.

reading.explanation: You are Zeus, and you demolish everything in your path. Your friend Hercules watches and is all like "That's coo' Zeus (くず), that's so cool."

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means favor and the verb vocab version is to do a favor for.

reading.explanation: If you are going to do a favor for anyone, it's going to be for your good buddy meg (めぐ). Imagine a Meg you know (or know of) and imagine yourself doing a favor for her. Meg Ryan is so happy you're in her life.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hug and the verb vocab version is to embrace or to hold (in one's arms, that is). It can also mean to hug, especially in the form of 抱きしめる. Keep in mind that depending on the context, 抱く can be a euphemism for something way more sexual than just hugging. Not always, of course, but pretty often, so just be careful how you use it! 抱きしめる is the better option if you're talking about regular old hugs.

reading.explanation: What are you going to embrace? How about your dad (だ)? Or if he's not around, maybe an e-dad (いだ)? You know, like a digital version of a dad. The two readings for this word have different nuances. だく is more for physical holding and hugging, as in 赤ちゃんを抱く (to hold a baby). But when it's something you hold in your heart, like an emotion or feeling, use the いだく reading: 疑問を抱く (to hold doubts) or 夢を抱く (to have a dream), for example.

meaning.explanation: If you look to something, you are facing it, taking it head on. That's why this verb vocab is to face, as in "to face terrorism," etc.

reading.explanation: The reason you must (to) face terrorism is because the terrorists have threatened to take everyone's noses (のぞ) away. We must face them head on if we are to save our noses!

meaning.explanation: If 破る is "to tear" or "to rip," then this is to get torn or to get broken or to get ripped.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 破る.

meaning.explanation: A 紹介 is an introduction. So the verb version is to introduce.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Helps that I introduced introduction to you earlier.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hop and the verb vocab version is to hop or to jump or to leap. Basically anything that gets both feet off the ground via your own foot propulsion.

reading.explanation: Know how 飛ぶ means "to fly"? This is a similar idea, though this time you're not flying nearly as much, because you're just hopping or jumping. Anyways, the readings are the same.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means listen and the verb vocab version is to listen to or to hear.

reading.explanation: The meaning is really similar to 聞く, right? The reading is the same.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means display, so if you're doing the action of displaying something, you're going to put up something, or, sometimes more specifically, to put up a sign.

reading.explanation: You have to put up a sign for your newest invention, the car car (かか). It is a car made so that other cars can drive the car. Nobody wants to buy it, which is why you have to put up a sign.

meaning.explanation: If you're anti something and you confront the government about it, in some cases you are going to rebel against the government... that is, if you're crazy enough about it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Resist and confront those who oppose you. This is to resist.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means return and the verb vocab version is to return or to be returned. This is when something does this on its own. You aren't doing the returning of something in this case.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means struggle so the verb version is to struggle or to fight. This struggle is fairly figurative, too. It's more like "the struggle against terrorism" or "the fight against drugs." Not so much a fight with people, which would be 戦う.

reading.explanation: Your neighborhood is fighting a struggle against car theft. Sadly, your car was stolen. So, you say: "ta-ta, car (たたか). Ta-ta."

meaning.explanation: 盛り上げる is "to heap up" - this has a similar idea, except now this is more like an excitement or swelling. As excitement heaps up in you, you are going to get excited. Note how 上がる is in here. This means something is happening to you (or something else), but you're not doing the action. When you get all sorts of excitement building up in you, you aren't really doing it, it's just happening on its own in reaction to something else.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 盛り and 上がる. Let the excitement build as you realize you know the reading already.

meaning.explanation: If you are tenacious you will be able to take control of and to carry out any plan you want. You are tenacious, you are.

reading.explanation: Notice how the word "take" is in this verb. If you take something, you might say 取る. This word shares take's reading.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means whittle down and the verb vocab version is to whittle something down, to shave something down, and to reduce something. This verb is transitive, meaning you're whittling something down, like a piece of wood, or reducing something, like your expenses.

reading.explanation: To whittle something down or not to whittle something down. Will have to take it on a case (けず) by case basis.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When something leaves traces or marks behind, it's because they were there, but now they're gone, and you've come 後 (あと) they left.

meaning.explanation: In Japanese, pickled things refer to  Japanese pickled vegetables! 漬物 refers to Japanese pickles made by soaking vegetables like cucumbers, daikon radish, or eggplant in a solution containing ingredients like salt, rice bran paste, vinegar, and soy sauce. They're left to ferment or marinate, enhancing their flavors. In contrast, western pickles are simply called ピクルス.

reading.explanation: You already learned 漬ける (to pickle something), so just take the る off and shove the け into the kanji. You still read it, but it's hiding. It probably shrank in the pickling process. Stick some things (もの) on there and you know the reading! Not bad!  By the way, sometimes you'll see this word spelled like 漬け物 too.

meaning.explanation: I steal by listening to what people say. I do this by wiretapping their phone and bugging their homes.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You are favored with knowing things. You have wisdom and intelligence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you have a tenacious writing brush, you are doing a lot of writing. Also, if you write for a magazine you probably write a ton too, because they have to come out with new issues every week or month.

reading.explanation: The 執 is a little altered, where しつ is shortened to しっ. You've seen this kind of thing before, so just keep this shortening pattern in mind and you'll be a-okay!

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 馬鹿 means "idiot?" Well put two idiots together and everything they say and do is absolutely absurd. Remember how ridiculous that "Dumb and Dumber" movie was? Yeah. Like that.

reading.explanation: You already learned 馬鹿, so as long as you can remember it twice in a row, you should be able to read this too!

meaning.explanation: 馬鹿 is "stupid" so if you hear a rumor about something (らしい) that's stupid, you'll just respond by saying "that's absurd."

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 馬鹿.

meaning.explanation: To 頼む is "to ask for" or "to request." The noun version of that is a favor or a request.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 頼む.

meaning.explanation: A cool cluster is something that has a cluster of cool-creating coolant. This device is air conditioning.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Join and join with each other. This is an annexation, or a merger. 併合 generally means that one entity absorbs or incorporates another entity, often implying a dominant or controlling role by one of the parties.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember that 合 is read as ごう here. Who orchestrated this annexation? Good ol' grandpa ごういち.

meaning.explanation: 及ぶ means "to reach" or "to amount to." The noun version is more like a grammar thing, as it means "as well as." Perhaps if you are reaching a certain point or certain amount, then you are adding things on. That's why this means "as well as". Note that 及び is a term usually used in formal writing.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 及ぶ, so if you know that one you know that one as well as this one.

meaning.explanation: A dancing (舞踏) meet is when you all get together to do dancing, the kind that's like "step step swing" (or whatever). This is a ball or dance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
