reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A person with genius and talent is a genius, or a person of exceptional talent. So smart! 俊才 is an advanced word usually only seen in writing. It tends to refer more to the kind of genius or talent that can be developed through effort. In that sense it differs from 天才, which is for the kind of genius that comes from heaven — either you have it or you don't.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of glad? It's also glad!

reading.explanation: Whenever you're really glad to be alive, you look up at the sun's rays and sing, "Ooh, rays (うれ), I'm so glad you're here!" Then your Uncle Ray comes dancing into the room and sings back, "Ooh, Ray is happy you're happy!" The sun's rays and Uncle Ray both make you really happy.

meaning.explanation: If 扱う is "to handle," the noun version of that is handling or treatment.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 扱う, so if you know that you'll have a good handling of this one.

meaning.explanation: A famous honor is still an honor, but it is also a prestige to have, since you are famously honorable. So prestigious!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have a prosperity of honor, therefore you have honor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The inside ditch is the inner ditch, or, if you make it awesome enough, the inner moat. If they get through the outer moat, we have the inner one, at least!

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi / vocab readings of these kanji. 内 + 堀 added into one word.

meaning.explanation: It's so elegant and so comforting. This is Japanese court music, and it's what fancy court people listened to in Japan back in the day. You can also call it gagaku if you'd like.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The fragrance river prefecture is Kagawa Prefecture. Might help to look at the reading first.

reading.explanation: This reading is made up of the kun'yomi readings for 香 and 川 (rendaku'd) and the on'yomi reading for 県. You haven't learned this reading for 香 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help: If you want to get to Kagawa Prefecture you're going to need a car (か). It's all the way over on Shikoku island, and you won't be able to cross the big bridge without a proper car!

meaning.explanation: In your knee there is a small priest named Kneecap. This is a really common, cute way of talking about your kneecap. It's usually used by kids and adults alike, and it's more common in spoken Japanese than 膝頭. Kind of like how we use "kneecap" instead of naming the "patella" bone all the time.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for 膝 and 小, but the on'yomi reading for 僧, which gets rendaku'd from そう to ぞう, so watch out for that! You've learned all these reading before, so you should be able to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: To fly and leap is leaping. 飛躍 is mainly used in a figurative way to highlight remarkable progress in areas like personal growth or technological advancement. It can also describe a logic that jumps suddenly from one point to another without clear connections.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that is overgrown and luxuriant must have quite the luxuriant growth. Lots and lots of growth.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I praise you for what you did, so here's your prize to go along with my praise, a medal!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A medicine dose is medicine or drugs you're taking.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you take a dose of something, you are taking a dose of medicine. Take your cough syrup, child!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji, probably because it's attached to things usually, so it's treated like on'yomi.

meaning.explanation: You revolve to review the record of the past. These records are memoirs or reminiscences.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You know that 麺 means "noodles", and つゆ is another word for "soup" or "broth". Put the two together and you have the delicious mentsuyu , or noodle soup base. It's usually made of dashi, soy sauce, mirin and sugar. Yum!

reading.explanation: You learned the reading for 麺 when you learned the kanji.

meaning.explanation: What's supernatural and suspicious? A monster, or, if you know the Japanese term, a yokai.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means Milord, and this word used to be a name ender similar to the English title Lord, but nowadays it's closer to Mr. or Ms.. It's rarely used in speaking or even written correspondence these days, but is still used in official documents, and you'll probably see it most on certificates. If in doubt, you're better off choosing the name ender 様 because it's much more widely used, and also more polite than 殿.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Do you know a Lord? Imagine it being someone named Mr. or Ms. Don (どの). If you know a Don, that's great, imagine that person. If you don't, think of a famous Don that's out there.

meaning.explanation: A neighbor person is a neighbor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Remember the movie "Tonari (となり) no Totoro"? That is the Tonari.

meaning.explanation: All the near neighbors are the people who live around you and near you. They're a part of the neighborhood.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A neighbor country is a neighboring country. For us, our 隣国 in America are those sneaky Canadians... always waiting to strike, I can tell...

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A neighbor house is a neighboring house. That house is right next to ours!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for this vocabulary is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. Go eat some noodles to celebrate!

meaning.explanation: Remember how 沖縄 is "Okinawa"? This is the prefecture, Okinawa Prefecture.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 沖縄 and 県 put together.

meaning.explanation: The outside ditch is the ditch around our town that's on the outside (not the inside ditch, which is the inner moat). This is the outer moat.

reading.explanation: This word uses the same readings from the previous vocabulary except that 堀 gets rendakued - don't forget!

meaning.explanation: You've surpassed what is normal alertness. You are too alert. You notice everything. This is oversensitivity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Milord's hall is a nice place. It's where a lord would live. A palace. By extension, this can also mean a sanctuary, and even a hall of fame.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A location where cars can be a resident is a parking lot.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned these readings already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

meaning.explanation: You patrol and revolve around the block to make your patrol. You're going around patrolling.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A medicine dose expert is someone who knows exactly how much dose of each medicine you should be getting. The person who specializes in this is a pharmacist.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A patrol of thanks is a patrol you make to something you're thanking. Sounds religious. Sounds like a pilgrimage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: You'll have to imagine a pillar standing tall, and made entirely of the Egyptian god Ra and hashbrowns. It is a hash-ra (はしら) pillar, made by the Egyptians who love breakfast.

meaning.explanation: Those who patrol and inspect are police officers or patrol officers. 巡査 specifically refers to the lowest-ranking officers in the police force in Japan, whose duty is patrolling or doing things around 交番 (police boxes), or responding to emergency calls.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A portable belt is something so portable you can put it on your belt. It is portable. Note, this is also a very common term for a cell phone or mobile phone. You'll learn more about that in the coming levels.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A prevent rot dose is a dose of something you put on your cut or wound that prevents it from rotting (or you put it on something else to prevent it from rotting). This is an antiseptic or preservative.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you're overgrown with prosperity you are probably really prospering.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A machine alert is an alert that is timed by a machine, not by a human. It's pretty quick. It's also quick-witted. Machines can move and think so much faster than us, after all. 機敏 is often used to describe the way someone responds promptly to various situations, and implies being highly responsive and adaptive.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Life, when it multiplies (multiply), is doing reproduction.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You're a resident and you exist in the place you're residing in. That means you have residence.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your roofs are spread out around your property. Put these roofs and areas all together and you have your residence or estate.

reading.explanation: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I praise you for your beauty. I'm so into your beauty, I hand you a reward... a prize, basically.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Grab your noodle pole and let's make some noodles. What's a noodle pole? It's a rolling pin! You use your rolling pin to flatten out the noodle dough before you slice it into noodles. That's why a rolling pin is so important to make noodles.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. So just keep rolling.

meaning.explanation: A sacrifice hit is one you do in baseball, when you hit the ball in the air, and then the person on third tags up and scores. In baseball, this can either be a sacrifice bunt or sacrifice fly.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned the readings for both of these kanji, so you should be able to read this word already!

meaning.explanation: Remember when you learned 房? Well it can be used as a counter for clusters of fruit. Like a section of an orange or a bunch of grapes! Yum!

reading.explanation: You learned this reading already when you learned 房!

meaning.explanation: Spread the gold around. First part, I want you to put in a security deposit.

reading.explanation: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you have an alert feeling, you are sensitive to things going on around you. That means you have a lot of sensitivity!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of sharp? It's sharp.

reading.explanation: Something that is sharp will stab someone, but they will sue you for your rude behaviors. They sue rude (するど) behaviors...

meaning.explanation: Someone on sharp alert has a sharpness about them. They are quick witted and have a strong keenness to them. This word is formal and literary.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that is sharp will benefit from its sharpness, since that's all it has, really.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you collide and attack what you're colliding into, you're going to not only cause a large shock but also crash and impact into them. Blamo!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Concurrently with my current business I have a side business. It's really a second job, actually.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You're singing and you're chanting. It's a gay ol' time. You're singing and singing and singing!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You're chanting and you're singing and you're having a gay ol' time. You're singing all your songs and even the chanting sounds like singing. It's so fun.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An alone chant is one you do alone. It's a solo!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A seized thing is something you've seized from your victory. It's your spoils. It's your trophy!

reading.explanation: Since you didn't learn the kun'yomi for 獲 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. Eh (え)? We won the game? Ehhhh?! No way! To the victor belong the spoils! Yay!

meaning.explanation: You're so glad, you get glad again. No matter what you're doing, it's undoubtedly in a state of enjoyment. 嬉々 itself refers to a joyful state where someone happily does something. It's generally used as the adverb 嬉々として, which means “happily” or “gladly.” While less common, it can also serve as an adjective when combined with たる.

reading.explanation: This word uses on'yomi readings of the kanji you learned... twice! You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something or someone resident in 日本 (Japan) is stationed in Japan. 駐日 is generally used to describe both individuals and institutions stationed in Japan for official duties, such as the 駐日大使 (Ambassador to Japan) or 駐日大使館 (embassy stationed in Japan).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A resident detained in a location who is in the army is a member of the stationed troops at this location. They could also be the occupying troops as well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sitting spread is a spread of tatami mats, making up the tatami room in a Japanese house.

reading.explanation: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An electricity pillar is a telephone pole. All those wires and telephone wires going to and from those telephone poles.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of dilute? It's dilute. And something that's been diluted is now thin.

reading.explanation: This drink is way too diluted. You sue (うす) the makers for their thin drink.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means dilute, and this is an intransitive verb, as you can guess from the まる ending. So this verb means to be diluted, to be diminished, or to become weak.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too. If not, here's a mnemonic to help you: You don't want your drink to be diluted, so you sue (うす) anyone who dares pour you a weak drink.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means luxuriant and the verb vocab version is to be luxuriant or to grow thickly.

reading.explanation: She gave (しげ) me a razor because my beard was starting to grow thickly... too thickly. But, I won't shave my awesome beard no matter what she gave me.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transparent and the verb vocab version is to be transparent (since usually people can't "to transparent" something).

reading.explanation: To remember the reading, just think about something that is supposed to not be transparent, but is transparent after you give it to someone for a while. You're so upset that your (dog/cat/plant/car/etc) is transparent that you sue the guy who was supposed to not make it transparent.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blow so the verb vocab version is to blow.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means chant so the verb vocab version is to chant.

reading.explanation: Really, when you are going to chant, the most important thing to do is to figure out your tone (とな). If you get the tone down, the rest comes naturally.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concurrently, but since you can't "to concurrently", we're going to have to come up with another word to use: "to combine" or "to double as." Since this kanji has to do with something having a dual purpose, we can say that something can combine as being another thing, or double as being another thing, which is where these words come from.

reading.explanation: For example, a car (か) can double as a place to sleep at night when not enough people become members of WaniKani.

meaning.explanation: If 遠慮 is "decline" or "restrain" then the verb vocab version is to decline or to restrain.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, the reading comes from 遠慮.

meaning.explanation: Somehow the kanji portable turns into the verb to engage in or to participate or to take part in. I suppose if you are portable, you're able to engage in all kinds of things, since you can move all over the place, participating everywhere you can (rather than being not portable and being stuck in one place).

reading.explanation: A Taz saw (たずさ) is a saw owned by a Tazmanian, and it is particularly portable. It allows you to participate in all kinds of things, like cutting down trees, or being in a horror film.

meaning.explanation: If you know that 避難 is "evacuation" then you know that this is the verb form of that: to evacuate.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will also help to know the reading of the word 避難.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gallop and the verb vocab version is to gallop.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means patrol, but what do you do when you patrol? You go around, which is to go around.

reading.explanation: You're going around patrolling to protect the house of Meg (めぐ) Ryan. Just imagine Meg Ryan's house, and you walking around it. Imagine Meg Ryan looking out at you.

meaning.explanation: Here we have world with the particle に, following by the verb 出る (to go out). Put that together and this means to go out into the world, to be published or to be released to the public in some way or another. Once it's out there in the world, there's even a chance for it to become renowned.

reading.explanation: This uses kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you should already know by now, so I think you're good to go!

meaning.explanation: If something is suspended, it is going to hang or to depend on your actions. We need you to make sure it goes right! Your actions are what we're suspended on!

reading.explanation: We're depending on you to help us to get this car (か), okay?

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lean and the verb vocab version means to lean something.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading already with 傾く, so remember that and you'll know this one too!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means review. What do you do when you review something? You look back on it. Meaning to look back on something or to reflect on something. This can also mean to be attentive to someone, for example your family. This is a transitive verb, meaning it takes a direct object. You look back on the past, you reflect on the consequences of your actions, and you're attentive to your family.

reading.explanation: For the reading, think about another word that is similar: 帰る. With 帰る you are returning to somewhere. With this word, you're returning to look back on something. They share the same first part reading, so you should take advantage of that. 帰る → かえり.

meaning.explanation: 緩む is "to loosen," but has to do with loosening on its own. This word is when you loosen or relax something, meaning to loosen or to relax.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 緩む, so you can use that!

meaning.explanation: To take and then handle means you're taking it and handling it, causing you to manage or to handle something. You got it because you took it.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 取る and 扱う.

meaning.explanation: You already learned that 逃げる means "to escape," and this verb is when you let something escape, or slip through your fingers. So this means to miss or to lose a good chance, or to let go of a good opportunity.

reading.explanation: Here's a mnemonic to remember the kun'yomi for this word: You missed a huge opportunity. Why? Because there was no gas (のが) in your car! Think about what opportunity you missed out on because you forgot to fill up your car.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means multiply and the verb vocab version means to multiply or to increase.

reading.explanation: What is multiplying? Your use of the word "fu" (ふ) for when you laugh. You used to say just "ha ha ha" like everyone else. Now the occurrences of you saying fufufu is really multiplying. You might also notice that this is similar to the word 増える, which means "to increase." This has a similar meaning and the same reading, use that to your advantage!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means title, so just think about when someone gives you an awesome title. They are doing this to praise or to give praise to you.

reading.explanation: After they go to praise you, you're all like "I don't need praise! Ta-ta (たた)! I'm outa here."

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means praise and the verb vocab version is to praise.

reading.explanation: If you are going to praise this guy in front of you, it would have to be for his amazing hoe-using (ほ) abilities. Look at him go with that hoe.

meaning.explanation: 繰る is "to spin" (so spinning) and 返す is "to return" (so returning). Put them together and you have something that's spinning and returning to the same spot over and over. Something that does that is repeating itself, making this to repeat or to repeat over and over.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 繰る and 返す. Combine them together to get the reading.

meaning.explanation: 選択 is "selection" or "choice." If you do the verb version of this, you are going to select or to choose.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading also comes from 選択.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spread and the verb vocab version is to spread out or to lay out. This word generally refers to laying something flat, like a carpet or a picnic blanket. This use also extends to laying railroad tracks or asphalt for street paving. Metaphorically, it describes laying down something foundational, like establishing rules or specific organizational systems.

reading.explanation: What is getting spread out? Sheep (し)! Someone's been hunting sheep, because you're looking at a bunch of empty (dead) sheep bodies spread out on the ground.

meaning.explanation: I say my commandment in order to warn and to caution the people not to do bad things.

reading.explanation: The first commandment I say to warn them of not doing bad things is I mash (いまし) my own potatoes. Nobody else mashes my potatoes. Got it?

meaning.explanation: Something that is transparent and bright so that you can see through it is transparent.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: My warning commandment is there to make sure you take precaution and show vigilance when it comes to that precaution. It's only a warning commandment, though, which is why it has to do with prevention and precaution.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: My instruction is my commandment. You must do what I say in my instructions/commandments. This is my warning. This is my admonition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something is diluted to the point of weakness. It has much weakness and feebleness.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have only one life so do everything with lots of eagerness (懸命). Do everything with all one's might. Go all out.

reading.explanation: Everything except the 生 uses the readings you learned with the kanji, and you learned this reading of 生 when you learned 一生. You've really been going all out to learn these readings!

meaning.explanation: Your interior formal name ender (person) is the person who's waiting internal, out of the picture (remember, kanji was made forever ago and is pretty sexist). This person is your wife.

reading.explanation: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: You release and abandon something. This is abandonment. 放棄 is a relatively formal word for abandoning something. It can refer to giving up responsibilities, like neglecting duties or parental obligations, or relinquishing entitlements and rights.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An aviation (航空) mother warship is a warship that is like mother to all the aviation things (the airplanes). They come home to their mother warship, which is an aircraft carrier.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Penetrate the night and go on through to the morning. You were up all night and had a sleepless night aka all nighter.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of amazing? It's also amazing! Or terrible. But that's because this word actually derives from the name of a skilled butcher character in ancient Chinese literature. The more you know!

Kind of like a chip or pretzel, you can't just have one. With lies, you have to open your mouth for two more. And then two more.... and... well you get it.

reading.explanation: You never wrap things once, you always wrap them twice. And then you double that. It's a two two (つつ) wrapping technique. つつむ is the reading we want you to focus on, but it's good to know that 包む can be read as くるむ as well. くるむ is used when you wrap something up carefully and protectively, like a baby in a blanket. つつむ on the other hand, has broader use and is commonly used for wrapping things like presents.

meaning.explanation: At the arrival time you will arrive. This is your arrival.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The hinge axis of something is the axis or pivot where things hinge. 枢軸 is generally used figuratively to describe the central part of something important, or the center of power.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The middle of the axis is where the axis is, of course, but it's also where the pivot is too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A pair of eyeball mirrors - that's binoculars. Binoculars have mirrors in them to allow you to see through the pair of eye holes, which is how this word makes sense.

reading.explanation: The 鏡 part uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. To remember this, just think about how when you look down binoculars, you see something strange (like a strange reading for 鏡). That strange thing you see through these fantastic binoculars is... tomorrow. Your binoculars are so strong that you can already see tomorrow, today (きょう)!

meaning.explanation: I'm going to twist this bullet and turn it around on you. You're the one I'm going to blame, which is why my blame bullet is twisted back at you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The middle hinge is the center pivot point.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Clothes and attire makes this clothing at its core, but these days, it often refers to special costumes or outfits. This commonly refers to special or ceremonial clothing, costumes, stage outfits, traditional cultural clothing, etc. For some example usages, feel free to check out our common word combinations and example sentences!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. While you've learned these for both of the kanji, 装 actually uses one you haven't learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know whose wardrobe was definitely full of special clothing, costumes and outfits? The shogun's (しょう)! Know all those old-timey looking paintings of shoguns in their regal attire? Just think of that when you have to remember this reading for 装!

meaning.explanation: It will pass through what you believe and run into some netting. Just think about how all these communications are passing through between people, and everyone believes everything that's being said. Netting this all up (all these communications!) leaves you with a communication network. What fun!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Distract me with a twist in what we're doing. Just imagine you're working on something. Then, you get distracted by a twist in whatever it is that you're working on. This little twist doesn't destroy everything, but it does cause a complication and confusion.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Time to overcome the clothes of our enemies. They all wear the same kind of clothes (let's say blue clothes) so we know that if we overcome the blue coated people, we will have won. It will be a conquest!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You need something so you request it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a demand.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: If you're overcome with brightness, you'll be able to see all the little fine detailed things.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 不孝 is "disobedience to parents"? Well, someone who shows disobedience to parents is a disobedient child or an unfilial child.

reading.explanation: 不孝 is a reading you should know already. Add the もの reading for 者 and you have yourself a reading. Now go be obedient to your parents and keep studying your kanji.

meaning.explanation: When you throw out something and abandon it, you are essentially dumping it. 投棄 is a formal word for throwing away things, often used in the context of illegally dumping waste.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 投 when you learned 投資 a long time ago.

meaning.explanation: Something that is round and slippery just moves around with no trouble at all. It is so effortless in how it slides around. It is also super smooth.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When your heart moves then shakes, you’re in a state of emotional turmoil or unrest. 動揺 refers to being emotionally shaken, or feeling disturbed, agitated, or unsettled.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned as well!

meaning.explanation: Let's departure on our digging up of this site. It is more than just digging, we're going somewhere and learning new things with this dig. This is an excavation!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the 発 getting shortened.

meaning.explanation: An imitation of an example is the exemplification of something. It is also a model of the example of what you're making.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Let's take a look at this example and surround it. This example shows the extent or scope of what we're doing, and the line that surrounds it shows how far that scope goes.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You know how 孝行 is "filial piety," right? Well, this is basically the same thing. You're just showing said filial piety to your parents, which, of course, is what filial piety means. That makes this word mean filial piety.

reading.explanation: The reading is 孝行 plus the kun'yomi of 親. Put them together and you'll become a good filial child.

meaning.explanation: The char point is the part you're looking at so hard it burns a little hole in it. Just imagine yourself looking at a single point so hard that it begins to smolder. This is the focal point or the focus.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Please temporarily wait. Please wait for a little while. In a little while something will happen, but for a moment you'll have to sit still.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: For a little while, we're going to listen to shiba rock (しばらく). This is a form of rock and roll performed by shiba dogs. You should look up shiba inu puppy pictures if you haven't ever heard of shiba inus.

meaning.explanation: What's your favorite fry meal? Surely it's fried rice, who doesn't love fried rice. Note that this word is also commonly written in katakana, so you may see it written that way on a menu!

reading.explanation: You know the reading for 飯, but 炒 uses an exceptional reading that you didn't learn. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Do you know what would bring your fried rice to the next level? Some charcoal (ちゃー)! Next time, just add a little charcoal to your fried rice, and it'll taste so much better. Trust me on this one.

meaning.explanation: A purification location is the place where you perform purification on people. Who needs the most purification? The dead. Where do you purify them? In a funeral hall.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the on'yomi for 場 when you learned 入場 ages ago.

meaning.explanation: A garbage (ゴミ) sack is a garbage sack or garbage bag.

reading.explanation: The word for sack (ふくろ) is rendaku'd, so be careful of that.

meaning.explanation: Your grip power is your grip, or more specifically your grip strength or handgrip.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A grip with your hand (onto another hand) is a handshake.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. With 手 just think back to other vocab words that use the on'yomi reading.

meaning.explanation: It hangs on an axis point. The axis opens up, and reveals a hanging scroll. This might take a little extra imagination, but I believe in you.

reading.explanation: For 掛 you'll want to think back to the word 掛ける, then shorten it and shove it into the kanji half way (the かけ part at least). For 軸 that's the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that to work off of.

meaning.explanation: If you have the ol' liver flame then you probably have hepatitis. AUGH! MY LIVER IS ON FIRE.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What kills insects with one dose? That's an insecticide or a pesticide.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You know that 不孝 means "disobedience to parents. So, if you add parents to it, it just means the same thing. Just a longer version of the word, basically. This means lack of filial piety or disobedience to parents.

reading.explanation: The reading for 不孝 is the one you learned. Then, add 親's reading (vocab) to it.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The lawn grass is the lawn or the turf.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings, which you learned already!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Your lawn of life is just your lawn. Of course it's alive, otherwise it wouldn't be a very good lawn.

reading.explanation: The reading for 芝 is the one you learned with the kanji. The reading for 生 is one you haven't seen before (exception). It's ふ, and you can remember it by thinking how you were such a fool (ふ) for putting all that poison on it. Now it's dying, and now it's becoming less of a lawn.

meaning.explanation: The liver internal organ is your liver.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Though, it also means chutzpah or courage (besides just being liver). Maybe your liver is where your courage is.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: Your liver isn't doing great. You have cancer in your liver, so now they're giving you chemo (きも) to help get rid of that cancer.

meaning.explanation: A lodge where you will stay overnight is lodging. It is where you will stay the night.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You are mourning your fault. Because of your fault, you have gotten a loss and forfeit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. Mochi is mochi.

reading.explanation: If you know the meaning, you should be able to read this too. After all, mochi is mochi (もち)!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's the first two letters of the word mourning? It's mo (も). You can use that to remember.

meaning.explanation: The luck sack is a mystery bag. These are bags that are sold during the New Year's holiday. They contain various goods that are sold for a certain price. You don't know what's in them, but you know the minimum value of it at least. These are known as mystery sacks as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is 福 and 袋, put together. Also, watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: The country pattern is the pattern of things a country does. This is the national character of a nation.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. 国 is くに and 柄 is the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When it comes to nets, you gotta go talk to Amy (あみ) if you want a good one. Only Amy makes good nets.

meaning.explanation: One overnight is a one night's stay.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortened 一 and the rendaku in this one.

meaning.explanation: You know that 透明 is "transparency" or "transparent" - so, if something is not transparent, then it is opaque, making this word opacity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading you learned with the kanji is the same as the one used here. They're a pair, you know?

meaning.explanation: The fasten arcs are arcs that go around something to fasten these things all together. What are these things? They are (parentheses) and [brackets].

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Also, watch out from the shortening.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, you lucky duck. Follow that reading pattern to here, and you should be okay.

meaning.explanation: A person's pattern is the pattern of actions which they take to become who they are. What do they usually do? What is their pattern? This is the same as their personal character or personality.

reading.explanation: The readings are both kun'yomi readings, combined. For 人 you'll just have to remember this. With 柄 that's the reading you learned anyways, so that makes things easier. Just keep it consistent!

meaning.explanation: The philosophy study is the study of philosophy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You know that 携帯 means "portable" or "cell phone" or "mobile phone." And then 電話 means "telephone." This is basically just the longer version of simply saying 携帯, making this a portable phone or cell phone or mobile phone. It's sort of like the difference between saying "my cell" and "my cell phone," you dig?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the readings of 携帯 and 電話 for this one.

meaning.explanation: My challenge has made a departure and is being sent to the enemy. This challenge that I'm sending is a provocation to see if they'll take me up on my challenge.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you're going to abduct some noodles, make sure it's everybody's favorite noodles, ramen! The other meaning of the first kanji actually makes more sense here though, because you pull the dough to stretch it when you make ramen noodles. Choose whichever meaning helps you remember it best! This word is mostly written in kana, usually as ラーメン, but sometimes らーめん. You'll see the kanji version pretty often on packaging and menus, though, so it's worth knowing! The word is also occasionally written as らー麺 or ラー麺.

reading.explanation: Both of these kanji take the on'yomi, but the first one has a slightly irregular reading, because it's based on the modern Chinese reading. To remember that it's a long らー, just think how excited you are about these ramen! Raaaaaa! Raaaamen! So exciting!

meaning.explanation: When you leap and advance, you make rapid progress and great advancement. You might recall that 飛躍 also means "rapid progress," but what sets them apart? 躍進 emphasizes the subject's perspective as it advances at a rapid pace, whereas 飛躍 conveys significant progress or leaps more neutrally, without highlighting pace or perspective.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is rope so this word also refers to a rope. This can also mean a sumo champion's belt, though you'll probably see that meaning a lot less, unless you're a huge sumo fan.

reading.explanation: The reading used here is the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. So, put that knowledge in a sack and move on to the next item.

meaning.explanation: A sacrifice fly is a sacrifice fly. In baseball, this is when you hit the ball in the air so the runner can tag up and move up a base.

reading.explanation: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 飛 just think about how he (ひ) hit a sacrifice fly, and he hit it so hard the ball heated up.

meaning.explanation: Someone built from a small pattern has a small build. I know lots of little old ladies that were built from these small patterns.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of solid? It's solid, serious, upright, or hard. This word is often used in the figurative sense, as in a solid defence, a serious topic, or an upright person.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: If you can read this word, you may well know what it means. It's everybody's second favorite noodle dish, somen, or somen noodles, which are fine white noodles.

reading.explanation: The first kanji has a slightly irregular reading because it's prolonged. That's because somen are your soul (そう) food.

meaning.explanation: 最新 is, as you can probably guess, "the newest." So, the newest sharp thing, is the cutting edge. It is state of the art.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I write for purification. I do this purification writing in my study and den.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I want to take the whole and fasten it together. Take all the parts and put it together in a synthesis and recap of the information.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Temporarily determine something. That makes it tentative and temporary.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A dry lagoon is a tidal flat.

reading.explanation: The reading for 干 is an exceptional one. Just think to why the lagoon is dry. It's because of the heat (ひ) of the sun. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means char, but the verb version is to be burned or to get burned. You're not doing the burning, of course, but you're getting burned (owch!).

reading.explanation: The times where you were burned were mostly when you were a 子 (こ). That's because kids aren't good at working with hot things.

meaning.explanation: If 吹く is "to blow" and 出す is "to remove," then you are removing your blowing. You need to begin to blow to do that!

reading.explanation: The readings come from 吹く and 出す.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is wild and the verb is to be stormy or to be rough. If something is wild, like a storm or something, then it will be stormy and rough, after all.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: This is a combination of the words 透ける and 通る. Something that is transparent enough for things (like light) to pass through it is still going to be transparent, aka to be see-through.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already learned that 漬ける means "to pickle something." When it becomes 漬かる, it means the food has reached a state where the pickling or marinating process is complete, and it's ready to eat. So this word means to be well pickled or to be well marinated.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 漬ける, so you should be able to read this one too.

meaning.explanation: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and that 飛ばす is "To let fly." So, if you use your blowing to let something fly, you are going to blow away it.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 吹く and 飛ばす, put together.

meaning.explanation: You know that 吹く is "to blow" and the kanji 込 means into. So this word means to blow in or to breathe into, and it can be used both transitively and intransitively. It can also be used figuratively to mean to breathe into orto imbue, like breathing new life into something, or imbuing someone’s mind with hatred.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 吹く and the kanji 込む.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means challenge and the verb vocab version is to challenge someone.

reading.explanation: I don't (いど) just challenge anyone, but when I challenge someone, it's for real. My challenging reflexes come from my Id (いど), after all.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hoist. But most commonly (and most importantly), this word means to deep fry. I guess you can think of it as hoisting that delicious deep-fried food out of the oil. Of course, 揚げる can also mean to hoist (a sail) or to raise (a flag) depending on the context.

reading.explanation: Remember the other "to raise" vocabs? They are all あげる as well. For example, 上げる is あげる and 挙げる is あげる as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dig and the verb vocab version is to dig.

reading.explanation: If you are going to dig you are going to end up making a hole (ほ).

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dilute and the verb vocab version means to dilute or to water down.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 薄い, so if you know that you'll be able to read this too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means distract and the verb vocab version of this word is to distract and to divert.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to divert and to distract Maggie (まぎ).

meaning.explanation: You've seen 逃げる and 逃す. This one is 逃れる. This one simply means to escape. So that's not too bad. The difference between this one and the other escapes is that it has to do more with luck.

reading.explanation: This is the same reading you learned for 逃す, so you should be able to read this word as well.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grip and the verb vocab version is to grasp.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You go to grasp someone. You really need them. You are soooo needy (にぎ). Except, you can't really pronounce "d" sounds very well, so you say にぎ.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 逃げる means "to escape"? Well this verbs means to let go, to set free, or to let escape.

reading.explanation: You learned the に reading for this kanji when you learned 逃げる. If you have trouble telling the two words apart, remember that if you're going to let go of someone, make sure they have their knee guards (にが). It's a dangerous world, you can't have them running free without some extra protection, you know.

meaning.explanation: To 駆ける is "to gallop." 回る is "to revolve." So if you're galloping around in a revolving fashion, you are going to run around.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 駆ける and 回る.

meaning.explanation: 駆ける is "to gallop" and the kanji 込 means into. To gallop into a place is to rush into it. You can’t gallop slowly, after all. This can also mean to seek refuge, as in hurrying to a place for safety and support.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 駆ける and 込む.

meaning.explanation: 駆ける is "to gallop" and 出す is "to remove." So if you gallop out to remove yourself you are probably going to rush out a little fast. Calm down and slow down, man!

reading.explanation: The readings come from 駆ける and 出す.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and the verb vocab is to shake.

reading.explanation: If everything starts to shake what else will shake along with it? You (ゆ), of course.

meaning.explanation: The east lawn isn't some eastern lawn, it's in reference to the company Toshiba. Might be better to look at the reading first for this one.

reading.explanation: The readings come from the readings you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slippery and the verb vocab version is to slide or to slip.

reading.explanation: You're about to slip, and notice the floor is covered entirely in souvenirs (すべ)! Souvenirs of all shapes and sizes are scattered all over the floor, making it extremely easy to slide and slip.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means overnight and the verb vocab version is to stay the night.

reading.explanation: We are just going to stay tonight (と) and maybe tomorrow (と) night.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fasten and the verb vocab version is to fasten or to tie up or to tie together.

reading.explanation: You are fastening up the coocoo (くく) clock, so the coocoo bird doesn't come out anymore. That annoying coocoo bird.

meaning.explanation: You know that 口笛 is "whistling." So, if you're blowing your whistle you're going to whistle.

reading.explanation: The readings are of 口笛 and the reading you learned from 吹.

meaning.explanation: A mix of cars that pass through a net, that's a traffic network.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The rope pull. Both sides are pulling on the rope. That is a tug of war.

reading.explanation: The readings are from 綱 and 引く.

meaning.explanation: The pair of children are the same as each other. They're twins.

reading.explanation: The reading is like 二人, (the ふた part) plus 子, combined together. A little weird, but makes sense. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Two overnights is a two night's stay.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Unite something together and fasten it and you have unification or generalization. Nowadays this word is used to mean management in some contexts too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Every leap you take is a move filled with vibrancy. Your dynamic movement captures the essence of lively motion, captivating all who witness it. 躍動 is not just about movement, but also about expressing internal vitality or liveliness through movements or actions. It’s commonly used as 躍動感 (a lively feeling).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of wild? It's wild or rough.

reading.explanation: The reading is one of the readings you've learned from the kanji. The あら one.

meaning.explanation: The "side rope." This doesn't make much sense. What this is, though (you'll want to look at the reading), is the Yokozuna. This is the Sumo Grand Champion.

reading.explanation: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A sky attack is an air raid / air attack. Tora tora tora!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You learned another vocabulary word 札 as "amulet," but this is a special honorable amulet. It's a talisman.

reading.explanation: The reading for the 御 is お because ふだ uses the kun'yomi reading. Kun'yomi + kun'yomi = yes.

meaning.explanation: Your sphere might is the force you command over a sphere or ball… in this case, a baseball, making this a pitcher’s stuff.  If you’re not familiar with this baseball term, we recommend giving it a google. In short, it refers to a pitcher’s pitches, judged by how inherently hard those pitches are to hit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If a 原子 is an atom and a 炉 is a furnace, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an atomic reactor or nuclear reactor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You have rights and might over this area. That gives you authority.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This may look like a verb at first, but it's actually the adverb version of the adjective 凄い. When something is awful it's usually awfully awful.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A 軍艦 is a battleship, and 島 is an island. Welcome to... Battleship Island (go Jurassic Park music).

reading.explanation: This word uses the on'yomi readings for 軍 and 艦, and the kun'yomi reading for 島. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A high furnace is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a blast furnace.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The decision is split, causing a breakdown in all we've decided. A big ol' rupture.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the na-adjective version of bright. The word is bright or cheerful.

reading.explanation: Of all the people who are bright and cheerful, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk Hogan (ほが).

meaning.explanation: A bright bright is something that's bright.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned it when you learned 包む, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case: Remember how you wrap your bundles? That's right, with the two two technique. Your packages are always double wrapped.

meaning.explanation:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
This word covers a lot of meanings so it can be charm, taste, vibe, or even gist.

reading.explanation: If something has charm, your thought/思 (おも) goes in that direction/向き (むき). You feel the vibe? Do you get the gist?

meaning.explanation: I would like to enroll into this country. This is citizenship.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 慰謝 means "consolation?" Add fee to that and you get compensation. Or consolation money, depending on the situation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I show my consolation by apologizing. This is consolation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The tribute I offer is my contribution.

meaning.explanation: A reverse attack is a counterattack.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A water crystal is just a crystal. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A rare taste is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a delicacy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of delicious? It's delicious. It also means "skillful" and "clever" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?

reading.explanation: What's especially delicious? Horse (うま) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.

meaning.explanation: If you break and destroy something, that is destruction. That is annihilation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: Dew is just the earth's way of giving water to you (つゆ). Rain is too forceful, you may not go to the ocean or a lake, so the earth gives dew to you by putting it on the grass outside your house everyday!

meaning.explanation: Dignity is a strict thing. If you’re too lenient, you’ll lose all your dignity and majesty.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I will chastise you and give you penalty. I do this as a discipline. A punishment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Using violence I'm going to expose the truth! This is disclosure. This is exposure. This word carries the connotation of something scandalous being revealed, often in a dramatic manner.

reading.explanation: The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step back (ばく) to deal with the new information.

meaning.explanation: The illusion is destroyed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is disillusionment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The distance that is detached from the distance is the distance and range. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Destroy to death. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your downfall and ruin.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: In order to use a house counter in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find eaves. And all those eaves together stand in a row.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  These houses that stand in a row are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have no key (のき). With no key, those eaves are just there for you to look at.

meaning.explanation: Seal in the cylinder. This cylinder that is sealed in is an envelope. You just have to think back to the day, when things were more like in scroll form. So, a scroll's envelope would have been shaped like a cylinder, making this an envelope.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When what you expose is exited out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is exposure. It can also refer to photographic exposure too, in case you were wondering.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Slap that bug and destroy it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is extermination.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Extinction where everything is destroyed is extinction.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A fake thing is fake or counterfeit.

reading.explanation: You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.

meaning.explanation: Ah yes, wet clothes must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for false accusations. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.

reading.explanation: This word is made up of the reading from 濡れる and the rendaku version of the きぬ reading of 衣. You learned this reading in the 衣 vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "give new (ぎぬ) clothes to me!"

meaning.explanation: Enroll your door... and by door, I mean enroll your family, because each family has one door to their house. Enrolling your family means you are enrolling them into the family register. This is actually an interesting topic. Look up "koseki" in Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.

reading.explanation: The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of 子 (こ).

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that for the word fence in Japanese, フェンス is typically used. 垣 isn't very common but it's sometimes used in literature.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: You know that 主義 is "-ism." Add that onto an ism that is building a seal(ed) in system, and you have feudalism. Why? Because with feudalism, power is sealed in with one group or one family. Nobody else can get in (until they are overthrown, anyways), making this feudalism.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A warm furnace is a furnace for warming you and other things. This is a fireplace or hearth or even a stove.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I'm going to expose my bones for a second here and be blunt with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Things that chafe and rub have lots of friction.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Being courteous is the right idea if you want to be on friendly terms with others. The more courteous you are to someone (and vice versa), the more a sense of closeness grows between you. 懇意 formally describes being on good, cordial terms with someone. You might talk about a colleague you've become friendly with (懇意になった同僚) or a professor who treats you warmly (懇意にしてくれる教授), for example.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A courteous talk is a friendly talk. We all know that "friendly talks" are never what they seem, though... right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A courteous parent is a parent who knows when a kid needs a friend. Then, they set their kid up with you so that you can have a friendship. What a nice parent the other person is!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A gentle and peaceful person is gentle and tender. 柔和 is commonly used in literature to describe someone whose nature or features express gentleness.

reading.explanation: You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to be gentle and tender if you want to touch something that's new (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs that gentleness.
