meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of gentle? It's gentle... but in this word's case, it's also flexible, soft, and tender.

reading.explanation: You find something that is so gentle and soft to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "Yah what (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "Yah, what can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.

meaning.explanation: The point of something is the gist and principle of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's gist as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as むね.

meaning.explanation: A bright news report is going to be one full of good news. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A hedge (or fence) root is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a hedge or a fence.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With 垣 that's the one you learned and with 根 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A full tide is a high tide or full tide. That's when the water comes up.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If something's got charm and is to your taste, then it's your hobby. Hobbies are activities that you find charming and develop a taste for.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you see 即 before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is immediate or instant.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An instant sit is immediate. It's also instantaneous. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It's instantly effective! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means immediate effect or instant effect.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

meaning.explanation: An instant interest in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some improvisation, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of そく.

meaning.explanation: The に on the end of this word turns sincerity into an adverb. What's the adverb version of sincerity? It's sincerely, or indeed. It really is.

reading.explanation: This shares the same reading as the vocabulary word 誠, but here's a reminder just in case: My coat (まこと) really is a coat! Indeed, it is.

meaning.explanation: A fluid crystal is a liquid crystal.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A pasture place is a livestock farm. It's also a ranch. The place where things pasture is this place.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The parts we need. The point of that. That is the main point. That is the essentials. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A bog rice paddy is a marshy rice field. This is just a rice paddy in marshy form.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Nourishing and fostering. The thing that gives you this is nourishment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The furnace heart is the heart of the furnace. The heart of this particular furnace, the one we're talking about here, is the nuclear reactor core.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A pasture teacher is one who leads his flock around through life. This is a pastor, minister, or clergyman.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The pasture grass is the pasture and grass.

reading.explanation: With 草 you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this pasture you have to constantly sew (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.

meaning.explanation: A pasture field is pasture land. It's also a ranch.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"

meaning.explanation: The best consolation for someone's problem is paying a sympathy call. It is consolation through a sympathy visit. 慰問 is a formal way of saying お見舞い (sympathy visit). It's often used when someone notable, like a celebrity or politician, makes a visit to offer support and comfort to people in difficult situations, like hospital patients, nursing home residents, or those affected by disasters.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Relax in peace. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly peace. You feel security too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You'll see this used to mean pipe more often than cylinder, though.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to pipes, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a two two (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.

meaning.explanation: The point to my theory is the point of an argument. That's what I'm trying to say in my theory / argument, man!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: With a seal we're printing everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this printing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of rare? It's rare. But, this can also mean unusual or curious (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something).

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You know what's unusual and rare? This maze is rare (めずら). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!

meaning.explanation: The instant day is the day that's going on this instant. It's the same day as now.

reading.explanation: The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the truth (じつ) is that it's the same day today.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is seal in, but the vocab noun version is seal. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with).

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a fool, make sure you seal your envelopes.

meaning.explanation: A seal in writing is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a sealed letter.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: At one moment it happened simultaneously. It was simultaneous. It was all at once.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of 一.

meaning.explanation: You have consolation so now you can relax. What a great feeling this is. You now have solace and relaxation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Things get divided and split. We can just call this a split or division. 分裂 primarily refers to cells dividing in biology, but it can also figuratively describe an entity or group splitting into separate parts, often due to internal conflict.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sink and stagnate. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of stagnation and inactivity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A stone hedge is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a stone wall.

reading.explanation: The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.

meaning.explanation: An exposed shop is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a street stall.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mutual slap is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is sumo wrestling.

reading.explanation: The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's すもう.

meaning.explanation: An odd attack is an attack you don't expect. This is a surprise attack.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A bog swamp is a swamp or marsh.

reading.explanation: Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular swamp, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the Shogun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.

meaning.explanation: A tides stream is the stream going through the tide. It's the tide or the tidal current.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of salt (しお).

meaning.explanation: The wind tide is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the tide and current. These days, we usually use this word for the current trends that come in like the tide.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Take your dignity and stretch it. Your dignity is so stretched! That makes you feel big! That's why this word is to act big or to be arrogant.

reading.explanation: The reading is from 威 and 張る.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means attack and the verb vocab version is to attack.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going to attack me or something? Oh so scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb. The kanji means hoist, but the verb most commonly means to be fried up, ready to eat. Imagine something being hoisted up onto the table because it's fried and ready to eat. The verb can also mean, more logically, to be up.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 揚げる.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consolation and the verb vocab version is to console.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going to console you for what happened to you. The nag saw (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy and the verb vocab version is to destroy and to annihilate.

reading.explanation: You are going to destroy the hoe roe. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.

meaning.explanation: Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!

reading.explanation: The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small 村 (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means conceal, but as a verb, this word means to go under or to pass through. Most commonly, this word means to dive underwater or to go underground. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you!

reading.explanation: 潜る has two possible readings: もぐる and くぐる. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on もぐる, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get mo' goo (もぐ) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?

meaning.explanation: The kanji means chastise but the verb vocab version is to learn by experience. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).

reading.explanation: As a child (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means printing so the verb vocab version is to print.

reading.explanation: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to sue (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.  This is an intransitive verb, so it refers to something sinking on its own. You didn't do anything to make it sink. You know this is when something is just sinking on its own (you didn't sink it), because of the む, which shows it's a cow sinking. The cow stepped into some quicksand and now it's sinking, not because of you.

reading.explanation: You look at the cow. Poor cow. She's (しず) sinking.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means split, but if you split something, you are going to tear it or to rip up it.

reading.explanation: In order to get it open, you need to tear and rip up a sack (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

meaning.explanation: When you open something sealed, you're unsealing it or breaking a seal. 開封 generally refers to opening something sealed, like opening a letter or package.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something rare is often unusual. This word could also mean rare (of course) and peculiar depending on the context. These days, media often uses this word to describe the way something is unusual, quirky, and funny.

reading.explanation: The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too rare, wouldn't you say?

meaning.explanation: A challenge (挑戦) someone is someone who is going to challenge you. They are a challenger.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Line up house counters and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same across the board. It also turns them into a row of houses.

reading.explanation: This is a combination of the words 軒 and 並 that you've already learned, so you should be able to read this word too. Just note that for 並, the み in なみ is sticking out! While you might sometimes see this written 軒並, 軒並み is way more common.

meaning.explanation: One wing is just a part of the bird or plane it's attached to. But that one wing plays a role that's very important! This word usually comes up in the phrase 〜の一翼を担う (to play a part in…).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you help with your power, you are providing assistance and support. Note that this is a formal word that’s mostly used in professional situations. It implies that someone has done something substantial for you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since 力 has two on'yomi readings, here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: You really need some assistance with this lock (りょく). You are certain that world peace and eternal happiness lie behind this one lock. But no one is willing to support you in opening it. What a cruel world.

meaning.explanation: A sleep bed is where you sleep. Where do you sleep? In a bed or a crib. Side note, if you're a baby sleeping in a crib, you must really want to learn kanji.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn the second kun'yomi reading for 床. You take とこ and rendaku it into どこ. How do you remember this? Just think about your bed. Then wonder, "where (どこ) is it?"

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But it also has a secondary reading you haven't learned, so here’s a mnemonic for it: Blade in hand, you charge at your foes hollering "Yah! Eee! Baa!" (やいば). As the blade cuts through them, you cry "Yah! Eee! Baa!" even louder. This battle cry always fuels your fury and doubles the force of your swinging blade. "Yah! Eee! Baa!" While both readings relate to blades, they have slightly different uses. は is used for any cutting tool's blade or edge, whereas やいば is a little old-fashioned and specifically refers to the blades of swords or knives, often in literary contexts.

meaning.explanation: Gold hair is blonde hair. Makes sense!

reading.explanation: The reading for 髪 isn't the one you learned. It's actually はつ, but it's getting rendaku'd here. So, to remember the reading of it for this word, just think about how if you were blonde, you'd wear many hats (はつ) to hide it. I have no idea why you'd hide it, but you can come up with a compelling reason that makes sense to you.

meaning.explanation: Both wings are both wings! There are two and you have them all!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A can coffee (コーヒー) is coffee that's in a can. That's canned coffee or can coffee.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A big cannon is... wait for it... just a cannon. I guess all cannons are big, right? At least when you compare them to guns.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You know how 携帯 refers to a mobile phone? This is a strap (ストラップ) for a mobile phone, making this a cell phone strap or mobile phone strap.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the reading of 携帯.

meaning.explanation: You're free to choose and select any of these limbs, leaving you many choices. With all these options and alternatives, which one will you go for?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji is distract and the adjective version is confusing or misleading.

reading.explanation: You know who is particularly confusing? That maggie (まぎ) girl. She's confusing because she uses magic (まぎ). Think of a Maggie you know, if possible.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The pipe control tower is the tower that controls all the pipes... think of the pipes not as pipes, but as directions things are moving in. You're controlling all of that on a map, and the pipe shows where everything is going and you're changing it to be where it needs to go. You are in the control tower.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: For the sake of exchange! What sounds so glorious is really just currency exchange.

reading.explanation: You need to do a bunch of currency exchange for your newest investment: car wash celery (かわせ)! Why of course, it's celery that's stored, cleaned, and… smoked inside of a car wash. So go get all the currency you have, we have some exchanging to do.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 揚げる means "to deep fry"? This is the prefix or suffix version of that word, making it deep-fried... Note that 揚げ can sometimes be used as a standalone word, in which case it usually refers to deep-fried tofu.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 揚げる as well.

meaning.explanation: Before you take the last measurement, you know you're on the brink of something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

meaning.explanation: You are alone in what you are able to create. Nobody else can create like you. So what you create is your own original creation. 独創 refers to the act of creating something original, or the resulting creation itself. This word is quite formal, and generally used as 独創的 (original) or 独創性 (originality).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You know that 泊まる is "to stay the night." The noun version is a overnight stay or sleepover.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 泊まる, so pull from that and you shall know this.

meaning.explanation: A grain's child is even smaller than a grain. It's a particle, sometimes even an atomic particle.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A peach color is a peach color, or pink.

reading.explanation: The readings come from the vocab readings (and kanji readings, actually) of the two kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A philosophy scholar (学者) is someone who studies philosophy. They're known as a philosopher.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 滑る is "to slide"? Then, how 台 is a counter for machines? In this case, this slippery machine is a slide, more specifically a playground slide.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 滑る and 台.

meaning.explanation: Recreation and comfort are things you do for pleasure and amusement. So nice!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The princess (formal name ender) is the princess, and you're talking to her politely. She is the princess.

reading.explanation: The reading is the reading of 姫 and 様 combined together.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be used to refer to a noble girl as well, as in a girl of the noble family.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A vermilion colored seal is a red seal. Just look up the (Japanese) word in Google Image search and you'll see what this is.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A riddle riddle is a riddle, and it's also a puzzle or an enigma.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The right wing is the right wing. As in, "right wing politics" or "right wing beliefs."

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 右, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Those in the right wing love eating uni (う), not because they like the taste, but because uni is expensive. Picture some right-wing people in your mind right now and watch as they try really hard to pretend they like eating uni as they shovel buckets of it down their throats.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the meaning and the reading of the kanji: さむらい.

meaning.explanation: A sand hill is a sand dune.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A netting door is a screen door. Makes sense, right? Screen doors are like little meshy nets made into a door shape.

reading.explanation: You've seen 網 on its own. We're going to use that reading. Then, add the 戸 reading with rendaku and you have yourself あみど.

meaning.explanation: Earth and sand is earth and sand, or sediment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word and it uses the on'yomi for both kanji. This on'yomi for 砂 is a bit less common, and you haven't learnt it yet, so here's a mnemnonic to help you: If there's too much sediment, you need to speak to a shaman (しゃ) about it. Only a shaman has the power to get rid of all that earth and sand and get the river flowing again.

meaning.explanation: You know that 堅い is "solid" or "tough." When your hand is solid and tough, it's solid and steady. If your hand is shaky, it's the opposite, or something.

reading.explanation: The reading is the two words 手 and 堅い combined together. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A wild wave will make for some stormy seas or raging waves. Don't go out in these kinds of waves.

reading.explanation: The readings come from the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, 荒 (the secondary reading you learned with this kanji) and 波 (just the vocab version).

meaning.explanation: This measurement also refers to a specific measurement, a "sun", which is about 3.03 centimeters. You'll hear it brought up from time to time to measure things, though usually with more traditional Japanese items.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji! Congrats! Now to remember it's three point zero three centimeters.

meaning.explanation: The feeling of teardrops is a feeling that makes you cry. But it's not a bad feeling because these are tears of gratitude, or because you're being moved to tears. 感涙 is an advanced word primarily used in writing. It refers to the kind of tears you might shed when you're profoundly touched with emotion, like when you're truly grateful for something or moved by a song or movie.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 涙 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Your excessive tears of gratitude have ruined (るい) your life. Your friends didn't like being cried at for the smallest compliment or favor, so now they don't even return your calls. No one else you know is being moved to tears on a daily basis like this. It's ruining your life!

meaning.explanation: What can you see in the north that looks like a ladle and is made up of seven stars? That's the group of stars we call the Big Dipper or, depending on where you are in the world, perhaps the Plough.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: To remember the reading think about thunder. Back in the day, it was probably terrifyingly loud. Like the cry of the gods! Wait a sec, the "cry of the gods" would be 神鳴り (かみなり).

meaning.explanation: Thunder that falls from the sky is a thunderbolt.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A thunder rain is a rain that's coming with thunder. For all intents and purposes, if you see this, you'll think thunderstorm.

reading.explanation: The reading is the on'yomi readings. For 雨, you learned it with 雨天. So you should be able to put them together!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It also just sounds like can.

meaning.explanation: You know that 紛らす means "to divert" or "to distract." This is when you're not doing the action, now, making this word to be diverted or to be distracted.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 紛らす.

meaning.explanation: Remember 揺る which means "to shake" or "to jolt"? This is like that, but now you're not doing the shaking and jolting, making it to be shaken or to be jolted. You know this because it's really rare (れる) for you to be shaken like this.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 揺る.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means split, so this verb has to do with something splitting.  This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to be split, to be torn, or to burst apart.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 裂く.

meaning.explanation: You know that 焦げる is "to be burned" or "to get burned." This word however is when you're doing the burning, making it to burn or to scorch. You know this because when it comes to burning, you pull out all the stops. You use lots of gas (がす) to burn whatever it is you burn.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 焦げる, so if you know that you know this word as well.

meaning.explanation: 克服 is "conquest" so the verb version of that is to conquer.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure so the verb vocab version is to endure.

reading.explanation: Those who are able to endure are those who have had a lot of training. Who has had the most training of anyone? Ninjas. What group are they part of? The shinobi (しの).

meaning.explanation: The thing you want to take has escaped. Meaning you failed to catch this thing. This word is to fail to catch.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 取る and 逃がす.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means fishing so the verb vocab version is to fish.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: 荒れる is "to be stormy" or "to be rough." This is when you do the stormy rough things. You go wild on everyone, trying to lay waste and to devastate everything around you.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 荒れる.

meaning.explanation: 逃す is "to let go" or "to let escape." If something escapes your seeing, then you are going to overlook it.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 見 and 逃す.

meaning.explanation: A dragon scroll is a dragon that's shaped kind of like a scroll, spinning around. This is a tornado.

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. For 竜 just think about how it's a standing (立つ) dragon, because it would have to be if it's a tornado. Your まき reading comes from 巻く, but the kana is pushed into the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Fish thunder is underwater thunder that shoots at things and are kind of shaped like fish. That's a torpedo. Load the fish thunder!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scold and the verb vocab version also means to scold.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Shake plus "to do" is the verb version of shake. That's to shake or to rock slowly.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 揺る.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake so the verb vocab version is to shake.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 揺る.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shout so the verb vocab version is to shout. Can also be to scream.

reading.explanation: To remember the reading of this, just think about how you start to shout and to scream when you drink way too much sake (さけ).

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sink so the verb vocab version is to sink.  This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you're sinking something else. You can differentiate it from the intransitive 沈む by imaging that you're watching an enemy ship sink, and they shout out, "Who did this to me!" You respond, me (め). I did."

reading.explanation: When you sink something, like a battleship, you go on and say: "she's (しず) sunk, I sunk her." That's like your tagline, or something. You say it for some reason because you think it's cool.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be a pagoda. If you think about it, pagodas were the towers of the olden days.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: バベル's 塔 is Babel's tower. That's the Tower of Babel.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the reading of the kanji.

meaning.explanation: If something has a nothing edge, it's probably unrelated to what you're doing. There's no edge, your stuff always has edges.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can also say it's scarlet red or blood as well, though more in a poetic sense, I'd say. I don't think you'll hear surgeons calling blood 朱.

reading.explanation: The reading あけ is like the beginning of 開ける, which means "to open." Just imagine you're opening (あけ) a person up, and out gushes a vermilion colored blood. You shouldn't open people up like that.

meaning.explanation: 荒い is rough. Double that to 荒々しい and you have the same thing: wild or rough.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 荒い. Since you already know that 々 means it repeats, you already know this reading!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: In each political wing there are two bosses (つばさ). It's a weird system, but that's how they're doing it these days. Imagine your favorite / least favorite political wings, all with two bosses, arguing with each other.

meaning.explanation: Something that is obsolete will end in extinction. Join in the calls for its abolition, elimination and extinction, whatever it is.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: いつ is "when" and 頃 is "about." Combine those together and you have "about when?" or "how soon?"

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, just rendaku'd.

meaning.explanation: A warn bell is a bell that goes off when you need to be warned about something. This is usually an alarm bell or a fire bell.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The year approximate is your approximate age. This is also an indirect way to refer to adolescence, and when people reach marriageable age!

reading.explanation: The reading is the reading of the vocab version of 年 plus 頃, put together. Note: You will also sometimes see this written partially in kana like 年ごろ.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. When used as a suffix, it means approximate time and around (as in "around 3:00").

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Bear in mind that it's pronounced ころ when it's a noun, but it's usually ごろ when it's a suffix, though some people say ころ in both cases.

meaning.explanation: A villain who is bad is the most atrocious and fiendish villain of them all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A thin bacteria is... well... a bacteria. I guess all bacteria are really thin. So thin you can't see them with your naked eye, in fact.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

meaning.explanation: An electricity table is a calculator. Why is this? You can think about it in a couple of different ways. Maybe in the past, a calculator (aka abacus) would take up a whole table, making this "electric" version a calculator. Or, maybe it can be used to solve tables. Wrong kind of table, but should help you to remember the meaning of this word.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: When looking at a calendar, the 子読み (こよみ) of it is to... well... not be able to read it at all. Because, children can't really read. So, when you look at a calendar you have to explain it to a child, since they cannot read it.

meaning.explanation: A ghost garden is where many ghosts are harvested and where many ghosts grow. This is a cemetery.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The West's calendar shows the history and time period of "The West." To the Japanese and Chinese, this era is known as the Christian Era. It also used to be used as a way to refer to the Western Calendar, though we usually just say カレンダー nowadays.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The noun version of cloudy is cloudy weather or cloudiness. In some cases, this can also refer to the type of fog you'd find on a window or your glasses. Despite being a noun in Japanese, you'll actually see this translated as the adjective "cloudy" in English a lot. Don't let that fool you, though, it still behaves as a noun in Japanese! It's just another example of word types not quite matching up between English and Japanese.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Stiff freight always has to be paid for in coins, because coins are also stiff. You can't go paying for something stiff with something not stiff, that would make no sense at all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You're all naked, which makes you completely naked or totally naked.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It's possible that it's considerably considerable. It's considerably, fairly, and quite... something. Also please note that this is almost always written in kana and not kanji. But, we're learning kanji here, so gosh darn it we're going to learn some kanji.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned in the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 学生 is "student"? This plays off that. A cram school "student" is a student of a cram school, a cram school student.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Despite looking like an adjective this is a noun. It means the same thing as the kanji: curse.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A villain vessel is a vessel used by a villain. This vessel holds bullets, and is a dangerous weapon.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An eating table is a dining table.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already know that emitted water means "drainage." Add gutter to that and this becomes a drainage in the sense of a drainage ditch or gutter. When it comes to the drain in your sink or bathtub, you can use 排水口, which has the same pronunciation but a different kanji.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 戸籍 is the family register? This is referring to that, and that makes this word mean entry in family register.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An evil ghost isn't so much a ghost as it is an evil spirit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note this uses the secondary 霊 reading of りょう, so imagine an evil spirit rowing a boat.

meaning.explanation: A "ばい" bacteria is a germ. In case you're wondering, the ばい is referring to the kanji 黴, but people don't usually write that part.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A deceased ghost is a ghost (all ghosts are deceased). Can also refer to "the dead."

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A shade energy is a shady feeling. It's a feeling of gloom and melancholy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Bird skin is goosebumps. Makes sense, since a goose is a bird and a bird's skin is bumpy.

reading.explanation: The reading is the individual vocab readings of the two kanji, 鳥 and 肌.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What goes in the gutter? 水. But, the reading isn't exactly right. It's みぞnot みず, but close enough to create a hook.

meaning.explanation: If you're half naked you're half nude or half naked.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though you'll want to know that this refers most specifically to human skin.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: An "add dampness container" is a container that adds dampness to the air. That's a humidifier.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A hunt person is a person who hunts. A hunter.

reading.explanation: You learned the reading of 狩 when you learned the kanji, but the reading for 人 is totally irregular. Just imagine that you're hunting a reindeer named Rudolph (りゅうど). He has an unusually red nose, which makes him easy to spot and puts him at a bit of a disadvantage.

meaning.explanation: You have the noun version of hunt. That is hunting.

reading.explanation: The reading uses the reading from the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A ghost feeling is inspiration. For some reason, the feeling of ghosts is the feeling of inspiration. I guess a ghost goes inside you and makes you feel this inspiration? Oh, wait, you can feel that because you have the sixth sense.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The black tide isn't what you think, most likely. This is the Japan current, aka the Kuroshio Current. It's a Northern flowing current on the West side of the Pacific Ocean. Have you heard of the Gulf Stream? It's kind of like that.

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi readings of the two kanji, put together. 黒 and 潮.

meaning.explanation: The near approximate is the approximate time that was near to you. This period of time is the lately period of time. It's recently.

reading.explanation: The reading is 近い and 頃 put together.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 足, which also means leg and foot.

meaning.explanation: What happens when light travels a year? You have a light-year.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A far distance detachment is a distance that is far. It is long distance. Also remember that 距離 is a "distance" so a far distance is a long distance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are the same, so this can mean lump, mass, or bundle. Additionally, this can also refer to being the embodiment of something. When somebody or something is a mass or bundle of some attribute or trait, they might as well be the embodiment of it!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Recognize this word? Na naaa na na na na na na naaa ♬.

meaning.explanation: The former calendar is the calendar from before. It's the lunisolar calendar and the traditional Japanese calendar. Certainly not the current calendar, anyways.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Lunatic energy is madness and insanity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I'm offering to stand up and announce what's on the menu for today. I'll tell everyone about today's meal plan. This word doesn't mean the kind of physical menu you see in a restaurant, but rather a menu, or meal plan, in the sense of the foods you're planning to eat.

reading.explanation: You didn't learn this reading for 献 with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm actually announcing the menu for condors (こん). You thought I was going to tell you what's on the menu for humans? No no, that's a surprise. Condors need a heads-up for these things, because meals are extremely important to condors, given their size and everything.

meaning.explanation: When you control your hand an approximate amount, you are going to be a very moderate and reasonable person.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A damp energy is a feeling of dampness. It is moisture and humidity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just be careful of the shortening, and the irregular reading for 気.

meaning.explanation: The mountain peaks are just the mountains. Just because you can only see the peaks doesn't mean the rest of the mountain doesn't exist.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: You are naked now. You used to wear a car, but you don't have it anymore (and you're not wearing it). You had a car (はだか), but now you don't have a car. That's what you'll explain when someone asks you why you're naked.

meaning.explanation: 分裂 means "split" or "division." The nucleus version of this split is nuclear fission.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An ocean gutter is an ocean trench.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The young approximate is the approximate age of when you were young. This, approximately, is one's youth or early life.

reading.explanation: The reading is 若い and 頃 combined into one.

meaning.explanation: A small bundle is merely a package. Something big would be a big package, I guess.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 小 (which is a reading you've seen a couple times now, I'm sure) and 包み, with the み pushed inside the package. Beware of the somewhat weird rendaku. You don't see づ too often.

meaning.explanation: A polish is a polish or even a shine.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A righteousness cram school is, for some reason, a private school. Maybe because they don't think the public cram schools are any good, so they take their righteousness somewhere else to start a private one? I'm not sure. You may have seen the abbreviation 私学 (for 私立学校) as another word for private school. 私学 is typically used for any schools, elementary through university, that are run by individuals or private groups. 義塾 instead generally describes private schools founded during the Edo and Meiji periods. In contemporary Japanese, it's not really used on its own but can be seen in school names like 明徳義塾高等学校 (Meitoku Gijuku High School).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You stare at hope. It looks good. That is your prospect and view, as you stare at hope.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A waterfall river is a river that's moving like a waterfall! Fast and furious! Water that moves like this are rapids.

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab reading of each kanji: 滝 and 川. Careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: The previous approximate was the previous approximate time, which is recently or the other day.

reading.explanation: The reading is the kun'yomi vocab readings of the two kanji. That's 先 and 頃 (the reading you learned) put together. The 頃 is the rendaku'd version, ごろ so be careful.

meaning.explanation: This (この) approximate is this approximate time. It is recently or nowadays or these days.

reading.explanation: The reading is the 頃 reading from the kanji reading. Be careful, it's the rendaku'd form.

meaning.explanation: The origin villain is the villain who's running everything. They're the person responsible for the villainy going on. They are the ringleader or main culprit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A leg book is just the legs of a book. Not a whole book. It only contains the parts that walk around and move, not so much the descriptions (things that don't move). This kind of book is a script or screenplay. These "books" are focused on actions and things people say, which is why it's just the legs.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Also means shadow.

reading.explanation: Look at a shadow. It's long, surprisingly long. It's in the shape of a cage (かげ), because that's what is producing the long shadow. Check out each bar of the cage. Maybe you're inside the cage? Whatever is going on, a long shadow is being created by the cage and shade.

meaning.explanation: A 距離 is a distance and 近 is near. A near distance is a short distance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A 距離 (distance) that is short is a short distance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 一斉 is simultaneous or all at once. Add the に in there and you're heading towards those things. For "simultaneous" that becomes simultaneously. For "all at once" it stays at all at once.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 一斉.

meaning.explanation: Skin color is skin color, or skin tone. This word originally referred to a pale orange or peach color, and sometimes you'll still see it used that way. But labeling that as 肌色 wasn't inclusive of all skin tones. Now, it simply refers to skin color in general.

reading.explanation: The readings are the vocab kun'yomi readings of each kanji, 肌 and 色 combined into one.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Look inside your soul. You see all the bits and bobs that make up your soul rolling around and around, being pushed by the Katamari Tamashii (たましい). He keeps your soul nice and big and safe!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The person who's holding the spear is a little hoe 子. It's a child who learned to fight with a hoe, and he's turned the hoe into a spear to fight with. Imagine him swinging his hoe spear around like a little dork.

meaning.explanation: When attached to a word, this refers to a ____ spirit. It's the same meaning as the kanji, too.

reading.explanation: This word is made up of a single kanji, but it uses the on'yomi reading, not the kun'yomi reading. Luckily, you've learned this reading already. Yay!

meaning.explanation: If you kill bacteria you are performing sterilization. You're killing those bacteria.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

meaning.explanation: Someplace with nothing amounts of bacteria is sterilized and aseptic.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of stiff? It's stiff, hard, or firm.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as a very similar word, 固い. So, if you can use that word to help you to remember, you'll remember the reading of this word in no time as well!

meaning.explanation: A stiff fix is when you fix something to be stiff, which leads to stiffness or stiffening.  硬直 commonly describes a person's body becoming stiff in response to stimuli such as discomfort or shock, or after death.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Table sphere is a sport where you have a table and then you use a sphere on it. That's table tennis or ping pong. Makes sense, right? You use a ping pong ball and you play on a table.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of たく's shortening.

meaning.explanation: The skin touch is the feeling of touching with your skin. That is the touch of, feel of, or texture of something. It's what you feel when you touch your skin to something!

reading.explanation: The reading is 肌 plus 触る's reading, combined. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: The tide time is the tidal hour. This word is often used figuratively, as in “the perfect time to act”, especially in reference to quitting something or backing away from a situation.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the individual words, 潮 and 時. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 襲撃 is an assault or attack? This is the verb form, so it's to attack or to assault.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something with lucidity is clear. That's why this word is to become clear or to become transparent.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading when you learned the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means damp so the verb vocab version is to be damp or to be moist. Ewww.

reading.explanation: You know what's really damp and moist? Sheep men (しめ) are. They've been hanging out in a greenhouse and now their wool is all damp. They're going to need a towel to dry off.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means destroy so the verb vocab version is to be destroyed. You know you're not destroying things because of the beer (びる). You'd never destroy beer... but someone else might. Grrr.

reading.explanation: "THE HORROR!" (ほろ) you cry, as your beer is about to be destroyed.

meaning.explanation: This is a bit of a weird word. The kanji is char, and a previous word you learned (焦げる) is "to be burned." This, on the other hand, is "to be in a hurry" or "to be impatient." I guess if you're getting burned or have that feeling, you're going to be in a hurry and you're going to be impatient. You can tell that this is that word because it only has one kana, る, which stands for rude. You're feeling someone is being rude (or maybe you are), which is why you have this feeling of impatience and hurrying.

reading.explanation: You're being rude, but you're also being a big ass (あせ) with your impatience.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means curse, and the verb version is to curse or to put a curse on.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means earnings and the verb vocab version is to earn income, because you can't "to income" something. Can also be to make money.

reading.explanation: To earn income, you decided to start a car sale. (かせ) "Every car sale, a step to richness!" was your quirky business mantra.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means fly, so the verb version means to fly.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading already! You should be able to read this too!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means gamble and the verb vocab version is to gamble.

reading.explanation: The reading is the reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cloudy and the verb vocab version means to get cloudy or to become cloudy.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. It also happens to be the same as 雲, which has a very similar meaning (clouds).

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lunatic or crazy. The verb version of this is to go mad (you don't really "go lunatic" now, do you?) or to go crazy.

reading.explanation: To remember the reading, just think about how when you go crazy, you are coming (来る) to crazy town. Just imagine some voice beckoning you to come. Come here! Please come here! Come to crazy town! Give in to the voices!

meaning.explanation: 泊まる is "to stay the night." Now you're letting someone else stay the night, which makes this to let someone stay over or to let someone stay the night.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 泊まる.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bride and the verb vocab version is to marry, because you can't really "to bride" someone. 嫁ぐ is often used when describing how someone has or is going to marry into another family.

reading.explanation: Imagine you're getting married to a valley girl. You're all like. Hey, I'm gonna marry you! And she's all like Tots (とつ), we gonna get, like, married! Imagine her saying more "tots" things (tots = short for totally in valley girl speak, at least in my imagination).

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means polish and the verb vocab version is to polish or, strangely specifically (and we'll learn an even more specific word for this later) to brush your teeth.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rub and this verb means to rub or to scrub.

reading.explanation:
If you're going to rub me like that, I'm going to sue (す) you. It's making me very uncomfortable. The cost (こす) of your rubbing actions will be high.

So this word has two readings and both mean “to rub.” But you usually use する for a single action, such as lighting a match or grazing your knee, while こする means doing it repeatedly, like when you’re cleaning or polishing something.

meaning.explanation: Everything we're doing is to serve you, you know. This verb is a bit archaic and therefore has a formal feel to it. It's used to talk about serving emperors, kings, and gods, among others.

reading.explanation: To serve you well, we've gotten ourselves two cars (つか). If one breaks down, we can still serve you with the other car.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stare and the verb vocab version is to stare at (or to look at in a very staringish way).

reading.explanation: To learn the reading, just think about how you're looking at something for a lonnnnng time if you're staring at it. In Japanese the word "long" is 長い, and guess what the reading of the kanji part is? It's なが, just like ながめる's kanji-part reading.

meaning.explanation: You know that 裂く is "to tear" or "to rip up." So, if you're trying to tear or rip up something, and you're pulling it at the same time, you are going to tear up that thing, or more accurately perhaps to tear off something, since you're pulling.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 引く and 裂く.

meaning.explanation: As usual, you can guess this is a verb thanks to the う sound on the end. The kanji means frustration, and unfortunately frustration tends to torment people. This verb is pretty advanced, but still useful to know!

reading.explanation: We all know it's not okay to to torment each other. So how about we all sign a (さいな) contract saying that we'll never torment anyone ever again?

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The damp earth is where water seems to congregate, but not so much that there's a lake or ocean or anything like that. Just damp. This is a wetlands.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A 包み is a bundle or package, and 紙 is paper. What paper goes around bundles and packages? That would be wrapping paper.

reading.explanation: The reading is 包み and 紙 combined together. Be careful of rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A blink is a blink and a wink as well, depending on how many eyes you use.

reading.explanation: A wink is all it takes to get the "Ma butter" (まばた) from the store. It's hidden, and they only bring it out if you do the wink.

meaning.explanation: Energy bubbles are bubbles filled with the "energy" that's all around us (air). That's why this is an air bubble.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Tempering gold is a technique so magical that we can consider it to be alchemy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A blink interval of time is a very short period of time. It's an instant or a moment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: One blink is one instant. That is an instant or a moment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Every time a government is years older, it calculates the money that has entered its coffers. This is the annual revenue received by national and local governments.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji itself means habit but it usually refers to a bad habit, so try to remember that meaning if you could.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Ten thousand years old! That's a lot of time. This is the word for the turned-English Japanese phrase, banzai!

Ahh, what a nice cool breeze…

meaning.explanation: Remember how 揚げる can mean "to deep fry"? 揚げ出し is a Japanese cooking technique where you deep fry something (usually tofu) and serve it in broth. This word might be easy to remember if you know that "dashi" soup stock is often used to make the agedashi broth.

reading.explanation: The reading is 揚げる and 出す's reading.

This is usually in the form of foam, but could also be a bubble. 水泡 is a literary word, mainly seen in the idiom 水泡に帰す (to come to nothing). This phrase paints a picture of your efforts going down the drain, turning into foam or bubbles in the water, and ultimately disappearing into nothingness.

meaning.explanation: The one true sovereign is the Japanese emperor, a.k.a. the emperor of Japan. On its own, 帝 only refers to him, not to other emperors around the world. 帝 is a classical term for the emperor in Japan. It's found in works of classical literature, historical novels, or period dramas that are set in feudal Japan. In modern Japanese, the Japanese emperor is called 天皇.

reading.explanation: To remember the reading, think about how the Japanese Emperor, can always pull out his "me card" (みかど) when he's in trouble. It's kind of like how a "trump card" is the one that's above all the others, but with the emperor he's always up there, so it's a "me card" to him. And who's gonna argue with the emperor? Not me.

With the wind in your face. Imagine how refreshing a cool soda would be after rowing all day!

meaning.explanation: Forging and tempering of things is tempering and forging of things. When you do this to your body, to get ready for the big race, it's called training. (Though body tempering sounds way cooler, don't you think?)

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means pride and the verb version is to be proud of or to boast of.

reading.explanation: The hoe 子 (ほこ) is the kid who is carrying around a hoe all the time, swinging it around, doing dumb things with it. He's so proud of it, though, and it shows on his face. He's always boasting about his hoe skillz too.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means blink and the verb vocab version is to blink. This word is generally used in the phrase 瞬く間に (in the blink of an eye).

reading.explanation: Mah ta-ta (またた) is showing, causing you to blink. I don't know what a "ta-ta" is, but I bet you could come up with something that's blink-worthy.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means slice and the verb vocab version means to cut down or to slice off or to lop off.  This word mainly refers to cutting people with a sword, if you haven't figured it out yet.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 切る, which means "to cut." Similar meaning, same reading.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means forge and the verb vocab version is to forge and to temper.

reading.explanation: To forge something, you need to have your kit (きた) with you. Without it, you won't be doing any forging at all.

meaning.explanation: Hey look! If you weren't sick of them yet, it's another verb that goes with shake! This one means to shake too!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 揺る, 揺する, and 揺れる so I reeeeally hope you can remember it by now!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shut up so the verb vocab version is to shut up.

reading.explanation: You need to damn (だま) your mouth shut and shut up.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means thwart and the verb vocab version is to thwart or to hamper.

reading.explanation: Someone walks up to you, saying "habbah habbah habbah" (kind of like hubbah hubbah). He's trying to flash you or something. So, you go to thwart him with your taser.

meaning.explanation: The kanji 盆 means tray or ancestral festival. The お just adds politeness or respect. So お盆 also means tray, or refers to the ancestral festival also known as Obon. Usually, the context will tell you which meaning for お盆 is being used, but you can also distinguish between them by the pitch accent. お盆 for "tray" uses a Low-High-High accent (like our female audio), and お盆 for "ancestral festival" uses a Low-High-Low accent (like our male audio).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Two time ten years old is twenty years old.

meaning.explanation: 紛らわしい is "confusing" or "misleading." This is the negative of that (you can tell by the ない), meaning it's kind of the opposite of those things. This word is unmistakable, indisputable , and obvious.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 紛らわしい.

meaning.explanation: Something that's not calm is in a state of unrest. When things are unsettled, it's disquieting for people. 不穏 is generally used to describe the unsettling mood or atmosphere of a situation, highlighting tension and unease rather than describing something physical.

On its own, it often describes the behavior of people who can't let go of a particular issue and keep on about it in unwanted ways.

You can think of it this way: You were barefoot too long, and because of this, you don't have feet anymore, though you had ashi (はだし) at one point in the past.

meaning.explanation: Your torso body is the body area that's your torso. It's your body and trunk and torso, depending on what kind of body you have.
