Just picture after picture of a sash. Purple sashes. Green sashes. Flashy sashes. What a weird book, that only has illustrations of sashes. 絵, however, is the reading you learned with the kanji, so at least you have that.

meaning.explanation: Sticky earth is clay. Just think about feeling the clay. It's sticky especially when fresh and kind of wet, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this is a word made up of a single kanji and nothing else, you can assume that this word will use the kun'yomi reading. The reading you learned for this kanji happens to be the kun'yomi reading as well. So if you know the kanji you know the reading.

meaning.explanation: A big help is a colonel or navy captain. They go around the seas, helping people in need by fighting the bad guys.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation:
A river of willows... so hilarious! What a great comic haiku, that one is. Try to think of a comic haiku about the river willow, if you can. The River Willow
Flows upstream like a salmon
This is not funny

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. And for once the kanji 川 doesn't use the kun'yomi reading. When you think of a comic haiku, think of something hilarious... like a centaur (せん), doing a standup act with a comedy haiku.

meaning.explanation: A cooking occurrence is just the act of cooking. It's the kitchen work.  炊事 refers to tasks involved in meal preparation as part of everyday life. It's a relatively formal word and not as commonly used as 料理, but you might see it used in lists of household chores or duties, like in a job description for a housekeeper.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A self cook is cooking for oneself. Better break out the TV tray.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means wick and this word also means wick, but it means things at the core of other long things more often. Things like pencil lead and marrow.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The 〜 shows the number of tatami mats, and the 畳 part is "tatami" of course. So, this is a counter for tatami mats. It is generally used to show how big an apartment or something is. Oh, your apartment is 12 tatami mats? Nice and big!

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A cloth towel is just a cloth towel. Essentially it's known as a dish cloth or tea towel.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A gate's front door is the doors of a gate or gate doors.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A water drip is a drop of water or a water drop.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A miscellaneous cloth is a dust cloth or house cloth. It's just a cloth that you use on random things.

reading.explanation: The reading of 雑 is different from what you've learned. Instead of ざつ it's ぞう. Just imagine using this dust cloth to wipe down a 象 (ぞう). Its trunk is particularly dusty.

meaning.explanation: 稼ぐ is "to earn income." This is the noun version. It's just earnings, the things you earn.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 稼ぐ.

meaning.explanation: A folding fan wind machine is a machine that blows wind like a folding fan. That's an electric fan or an electronic fan.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Insert some talking. Now you have an episode! Now put some more talking in that story. You have another episode!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You 取り (take) and then 分け (divide) something. But you'll want to be especially careful not to give anyone an unequal share. This is especially important because we’re dealing with money, and people will flip out and shoot you under the table if you aren't especially accurate. Note that this word is usually written in kana.

reading.explanation: The readings come from the words 取る and 分ける. So long as you know those words you should be able to read this one as well.

meaning.explanation: If you crash and fall then you're crashing or falling, maybe both.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What does Italy attain like no other? Flamboyance! They redefine chic and stylishness, dazzling everyone with their unabashed display. This word isn’t just about fashion; it's also for flamboyant, attention-grabbing actions. While it's an old-fashioned word, you still find it in phrases like 伊達眼鏡 (fashion glasses) or 伊達に〜はしていない (not doing something for show).

reading.explanation: The readings for both kanji are ones you haven't seen before. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember: So how does Italy attain its flamboyance? Because it embodies Dante’s (だて) bold essence—vibrant, captivating, and chic in every way. In Italy, Dante's influence is a living testament to flamboyant elegance.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading of the vocab is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A folding fan's child is, for some reason, a folding fan. I'm guessing there are different sizes of folding fans, and this is the smaller more manageable kind you can carry around easily and make it smaller by folding it up, which is why it's the "child" version of the folding fan. Still a folding fan, though.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If there are lies and deceit in your interactions with people, you're committing fraud, you're carrying out a scam, you're swindling.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Out of the front door jumps (飛び) Ra (ら). Every morning he can't wait to burst forth from the front door to soak in the Sun. He is the Egyptian sun god, after all.

meaning.explanation: An old woman, even with an honorific and an お is still an old woman. She might be your grandmother as well, though, so be nice!

reading.explanation: Even if she is your grandmother, something is wrong. You look closely at her face. She's a sheep! Baa! (ばあ).

meaning.explanation: Manipulate your grip over and over. You have to manipulate it because you're slipping. You're just grasping right now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If sand makes a lot of profit, it swells up and becomes gravel. They're like the fat cats of the beach.

reading.explanation: You learned the reading for 利 with the kanji, but the reading for 砂 is irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're walking through that big fat gravel, when a pile of it starts moving, and something suddenly leaps out at you. It's a... jaguar (じゃ)! Run!

meaning.explanation: When you roast tea, you get green tea, also known as green leaf teaor sencha. In reality there are various ways to make green tea, but for the purposes of this mnemonic, let's imagine it's always roasted!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A hat child is a hat or cap. Sadly, it's not made from children, unless you're crazy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The thing your heart requests is what your heart wants. This is your heartfelt desire. 心願 is often found in the phrase 心願成就 (fulfillment of a heartfelt wish), commonly used in the context of prayer rituals at Shinto shrines or Buddhist temples.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You know that 狩り is hunting already. This is the same thing (hunting). Difference is this one is attached to other words to specify what kind of hunting you're doing.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 狩り, but since it follows another word, it gets rendaku-ed. Here is a mnemonic to help with remembering the rendaku. Hunting can be girly (がり), if you dress up like a girly hunter.

meaning.explanation: If you insert and enter something, you are doing insertion to it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Point drips are drips coming down little by little. These are the drips of an intravenous drip.  Back in the day this was a way of talking about raindrops, or really any falling drops of water. But nowadays we only use it for IV drips.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The place with Italy force is a place known as Ise. It's a region of Japan that has a nice peninsula, I think. Going straight to the reading for this one may be your best bet.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out, because this uses the せ, not the せい you're used to seeing.

meaning.explanation: A lump spirit is the lump of spirit that's used in the famous game Katamari Damacy.

reading.explanation: The reading is 塊 and 魂 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: You lack likeness to anything out there. You totally lack something that gives you likeness. It's a deficiency, or something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The middle help in the army or navy is the lieutenant colonel or the navy commander. I'm guessing these ranks are kind of in the middle or middle high end of the ranking scales?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: If you have love and hate then you have love and hate.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The bottom lip is your lower lip or bottom lip.

reading.explanation: したくちびる just combines the kun'yomi vocab reading for 下 and the kun'yomi reading you learned with the kanji for 唇.

meaning.explanation: The few who help are the majors or lieutenant commanders. They are the few who step up to the plate to help out in the army, according to this word's kanji.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Change your face with cosmetics! This is via makeup or, of course, cosmetics.

reading.explanation: The reading for 化 is a new reading, け. To remember this, think about someone putting on makeup. They finish putting it on, and then you say "K, show (けしょう) me!"

meaning.explanation: If you lie about your title, the title which represents who you are, then that is a misrepresentation. A false statement.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The freight of cash comes in. What is a freight of cash? It's just money, currency, or coinage.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Morning fog is morning fog, because it's fog in the morning. This is the best kind of fog, I think.

reading.explanation: The reading is the readings you learned with both kanji. Be careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A soil fence is a fence made from soil. Usually this is in the form of a mud wall or an earthen wall.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: An elderly old woman is just an old woman.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: One's parent father is simply just one's father.  Note that 親父 has a masculine and somewhat vulgar tone to it. It can refer to your own dad, someone else's, or a middle-aged man you're friendly with. When not talking about your own father, you'll want to add a さん at the end, making it 親父さん.

reading.explanation: The reading for this is unfortunately a bit of an exception. 親 uses the kun'yomi おや, and 父 uses the じ reading which you learned with 叔父. You've learned all these readings before, so as long as you remember them, you're good to go. If you don't, check out the mnemonics for these readings on their vocabularies' pages!

meaning.explanation: When you manipulate something, imagine you're doing it with your palm. You use your palm to manipulate the movement, and then you fine tune it further, all with your palm! Something to note here is that you'll typically see palm in Japanese written as 手のひら. This kanji isn't as common but it does still mean the same thing.

reading.explanation: Where is the palm of one's hand? It's on your 手のhere (てのひら). Right here. I point to my palm, and say "hand here, is where my palm was." Another noteworthy thing about this kanji is it can be read as たなごころ. You won't see it read this way as often though so we're only teaching you the main reading.

meaning.explanation: Paper cash is paper money.

reading.explanation: This word uses the on'yomi reading for 紙 even though you went through all that trouble to learn the kun'yomi reading. Did you know paper money is made of sheep (し)? Well, part sheep, but there's sheep in there for sure. That's why you can wash your paper money with your t-shirts in the washing machine.

meaning.explanation: The peak of the mountain is a peak or mountain.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you climb to the top of the peak, you're so amazed to find vegetation at this altitude. The only thing that grows here, and in thick amounts, is 竹 (たけ). It is impeding your progress to the very top of the peak, in fact, which is a bother. It's as if it's guarding something...

meaning.explanation: A possible pathetic scenario you might imagine is probably not just possibly pathetic. It's downright pitiful and pathetic, for sure.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Well, at least most of it does. To remember the reading for 哀 imagine some pathetic person who lost their home. They may be pitiful but at some point after losing their home they decided that the hood of your car would make a fine place to live. You can't help but ask them, "Why (わい) my car?" There are so many other cars this pathetic person could be camping out on, but they chose yours.

meaning.explanation: If something is pathetic then you should have pity on it. You should also feel a little sorrow and grief for it, because seriously, so pathetic!

reading.explanation: You look at the thing you're feeling is so pathetic that you feel pity for and just think... aww (あわ), that's really pathetic.

meaning.explanation: The spear ahead is the most ahead part of the halberd. That's the point of spear or spearpoint.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the vocab versions of 矛 and 先 combined together.

meaning.explanation: To powder I will smash it! If I do that, it's pulverization and smashing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Rainbow colored things are rainbow colored.

reading.explanation: The readings are the kanji readings for both 虹 and 色.

meaning.explanation: The flower willow for some reason is a red light district. Just imagine a shady red light district, and right in the middle is a flowering willow.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji, making it refreshing as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same reading you learned with the kanji!

meaning.explanation: A pain grudge is pain you feel from the grudge. I wish I could change my grudge. It is my regret.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A rest rest is a rest. A break. A recess.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A cook food container is a container used to cook the main food staple in Japan. In this case it's a rice cooker.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Smashed stone is smashed stone. It's rubble and broken stone.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What do you get when you roast mochi? Senbei, a crispy Japanese rice cracker!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for the second kanji, but if you remember the meaning of the word, that will get you to the reading. In case you're having trouble, here's a mnemonic to help: You sit eating senbei next to a bay (べい), looking out over the water as you crunch.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: An attack that causes a crash is when you're shooting down something, usually an aircraft.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I am sad and pathetic in how I feel. Such a deep sorrow! Such grief from my sad pathetic feelings.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Divideable chopsticks are chopsticks you can split apart. They are splittable chopsticks, almost always made from wood of some kind.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 割る and 箸 put together. Be careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Sticky sticky things are really sticky and covered with stickiness.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 粘る. I suppose you never never want to touch something sticky.

meaning.explanation: When something bears a sudden likeness, we say it happens suddenly, or all of a sudden. Note that this word is relatively formal and somewhat literary.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You use your lie to take what you want. That's when you swindle or defraud someone to get their stuff. How dare you! 詐取 refers to the act of fraudulently obtaining something, typically money or property, through deceptive practices. This term is formal and often used in legal contexts.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A scroll of shaku. So, a scroll is all rolled up, right? And a shaku is an older form of Japanese measurement. If you roll up a measuring thing into a scroll-like container... what does it become? A tape measure!

reading.explanation: The reading for 巻 is the 巻く reading, pushed into the kanji. The 尺 reading is the normal reading of 尺. Careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading comes right from the vocab meaning, which is tatami mat. The たたみ part, specifically.

meaning.explanation: 陰 is a shadow, and adding お to it and makes it honorific. It becomes the shadow of someone very important, and means thanks to, as in "thanks to you, I was able to pass the test." This originally comes from the idea of being in the shadow of the gods, who are protecting you and helping you out! If that's hard to remember, think about shade helping you out. Perhaps thanks to the shade you were able to survive the heat of the desert.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 陰. Thanks to that other vocab word, you can read this one!

meaning.explanation: A black fog is going to be a really thick fog or black veil that covers suspicious acts or crimes. It's not a literal cloud of fog or a physical veil, it's what you hide your bad deeds in, metaphorically speaking.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 黒い and 霧.

meaning.explanation: This is an intransitive version of 擦る, so it means to be rubbed. It often implies damage, in which case it can mean to be grazed or to be scraped, like when your knee gets grazed against a rough wall.

reading.explanation: You really don’t want your knee to be grazed. If it happens, you are gonna sue (す). But the cost (こす) of suing is pretty high, so be careful not to get grazed in the first place! Depending on which reading you use, the nuance changes slightly. For example, すれる is the usual choice when you’re talking about your grazed knees or worn out jeans. For other uses, they are often interchangeable.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means sticky and the verb vocab version is to be sticky. It can also mean to persevere, because if you're being sticky towards the situation, not giving up and not letting go. You're totally persevering by sticking around.

reading.explanation: Will I give up? I'll never (ねば) give up! I'll also never unstick from you.

meaning.explanation: 磨く is "to polish" or "to shine." If you're doing that to your teeth you are brushing them. That's why this is to brush one's teeth.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 歯 and 磨く, put together.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means carve and the verb version is to carve something, or to engrave something. This is a transitive verb, meaning it can take a direct object. You engrave letters into a stone, and you carve a scary face into a pumpkin. Those letters and that face are your objects.

reading.explanation: Imagine trying to carve something using a hoe (ほ). Its long handle makes it a pretty impractical tool for carving. Now imagine all the trouble you have carving with it.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deceit, so when you're doing deceit, you are going to deceive someone.

reading.explanation: As a human everyone would know who you are. You can't deceive anyone like that. But, as a moo (あざむ)... a cow is what I mean... nobody would know who you are.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drip and the verb vocab version is to drip.

reading.explanation: To drip drip drip on your head... what's dripping on your head? You're standing below a toilet that's leaking. The dripping sounds like "sh*t, ta-ta (したた), with each drip making a "ta" sound because it's kind of thick and poopy.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means folding fan and since you don't "to folding fan" something, this word means to fan instead.

reading.explanation: Imagine yourself trying to fan yourself with an 青 (あお) fan. For some reason blue fans feel cooler. Maybe it's because they're the color of ice/water?

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means hate and the verb vocab version is to hate or to detest.

reading.explanation: What do you hate and detest more than anything? 肉 (にく). That stuff is gross, and you detest it.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grudge and the verb vocab version is to hold a grudge.

reading.explanation: Who do you hold a grudge against the most? That would be you, Ra (うら). You and your dumb sun.

meaning.explanation: 澄む is "to become clear" - this is when you make something clear, because you must (ます) make it clear. You have to. That's why this is or to make something clear or to clear something. This can also mean to strain when used together with 耳, as in 耳を澄ます, "to strain one's ears".

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the kanji, so if you know that, that'll make this answer clear too.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 湿る is "to be moist"? This is the version where you're doing the moistening, making it to moisten or to dampen.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 湿る.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means rest and the verb vocab version is to rest or to relax.

reading.explanation: I'm going to rest and play some Ico (いこ) on the ol' PlayStation.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means zero, but the verb vocab version means to spill something or to drop something. Think of it this way, if you spill something, eventually it will reach zero.

reading.explanation: Imagine you're co-boiling (こぼ) water with someone. With the two of you co-boiling, the water is boiling pretty hard. Watch out, though — you're about to spill the hot water everywhere!

meaning.explanation: A car manipulator is someone who manipulates the car. This 車 riffs off of 電車, which is a train, making the train manipulator a train conductor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The above lip is the upper lip.

reading.explanation: The reading for 上 is a bit weird, it's うわ instead of うえ. It's almost like うえ, just a little different.

meaning.explanation: 眺める is "to stare at." The noun version is view or scene. It's what you're staring at.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 眺める.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The willow you have outside is a naggy willow, always asking for more water. That's yah naggy weeping willow.

meaning.explanation: A woman's rights consist of women's rights. This is a formal word that is often used at the beginning of compounds, such as 女権拡張運動 (movement for the expansion of women's rights). In everyday conversations, you can just say 女性の権利 to talk about women’s rights.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Adding an お in front and a さん behind miss makes for a very respectful way of addressing ayoung lady. It can also be used to refer to somebody’s daughter in a polite manner. Note that older generations tend to use this word to directly address a young woman. But be careful when doing this yourself, as it might come across as overly formal!

reading.explanation: The reading of 嬢 is the same as the one you learned for the kanji, meaning you should already know it!

meaning.explanation: Accomplish and go forth! These are your accomplishments. This is your execution of actions.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means amass and the verb vocab version is to amass. 蓄える means to gradually accumulate something to store up. So you can use 蓄える for storing up resources or knowledge, or even for growing a mustache or beard!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You need to amass things, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly store up lots of things.

reading.explanation: You go to color something, painting the coloring all over the wall. Problem is, the coloring is made of ACID. This causes the wall to erode (いろど).

reading.explanation: You have two cheese cars (つちか) that are growing mold. But that's a good thing, because it's the good kind of cheese mold. So, you cultivate the mold on these two cheese cars, comparing the difference between the two.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dance and the verb vocab version means to dance.

reading.explanation: What is it that you have to endure? A barrage of tacos (た), coming at you.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to get spilled, to fall out, or to overflow.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 零す.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means humiliate so the verb vocab version is to humiliate.

reading.explanation: Remember the word 恥ずかしい? It has the same reading as this one, and a similar meaning as well.

reading.explanation: The thing that you melted in this situation is your toe (と). Feel your toe getting melted away. Augghh it hurts.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paint and the verb vocab version is to paint and to plaster and to lacquer.

reading.explanation: Let's put a new (ぬ) layer of paint on the wall. Then we'll plaster it.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means paste so the verb vocab is to paste (or to stick).

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means assault. What are some ways to assault a person? How about to punch, to strike, or to hit, to name a few?

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means radiance. Imagine if something is radiating on something else. That would cause it to shine or to glitter or to sparkle.

reading.explanation: The cog yak is so shiny. It's so shiny that it starts to shine and glitter. I don't know what a cog yak is, but imagine it in your head and imagine it being super shiny, shining off shines and glitter.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means smash and the verb vocab version of the kanji is to smash or to break.

reading.explanation: You want to smash my stuff? That's coo' だ (くだ). Whatever you wanna do.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means starve and the verb vocab version is to starve. This is a formal word and it's often used in phrases like 愛情に飢える (to be starved for love) or 知識に飢える (to have a thirst for knowledge).

reading.explanation: When you're about to starve, what do you yearn for? Uni (う), of course! As your hunger intensifies, all you can think of is uni!

meaning.explanation: Reason is not exhausted... but what you're asking is unreasonable. Soon my reason will be exhausted, though.

reading.explanation: The reading for 車 is the vocab reading, くるま. Then, 椅子 is いす.

meaning.explanation: You're clever and bright so obviously you're going to make wise and sensible decisions. In fact, when you go to make these very wise choices and observations, your brain glows brightly.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The thing you extract from a phenomenon is an abstraction. Extracting abstraction out of a phenomenon may not sound like a very concrete or vivid mnemonic, but I guess that makes it an appropriate abstraction…

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so it means to be cooked, to be boiled, or to be done cooking. Also a little cultural note — this word is used for both rice, and other foods in western Japan, while it's only used for rice in eastern Japan.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 炊く.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means inferiority and the verb vocab version is to be inferior to.

reading.explanation: When thinking about cars, an automatic (おと) car is inferior to a manual car. Sure, manual is harder, but way more interesting to drive.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means watered. When something is watered it becomes moist, right? That's why this verb is to be moist or to be moistened. 潤う refers to things being well-moisturized, like skin or eyes. Think of them as being enriched with moisture. That's why the meaning also extends to financial prosperity — moisture enriches the body, and financial gain enriches your life or business. So this word also means to be prosperous.

reading.explanation: If you get moist or moistened, then you're all (うるお) wet. It's just how it is.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means capsize but the verb version is what happens when a plan or idea capsizes. It going to be overturned. It was a bad idea, go back, don't do it or we'll all sink!

reading.explanation: Of all the ideas that need to be overturned, it's the ones from the 靴 guy (くつがえ). He thinks we should only wear shoes. Not shoes and nothing else, but shoes all over our entire bodies. Yikes, now that's an idea I'd like to be retracted, 靴 guy.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is an intransitive verb, so this verb means to be smashed, to be shattered, or to break (for things like waves and tension!).

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 砕く.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed. Things that are immersed are described by verbs like to be soaked in or to be submerged or to be flooded.

reading.explanation: What is soaked and submerged in water (that shouldn't be)? It is your heater (ひた). It's all soaked and doesn't work anymore :(

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means boil and the verb vocab version is to boil something. This is a transitive verb, so it's used when you put something into a pot and boil it up.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decline and the verb vocab version is to decline.

reading.explanation: You're wandering through the jungle exploring, when you come upon a deep pit. Since you're looking for treasure, you decide to go down into the pit to look for some. You take out your handy auto rope (おとろ), made of organic, environment friendly materials, and easily rappel down into the pit. Unfortunately, you get lost down there, and it takes you fifty years to get back to the pit you came in from. But your auto rope is gone! This is the last time you buy an organic rope, made to decay and to wither away when left in the wild.

meaning.explanation: 挿入 is "insertion" so the verb version is to insert.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 挿入, so if you know that you can insert this reading into your memory no problem.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means isolate and the verb vocab version is to isolate or to partition or to separate. You get the idea, anyways.

reading.explanation: Why did you have to isolate him from the rest of the soccer players? Because all he could do was headers (へだ) and that was getting pretty dangerous. He would head everything in his reach. He was going crazy with headers. He had to be isolated!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means kick so the verb version is to kick.

reading.explanation: This vocabulary word uses the same reading you learned with the kanji, plus the hiragana attached at the end.

meaning.explanation: Giving one kick is certainly an effective (if brutal) way to flatly reject or to brush aside something or someone. That one kick can also be used to easily beat anyone.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji.  First up, notice that いち changes to いっ. And since you haven't learned the on'yomi for the kanji 蹴 (kick) yet, here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're planning to flatly reject someone, one kick is all you need. Before you do that, be absolutely sure to put your shoe (しゅう) on first.

meaning.explanation: If you prune and take from what you pruned, you're going to mow or to reap or to harvest whatever it is you're pruning.

reading.explanation: The reading is the reading you learned with 刈 and the reading from the vocab 取る.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means confused or bewildered but this is usually just used when someone starts to panic. They're so confused and bewildered that they try to hurry through things.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Whenever you start to panic you can't help but blurt out, "A wha- (あわ)?" to everything people say and ask. For example, "Would you like a mint?" "A WHA?!" Yeah, you really do sound upset.

meaning.explanation: If something is pathetic then you should try to pity that thing.

reading.explanation: Awww (あわ), you're so pathetic it's cute! I will pity you. Reading also comes from 哀れ.
