reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A horse riding soldier is a member of the cavalry.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A cave hole is a cave or den.

reading.explanation: The reading of 洞 is one you've learned. The reading of 穴 isn't one you've learned, though. So, think about how you go inside this cave, only to find yourself covered by some red goopy liquid. You think it's blood, but luckily it just turns out to be ketsup (けつ). If you want to be less formal, you can also use the kun'yomi and say ほらあな, but then you'd never learn that reading for 穴, and where's the fun in that?

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Hoe Ra (ほら), the version of Ra who carries a hoe around, is using said hoe to dig out a cave for himself, to provide shade from the sun (despite being the god of sun). He digs digs digs and then sits in his nice cave, hoe in hand.

meaning.explanation: When you flip your idea of something, you're changing how you think about it. That's why this word is change one's mind.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The chief of this district is that guy, the count. He's also the earl of another district, and the chief of yet another.

reading.explanation: The reading is the はく reading you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Something that is adept but peculiar in how adept it is would have to be something truly clever and ingenious. Like a clever scam or trick. 巧妙 is typically used to describe deceptive actions, techniques, or methods that are not only skillful but also somewhat sly or crafty. It indicates a level of sophistication, often involving clever scheming or manipulation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A wind that is wicked comes and blows on you. It's so cold, and ends up getting you sick. You now have a cold.

reading.explanation: Strangely, the reading for this word is the same as the vocab reading of 風 (かぜ). That's probably going to be the easiest way to remember this, especially since otherwise the reading would be one big horrible exception.

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji and has the same meaning as well: coloring.

reading.explanation: The reading has いろ (like 色) in it, then a ど, so think about an 色 dog, running around coloring things, because that's what an 色 dog does.

meaning.explanation: A comic talent! And not just one, but two comic talents, because this means a comic dialogue or a comedy double act.  More specifically, 漫才 refers to a double act that features a "funny man" (ボケ) and "straight man" (ツッコミ) in a comic dialogue routine. 漫才 is one of the most popular forms of comedy in Japan.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: When you revise something to make it correct you are doing a correction and revision.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji refers to a bundle, but this refers to a counter for bundles. Put this on a number, and you have "1 bundle" or "2 bundles" or even three, oh my!

reading.explanation: Saying "1 bundle" and "2 bundle" takes too long, so you decide to call these bundles what they look like: わ for walrus (わ)!

meaning.explanation: The law courts are the courts you visit to get law distributed. The room in which you do this in is a courtroom.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The meaning is the same as the kanji's meaning, crab. If you know this word, and you know the word 鰐 as well... then, well, you know something, though I'm not sure what that something is.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. But you knew that already, didn't you?

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: A feeling of inscription is the feeling one gets when something so strong happens that it's like the feeling gets inscribed into your soul. This is something that left a very deep impression.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who is bad but also clever (賢い) is someone who is using their cleverness for evil. When you refer to clever evil people, usually you describe them not as "clever" but as devious, cunning, or other things.

reading.explanation: The reading is 悪い and 賢い combined together into one word. Be careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Drifting down the stream. Something that is doing this is drifting. It could also be the drift of something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something has drifted to the point where it has arrived. Where do drifting things arrive? They arrive on shore (as they drift on top of water). That makes this word drifting ashore.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You look at this inscription then you look at that inscription and you notice that each one is an individual inscription.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The embankment prevents the water from going over the edge. It's an embankment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: The reading is like the reading of 包み, which means "bundle" or "package." Try to think of an embankment that's made purely from bundles and packages. These 包み(つつみ) are the only thing holding the water in!

meaning.explanation: My interest is stirred up! I'm feeling excitement and stimulation from all this stirring up, in fact!

reading.explanation: The reading for 興奮 is one you didn't learn with the kanji, though it's similar. Instead of きょう it's こう, so just think of how whenever you feel excitement, it's thanks to こういち. So just think of こういち exciting you in some way to remember this vocab's reading.

meaning.explanation: Remember 殴る, which means "to punch"? Well, add on 合う and you've got punches that have come together with other punches. By "come together" I mean your fist is coming in contact with someone's face, and their fist is coming in contact with your kidneys. In other words, this is a fistfight.

reading.explanation: The readings come from 殴る and 合う, punched together.

meaning.explanation: Nothing but burdensome. That's all you get out of doing this task. The futility of it is ridiculous. The uselessness is huge.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Look below you. These things carry your burdensome weight. All of it. These are the shoes you wear, though in this case they are specifically geta, or Japanese wooden clogs. The clogs themselves are kind of burdensome and hard to wear too, actually, so you can think of it that way as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for 駄 is the secondary kanji reading. Instead of だ it's た. Hopefully you've heard of "geta" before. This will make it really easy for you to remember the reading of this vocab word.

meaning.explanation: Gloom pottery is... well, it's gloomy and depressing! This word can also mean annoying. If something or someone always makes you feel gloomy, you'll probably think it's annoying, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the shortening, and don't be tricked by the hiragana sticking out. The readings of the kanji don't change.

meaning.explanation: A gloomy energy has filled the room. This puts you in a gloomy mood. You are now feeling downcast. This word is formal, so you'll mostly just see it in literature.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Careful of the shortening of 鬱 or you'll feel gloomy.

meaning.explanation: Using the grasp meaning of 把 and combining it with grip, you can tell you're grasping at something and then gripping it. I usually grasp then grip at things flying at me, which makes this word mean grasp or understand.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A tomb grave is a grave... or it could be a tomb. Or maybe both.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A hemp cloth is a hemp cloth.

reading.explanation: The reading is the individual vocab readings of 麻 and 布 combined together.

meaning.explanation: A wicked devil! Ugh, I hate those things. They're always a hindrance and intrusion. Just imagine a wicked devil hanging out in your house, eating your food, and sleeping on your bed. What a hindrance.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sky cave is a cave with sky (open space) in it. This is a hollow, but can also refer to a cavity.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You've seen that 飢える is "to starve." The noun version is hunger or starvation.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 飢える.

meaning.explanation: To excuse yourself from the epidemic, you'll have to have immunity or immunization from the disease.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Shinto shrine courts are the courts of the Shinto shrines. Shinto is often associated with the emperor, which is why this the imperial court. Royal court will do as well.

reading.explanation: The reading for 宮 is one you haven't seen before. Just think about how cute (きゅう) this imperial court is. It's a My Little Pony imperial court, or something.

meaning.explanation: An epidemic of sickness is going to come from an infectious disease. Perhaps a plague or epidemic of some kind?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If there is nothing wicked about your spirit at all, you are a going to be an innocent and simple minded person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The emperor empress is the emperor's wife. That's the Japanese Empress, specifically, since 皇 usually refers to the Japanese emperor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: It's so robust and big! Things like this are magnificent, grand, and epic!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Comic drawings are manga, a.k.a. Japanese comics.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Take along this summit and move it across a range, visiting more summits. One summit after another you take the summit along to. By covering this many summits, you notice there's a string of mountains. This is a mountain range!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: A mulberry field is a mulberry field. Based on an old belief that lightening does not strike mulberry fields, 桑原 (often recited twice, as in "桑原桑原") can also be used as a charm to ward off undesirable events, though it's pretty old-fashioned. Apart from that use, 桑原 now mainly refers to the family name Kuwabara, like one of the main protagonists of the anime and manga series 幽遊白書.

reading.explanation: These are both the kun'yomi readings, but you haven't learned this for 原 yet. It's actually the rendaku'd version, so let's just use a mnemonic to remember it instead: You know you're in a mulberry field when you see a bunch of capybaras (ばら) rolling around in there with you. Capybaras love mulberries! Picture a whole family of capybaras munching on mulberries. Mm Mmm!

meaning.explanation: If something is burdensome to the eye (when you look at it), you know that that thing is not good or hopeless. Just look at that burdensome thing with your eye. This can also mean not allowed. Parents say this to their kids all the time.

reading.explanation: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: Something you do accidentally is hopefully something you do occasionally or once in a while. Also note that this word is usually written in hiragana. You'll only occasionally see it in kanji.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Occasionally Tamara (たま), the local ball girl, will take a break from her duties. But it's really only once in a while, because Tamara is such a hard worker.

meaning.explanation: A life horizon is your life, which you're looking out over, all the way to the very end. This is one's lifetime, though it could also refer to one's career. Basically, at the end of it something dies.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A rut in the road is for some reason an orbit or trajectory. Maybe imagine a big ol' rut in the road. You drive at it at very high speeds, hit it, and fly into the sky at a trajectory that will send you into orbit. Now you're up in space, circling the earth, wishing you didn't drive so fast.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You look up to someone... twice. That's too many times that you're looking up to someone. They must be pretty amazing for that to happen. Really, though, you're being fooled. This person is pompous and exaggerated. So you think they're cool, but really they're pretending to be more than they are.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, x2 with a しい added on for good measure.

meaning.explanation: Your robust years are the best years of your life! This is the prime of life.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You want people to express how they feel about you in a clear manner, so you demand they give you public acknowledgement. You want clear, concise public recognition for all of your amazing talents, skills, and for reaching level 50 of WaniKani. Maybe they'll throw you a parade!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A public announcement is a public notice. 公告 looks and sounds a lot like 広告, but the meanings are different. You might remember 広告 is for advertisements, but 公告 here is for the kind of official statements that companies or governments put out for the public, especially shareholders, creditors, or other stakeholders. You can remember 公告 is a public notice because the kanji for "public" is 公, and it's not covered by a canopy like the other one. It's uncovered, all out in the open for everyone to see — public!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: We have to examine you during this epidemic... soooo, if you could come over here and just stay here for a long time, that'd be great. Yeah, it's kind of a quarantine, sorry about that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I need to consult you on this problem, if I could. I have a question / enquiry I'd like to ask you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If 輝く is "to shine" or "to glitter" think about the noun version of this. This would be radiance. Radiance can come in the form of shining and glittering.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 輝く.

meaning.explanation: An assault into a place is a raid. 殴り込み usually means a raid by gang members or delinquents, where they barge into someone's home or enemy territory to start a fight.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from the word 殴る and the kanji 込.

meaning.explanation: A name record book is a book that contains names. That is a register of names or a list of names. Is your name on the list?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I believe and look up to a higher power, for I have religious faith.

reading.explanation: The reading for the 仰 portion is an exceptional one. Instead of ぎょう it's こう. Just remember, when it comes to religious faith, all you need to believe in is こういち.

meaning.explanation: If you see the kanji restaurant attached to a place name, there's a good chance that it's a restaurant, especially a traditional Japanese restaurant. It also crops up on the end of other places where you can rest, like inns, those traditional pavilions you see in Japanese parks and temple grounds, and tea houses.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

meaning.explanation: The renewed and revised edition of something is the revised edition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: The law of movement is governed by rhythm. Imagine moving around to a boss beat. As you move, you start to feel the rhythm in your step. Go ahead and walk around your room and feel this rhythm.  Note that リズム is a much more common word to use for "rhythm," but you may see the kanji version sometimes in formal writing. One thing you will see more often is 律動的 which means "rhythmic."

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A horse riding horse is what you need for riding a horse. This is a formal word and it’s typically used at the beginning of compounds where you'll see it translated as things like mounted, as in "mounted police," or equestrian, as in “equestrian peoples.” It's working like an adjective there, but it's still a noun in Japanese.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You want to make someone feel robust when they go away somewhere, so you give them a send-off. It's just a nice way to say farewell! 壮行 is usually for celebratory send-offs and appears in words like 壮行会 (farewell party) or 壮行式 (pep rally).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Distribute yourself accidentally to someone. That person ended up becoming your spouse. You distributed yourself to one person a little too much, it seems.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I'm stirred up causing me to wake up. I'm stirring and rousing oneself.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also be peak or ridge.

reading.explanation: Look up at the summit. It's such a mean (みね) summit. So big, so stormy, so mean.

meaning.explanation: I look up to heaven, and I am taken aback and amazed by it. It's just so amazing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accomplish and the verb vocab version is to accomplish.

reading.explanation: Everything you've accomplished can be stored in your single little pinky toe (と)... you haven't accomplished that much, apparently.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. You already learned 煮る, which is used for when you purposefully boil something. This verb, on the other hand, is intransitive, meaning that it refers to when something is getting boiled or cooked up, with no emphasis on who put the thing in the pot. That's why this verb means to be boiled or to be cooked.

reading.explanation: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji. Good for you!

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. While the kanji means flip, the verb vocab version is to billow or to flutter, as in some kind of material (maybe a dress or a flag) billowing or fluttering in the wind. It can also mean to suddenly change your mind, or your attitude, etc.

reading.explanation: For something to billow and to flutter, you'll need to ask the here guy (ひるがえ) - that's guy who's here right now - to open the window and let in the breeze.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lamp, so the verb version is to burn or to be lit. Just like what you'd do with a lamp.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who wanted the candle to be lit? Tom (とも) Cruise. He's afraid of the dark so he always wants all the lights and candles in the house to be burning at all times.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means consult and the verb vocab version is to consult with or to discuss.

reading.explanation: You need to consult with a hacker (はか) to solve your hacking problem. Imagine consulting with a hacker, whatever a hacker looks like in your mind.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means drift and the verb vocab version is to drift or to waft.

reading.explanation: You're going to drift away. Drifting drifting drifting. Then, you turn into a yo-yo and yell "ta-da yo-yo (ただよ)! Not sure why drifting turns you into a yo-yo, but imagine it and don't question it.

meaning.explanation: 尽きる is "to be exhausted". 尽くす is when you're doing the exhausting of something, which makes it to exhaust something or to run out. It can also mean to devote oneself to a certain cause.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 尽きる.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means look up to and the verb vocab version is to look up at or to look up to.

reading.explanation: Personally, I look up to the color 青 (あお). Literally and figuratively. I love the color blue, so I look up to it and respect it. Also, I look up at the sky and it's blue.

meaning.explanation: 溶かす is "to melt something" and that makes 溶ける to melt (where something just melts, and you're not doing the melting).

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 溶かす.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means regret and the verb vocab version is to regret or to mourn.

reading.explanation: The reading comes from 悔しい.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means savings, so the verb vocab version would become to save or to save up.  貯える means to set something aside for future needs or emergencies, like saving money or storing water.

reading.explanation: This shares a reading with 蓄える, which makes sense, as the meanings of them are very close to each other! If you’re not sure you remember the reading, here’s the mnemonic once more to help you remember it: You need to save up things, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly save up lots of things.

meaning.explanation: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means threaten and the verb vocab version is to threaten.

reading.explanation: I'm going to threaten you with your life if you have a bad odor (おど). Imagine someone with a bad odor, then threaten them.

meaning.explanation: Rut traces left in the road are tracks that mark the trajectory of a vehicle’s wheels. This can also be used figuratively to refer to leaving or following some sort of trace, or to describe someone’s or something’s trajectory, among other things.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Flip the translation of a word from one language to another. That is the translation of that word (or phrase, etc).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To carry you and transport you. That's a form of transport. Could also be a carriage, which is also a form of transport.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: Things that transport and send you places are forms of transportation. 搬送 is most often used in medical contexts to refer to the transportation of patients.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Who is the chief father? That's your uncle. And this uncle is the older brother of your mom or dad because he is the chief father. An uncle who is a younger brother of your parent is 叔父, which is another word for "uncle" you already know!

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception. But you already learned the 叔父 which means uncle too. Well they have the same reading! So if you know one uncle, you know them all.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This is a long reading for such a short word! Think of something being wicked. Evil, even! But what is wicked? It's the side of the island... but only the side. It's the 横島 (よこしま).

meaning.explanation: The eddy river isn't so much a thing as it is a famous place. We're talking about Yodogawa. It might be better to look at the reading to learn the meaning. Look up this Osaka Prefecture river if you'd like more info.

reading.explanation: The reading is 淀 plus 川. Be careful of the rendaku.

meaning.explanation: When you have mercy upon those you love it's called affection. You end up doing things out of the kindness of your heart because they mean a lot to you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The meaning of this word and the meaning of the kanji are the same: Again! This is a very common word, but it's almost always written in kana in casual situations. However, it's often written in kanji in formal contexts, such as official paperwork and legal documents. You'll also see it in some literature, particularly stuff that was written around the time of Miyazawa Kenji and Natsume Soseki.

reading.explanation: The reading you learned for the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. You hopefully won't have to learn it... again.

meaning.explanation: Plowed land is called arable land. This is the kind of land you use for growing crops or for pastures.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you scream wake up! at someone you can bet they're going to awaken. Screaming anything at a sleeping person would probably rouse them. They'll probably be mad at you though.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. That said, it's mostly used as a standalone word meaning "bay" in classical literature. Nowadays, it comes up most in place names, like the port Tagonoura (田子の浦) and the city of Urayasu (浦安市).

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Those sharing blood within a tribe are blood relatives. This is a formal term often used in legal matters related to inheritance or insurance claims. In fiction it’s sometimes applied to vampire bloodlines and other supernatural families.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The point at which something starts to boil is the boiling point.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: What's stuffed in the bottle? Jam you bottled for later! How could you forget?

reading.explanation: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 瓶 and the kun'yomi reading for 詰 that you learned when you learned 詰める. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too! Just remember that 詰 is taking the め from 詰める with it in this word too. You can't see it, but it's there.

meaning.explanation: When you use your intuition to determine the amount of something, you'll end up doing the calculations in your head. You do the same thing when it's time to pay your bill at dinner too: just determine the amount in your head, go with your intuition, and all should be good.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, 定 uses a reading you didn’t learn, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're having trouble with the calculation of your bill, just call Joe (じょう)! He’s surprisingly good with numbers, so whenever you’re lost at the restaurant table, just give him a quick call.

meaning.explanation: A morally good person who has mercy upon people gives to charity. These people prove they're good by mercifully giving all their money away to the poor and needy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Chastity is always in season so it's always cool to try to keep your chastity. Spring, summer? Doesn't matter. Your decision to stay that way is fine no matter what time of year it is.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You are a strong, independent person and you are the only one who can manipulate your chastity. Nobody else can. So if you want to keep your chastity that's completely up to you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: If you have mercy for people who are sad you have a lot of compassion. You just can't help but go easy on sad people.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A one sided corner is still a corner, just a really small one.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Plow the earth to make it ready for cultivation and farming.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Even something dry will dry up more if it's got dehydration. There's a lot of dryness going on here.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Wash wash powder is the detergent you put in the wash you make sure your clothes are washed well. Detergent used to only be available in powder form back in the old days, and it still can be, so this is for that good powdery stuff. Note that this word sounds a bit old-fashioned. To talk about laundry detergent in general, 洗濯洗剤 is more common nowadays.

reading.explanation: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 粉. You already learned this reading for 粉 when you learned the word 小麦粉. If you can remember that, you should know the readings for this one too!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: The wash wash shop is where you go to get your clothes washed extra well. It's the dry cleaners! They wash your clothes way better than you can because they wash them twice.

reading.explanation: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings by now, so you should be able to read this word too!

meaning.explanation: Something that will wither and dry up ends up doing exactly that, drying up. And as it dries up, there's less and less of it until there's nothing left. This is called depletion! This word is often used to describe situations where natural resources are getting used up and running out.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 渇 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If all of your plants are drying up you should just give them to your cats (かつ). Cats love to play with dried up plants. At least they won't go to waste.

meaning.explanation: The prefecture in Japan where they love princesses is Ehime Prefecture.

reading.explanation: This reading is a little messy. This reading for 愛 is an exception, 媛 uses the kun'yomi reading ひめ, and 県 uses the on'yomi reading けん. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for 愛: If you ask anyone outside of Ehime Prefecture what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "Eh" (え). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"

meaning.explanation: A sky bottle is a bottle that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty bottle.

reading.explanation: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You learned this reading for 空 when you learned 空き缶. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!

meaning.explanation: You must obey your business. When you're in this situation, you’re engaging in work. This is most commonly used in the compounds 従業員 (employee) and 従業者 (worker). You might also come across other forms, such as 従業する, but these are generally found in formal writing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Even if you untie an explanation it's still a pretty good explanation anyway.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An explanation that's bright is just a really clear and well developed explanation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Farming with a plow is still farming.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something that's both fat and obese has even more fat on it than you first thought. Like the blubber on a really big whale.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This isn't a literal snake's mouth, but rather a faucet. They do kind of have a resemblance though, just think about how the shape of a faucet kind of resembles that of a snake, with water coming out of its mouth.

reading.explanation: This one's a little unique, as it uses on'yomi for 蛇, and kun'yomi (which gets rendaku'd) for 口. You didn't learn this reading for 蛇, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Every time you try to drink from the faucet, you get viciously attacked by a jaguar (じゃ). Trying to drink from the faucet has become a fight for life and death. You just know the jaguar is hiding right there behind the faucet, guarding it.

meaning.explanation: A gentle and soft thing will be really flexible and pliable. Soft things are really easy to bend, like towels and flower petals.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Four corners are four corners!

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both by now, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of greatness? Great!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The only thing a great person doesn't do is make errors (えら). That's what makes them so great. They can always sense when an error is about to happen and they correct it before it even has a chance!

meaning.explanation: The land inside of a residence is called the grounds or the premises. Only really big residences have land inside them big enough to be called the "grounds" though.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Soft prohibition isn't going to be as bad as jail or prison. They went soft on you, so you're only under house arrest. That's not so bad, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い all the way at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. Confused is already an adjective and this word is a little different. Usually when you get confused it's because you were already hurried, busy, and things were hectic. So this adjective is what causes your confusion.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading, so you should be able to read this already!

meaning.explanation: If you want to char fish for dinner it will dry up because of your own impatience. Charring fish takes time and if you're too uneasy and shove it too far in the fire it will dry out, burn, and get gross.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The inside cause is an internal cause. Internal causes are usually the nastiest causes, if you ask me. This word is mostly used in the fields of medicine and psychology. You’ll often see it as 内因性, which is a technical term used to talk about factors that originate within a person or an organism.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Laws are standard in society. You must have laws and regulations in society. 法規 is a formal term commonly used in legal and bureaucratic contexts. In everyday conversation, people are more likely to use simpler terms, such as 法律 for laws or 規則 for rules and regulations.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A lotus flower is a lotus flower!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 花 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something is on the lotus flower... something little and kinda shiny. It's a little gecko (げ). It's hiding in the lotus and trying to catch flies. How cute!

meaning.explanation: If you have a residence that's also your house, it's still your residence. But you probably have a lot of money if you can own your own house, so it's probably a nice, big mansion too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This may look like an adjective, but it's actually the noun version of the kanji watered. Watered things, like plants, hold a lot of moisture in them.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 潤う, so you should know this one too.

meaning.explanation: A fire in a bottle that makes a big fire when thrown is called a Molotov Cocktail. Don't throw them in the house please.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually these types of mounds are burial mounds. (There's bodies under there!)

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Before you can give an explanation of who you are to someone you're about to meet, you have to nod or bow as a greeting first. It's rude to start explaining who you are before you greet them.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 会 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone bows to you, you always feel a little uncomfortable, so you say, "Eh" (え) and try to get them to stop. You're so uncomfortable that you can't think of words and "eh" is all you can manage to get out.

meaning.explanation: Corner corners are still corners. Sometimes they're the corners TO corners, so they're the little nooks and crannies that are hard to get at.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice, with the second one rendaku'd. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If your brain can't stop pouring out all the explanations your teacher gives you, you'll need to keep notes. That way when the information pours out of your head, you'll still have your comments and annotations to help you remember the teacher's explanations later.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A public residence is the one you tell everyone for things like documents and loans and stuff. That means it's your official residence and it's in everyone's books.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A government residence is one that is assigned to government officials. That means it's their official residence, and it goes on all their official paperwork.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: I request and then I request again. So many requests, but nobody will listen to me. My last hope is to get a bunch of people who have the same ideas together and make a petition.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You are determined to get an agreement out of people so you decide to be really positive with them. As long as you make it seem like everything is super great, and totally good for them, they'll end up agreeing with everything you say.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When medicine is sent to your direction it's going to you. That's your  prescription. Note that 薬方 isn't commonly used in modern Japanese. You might encounter it in historical or fictional settings, where it can add a distinct flavor to the narrative.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: A private residence is a private residence!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The remaining surplus is the remainder or residual left over. Just bear in mind that this is a technical word that you'll mostly see in legal and financial contexts.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: The fat that comes out of the wood from trees is used to make resin. Trees don't have fat, you say? Well you're wrong, look it up. Trees are super fat and we use the resin from them to do all sorts of stuff.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Rhythm is 律動, but by adding a 的 in there we get the adjective version of that word, making it rhythmical or rhythmic. Note that リズミカル and テンポのいい are much more common words to use for "rhythmical" and “rhythmic” respectively, but you may sometimes see 律動的 in formal writing.

reading.explanation: The reading is the same as 律動. The 的 part you should also be able to read by now.

meaning.explanation: Clear flat is one way to write the Japanese given name Ryohei.  Some well-known people with the name include metal sculptor Miyada Ryohei (宮田 亮平), actor Suzuki Ryohei (鈴木 亮平), and model and actor Ōtani Ryohei (大谷 亮平), who acts in both Japanese and Korean films and dramas.

reading.explanation: Unlike most Japanese names, this one actually uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Yay for easy names!

meaning.explanation: This isn't just any lotus. It's THE lotus. The Sacred Lotus. When you see it blooming all alone in a murky pond, you'll know.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The sacred lotus has (はす) a strong significance (and probably some powers). It has something at least, just remember it has something special going on, and you'll be fine.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The best time to plant seedlings is at night (なえ). If you plant them at night they'll sleep through the whole transplanting process and they'll wake up happy and ready to grow.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that 隻 is generally used to count relatively large vessels, like ships or even whole fleets.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: The skin under your skin is still skin. The extra layer is there to make sure when you get little cuts they don't bleed all over the place.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's another way of saying wise? Smart or discerning.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you do to get so smart? You sat (さと) in class all day. You didn't even get up after class was over. You planted your butt down and sat in your desk until class started again the next morning. You absorb knowledge through your behind, so as long as you sat down all day, you sucked up all the knowledge in the world!

meaning.explanation: Suburbs on the outside of town are still suburbs. They're sometimes called the outskirts of town too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Suburbs near you are still suburbs. They're all pretty much the same.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The mountain summit is still called the summit.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you try to call upon someone by screaming for them, you're probably trying to summon them. It's a little bit more serious than just calling them over casually. Maybe you're summoning someone to court, or summoning a magical creature in a video game. Pretty serious stuff.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A seedling letter is the very first letter you learn when you're little. What's the first thing you learn to spell when you're little? Your surname! You need to know who your family is, otherwise if you get lost or something happens, you won't know how to get home! Or even who you are!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: 世界 means "world" and 恐慌 means "panic" or "scare," so when you put them together you get a scare that made the entire world panic. This is how we refer to The Great Depression. It was caused by and subsequently resulted in everybody in the whole world panicking together about money.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

meaning.explanation: The kanji is threat and the noun version (here) is threat or a threat. Curious about the difference between 脅し and 脅迫? Both involve threats or intimidation, but the key distinction is the level of severity. 脅し is generally associated with milder forms of intimidation and coercion, while 脅迫 entails more direct and serious threats that may even break the law.

reading.explanation: Think about a threat being sent to you. It's in the form of bad odor (おど). Yuck, what a nasty way to send a threat.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil, so the verb version is to boil. It can also be used to mean to get excited, because you're boiling with that excitement.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to boil for dinner tonight? Walrus (わ). Boiled walrus is a delicacy where you're from, and the only way to be able to eat its yummy walrus flesh is to boil it for a long time until it's soft. Mmm smells good.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call, so the verb version is to call, as in calling someone over. 召す is an honorific verb, so it's used to talk about the actions of social higher-ups. 召す suggests the image of a superior who summons someone or something to themselves, hence the main meaning to call. But it can also be a polite way to say to take, like when they take a meal or a drink, and to wear when talking about their clothes.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If a noble decides to call you over, don’t look them in the 目 (め). That's super rude! To show respect when you're called, turn away your 目.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cover, so the verb version is to cover or to hide.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to cover yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "おお!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you おお at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.

meaning.explanation: If you humbly do something you are going to humbly receive, to humbly accept, or eat or drink it. Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. And you can use this word for all of them!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You technically already know this reading! You know how people say いただきます? Well that's the same as this! You're humbly receiving your meal. So to humbly receive is いただく!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means between, so the verb version is to put between or to sandwich.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means roast, and the verb version is to roast or to toast. This verb is most commonly used when referring to dry roasting things like coffee, tea, or beans.

reading.explanation: Do you know what animal likes to roast and to toast things? Eagles (い)! They're always roasting coffee beans and the like. That's how they stay so alert.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scream, so the verb version is to scream or to shout.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you want to shout at someone you should pick a word that will really hit them. Give them a big whammy (わめ) to the face! Hey, that word works. Shout WHAMMY!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed, so the verb version is what happens when you immerse something in a liquid. It's to soak or to dip.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 浸る, so you should know this one too.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plow, so the verb version is to plow or to till.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to till your land because you want to have a tiger yard (たがや). That's either when you have a yard full of live tigers, or you plant bushes and shape them into tigers. I hope it's the second kind of tiger yard. Either way, you have to plow the land to get it ready.

meaning.explanation: Wash wash to wash your clothes. You wash wash your laundry. Hmm wash wash sounds like the sound my laundry machine makes when it's washing my underpants.
