meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Someone comes up to you and asks, "Hey, do you want your stomach to swell like that?" How dare they ask you about your stomach. You respond with, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" It's none of their business how much you want your stomach to expand.

meaning.explanation: Just because you have to wait for special treatment doesn't mean it's not still good treatment. And just because everyone didn't cheer when you arrived, doesn't mean you're getting a cold reception, you know? Maybe they're planning a surprise party for you or something... yeah.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You should deal with and change your treatment of certain people depending on what kind of situation you're in. This vocab is just the same, making this dealing with or treatment

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: People who are biased about what they eat usually only eat sweet stuff like candy and ice cream. This picky eating gives them a really unbalanced diet. Candy and ice cream are okay, but you have to be open to eating other things too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Who do you sacrifice as an offering to the gods? A poor victim will be your sacrifice.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sometimes volcanoes erupt with just smoke instead of lava or fire. That's called an volcanic smoke.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is it. You're finally here. This is the moment where you learn the true meaning behind WaniKani!

reading.explanation: You should be able to read this on your own. And seriously... if you ever get this one wrong we're gonna show up at your house and look down at you with really, really disappointed looks on our faces. Don't let us down, kids.

meaning.explanation: Water erupts from water fountains. Sometimes they're big eruptions and sometimes they're small, but they're always fun to watch and enjoy in the hot summer.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you take along your leadership over and over, you're on a winning streak! You can expect successive victories in consecutive championships.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for は becoming ぱ.

meaning.explanation: If you can't wait to oppress people when you grow up, you're the kind of person who's prone to inflicting abuse on other people. You should try to correct that right away.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The fee you charge to produce your draft is called an advance for manuscript. Also known as copy money.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Expose what you want to expose by making an announcement. Then show the world!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 露 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're making the announcement from a row (ろう) boat. People will pay more attention when you're in a row boat because it's kind of weird. Especially since you're in a row boat on a stage.

meaning.explanation: If you have all the time in the world you can do whatever you want at any time.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To oppress people and then kill them is an atrocity. It's also called a massive killing because that's what you're actually doing. And you're awful, why would you ever do that?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: In reality, carp are usually black carp. The colored ones aren't as common, people just wish they were.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you board a plane or a car to take a ride it's called boarding or embarkation. You have to get on the right way or you can't ride.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should know those readings for both of these kanji by now, so you should be good to go.

meaning.explanation: To compete in a rowboat is to take part in a boat race, also known as a regatta. Who are you gonna bet on?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The inflation of boiling water means that bubbles are being inflated in there and bubbling to the top. This is called boiling, or if it's happening in a person it's called seething.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: People who have the same cells as you are your brethren, they're your brothers!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: When something has already been boarded and put onto something, it comes built in. 搭載 refers to something built into or onto another object, which generally is a vehicle or a machine.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Thin cells are what make up our bodies. They're still cells but they can also be called biological cells.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you cleanse water it becomes clean water that you can drink.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The origin of your collar is your collar! And the nape of the neck because that's where collars go.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A brocade carp is a fancy way of saying it's a carp that has a lot of pretty colors on it. It's a colored carp or a colored koi.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The commander of the whole army is just called " the commander." No one knows his real name and everyone is too afraid to ask.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The remainder of oppression is cruelty. Even when you're done oppressing people the brutality you caused will linger in their minds and hearts.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Failure that causes disaster is a crushing failure and you were utterly beaten by your opponent.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Barbarians have melons too, but they're long and funny looking. Wait, those aren't melons, they're cucumbers! Barbarians must have mixed them up.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Cucumbers have cute ribs (きゅうり)! I mean just look at them. Cute little green ribs. Adorable!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: A withered tree is a dead tree and it's got really dry wood. Perfect for a campfire!

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes you'll see it spelled 枯木 without the kana too. Keep your eyes open for it!

meaning.explanation: Slender and thin things are very delicate and dainty. They're easily broken, so you have to be careful.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well the science of skin is dermatology!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you are trying to manage latitudes you're really trying to manage the details of something. Managing latitudes is just a fancy way of saying it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you don't want your thoughts to turn rust colored, you need to be diligent and studying, learning, and experiencing new things. Without diligence your brain and all your thoughts will get old, and stale, turning a rusty, gross color.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A disaster occurrence is just a disaster or a tragedy. Look away! 惨事 is a formal word for a tragic or gruesome event — the kind that's so distressing it makes you want to avert your eyes. It emphasizes the horror and emotional pain of the event.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sad disaster is one that's especially disastrous and tragic. It's the worst kind you can imagine.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Disastrous conditions in the weather lead to you seeing a disastrous scene. Just don't look outside and you won't see the horrible stuff out your window right now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you are enlightened enough you'll need to make your departure from this world into enlightenment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Enlighten the darkness of people's minds with instruction and they'll reach enlightenment like you did!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: All that comes out of a writing brush is essays. You can't paint or doodle, you have to write with it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: All places are everywhere.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you surpass your surplus then you have lots of excess stuff.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mysterious person is really really good at what they do. So good that they aren't exactly sure what is it they do, but you know they're definitely an expert at whatever it is.

reading.explanation: This reading for this word is mysteriously an exception (sorry). So here's a mnemonic to help: If you're such an expert you should be able to tell what anything is if someone asks you. Even this crow toe (くろうと). Crow toes are pretty hard to recognize, unless you're a professional crow guy. But I guess you are, huh?

meaning.explanation: A speed horse is a fast horse, and a fine horse. This word isn't very common, but it does come up in horse racing contexts, and creative writing.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji, which you already know. However, 馬 uses a bit of a special reading here: め. So here’s a mnemonic to help you remember this:  This fast horse is so fast that all you can see whenever it speeds past you are its shiny bright 目 (め). Imagine this fast horse zooming past you over and over, but all you ever see are its white 目.

meaning.explanation: The fat on an animal's body is called fatty meat. Some people really like to eat it and others really like to hate it.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 脂 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Mmm, all that fatty meat. Think about fatty meat on your own body. If you have a lot of fatty meat, then you need a way to support said fatty meat. To do that, you would use a bra (あぶら).

meaning.explanation: The fiber you use to maintain your own health is the fiber you eat!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Even if you follow all the people you've ever met, you're still following them. Once a follower, always a follower.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 追 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They get you to follow them by yelling TWEET (つい)! Birds tend to follow each other, and something about hearing them tweeting at you makes you feel like you have to follow them.

meaning.explanation: The commander's origin was as the general of the army. He stepped down, but that's where he started. Maybe he's working the system backwards...

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you go gently you're actually going slowly. You can't be gentle if you don't move slowly.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you do it gently gently then you're only doing it gradually. You have to go slowly if you want to be as gentle as possible.

reading.explanation: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

meaning.explanation: The main shop is the main shop or the head office.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Humbly receive something and you'll be humbly receiving it. Or humbly eating it if they gave you food and not a puppy or something inedible. It can also mean humbly having. The theme here is humility! This is usually formal when written in kanji and used together with a verb like する. It can also be used alone to make very casual requests. In casual requests, it's still written in kanji in novels and other creative writing, but is generally written in hiragana anywhere else.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because たい becomes だい here.

meaning.explanation: Latitude degrees are still known as latitude.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Lotus root is lotus root.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your original draft is called a manuscript.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Bite into a melon and what do you taste? Uni reese's pieces (うり)! Did you know that? The next time you eat a melon see if you can taste the difference!

meaning.explanation: What do a warship and a rowboat have in common? In wartime they're both considered military vessels.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you face a lot of disasters in your life you're going to be really miserable. It's a shame, but it's hard to be anything but sad when your life is full of disastrous stuff.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You'll be really miserable if you find out you're going to have a really 短い (みじ) life.

meaning.explanation: The region of darkness in days of old referred to Mongolia. At least in China, where this word comes from. Imagine all those ancient Mongol tribes at the dark, unknown edges of China. Everything beyond the borders was shrouded in (figurative) darkness, I guess. No wonder they picked these kanji back then.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: North latitude is north latitude or northern latitude.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You end up writing your rough draft on some grass leaves because you forgot your notes. This grass will serve as your notes now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A bed just for seedlings is called a nursery. It's where all the little seedling grow before they're sold or replanted outside.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A latitude line can also be called a parallel.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you pave and attire something, you’ll end up with a pavement. Imagine the asphalt used in the paving of a street as its attire and this’ll make sense!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Pure cleansed things are pure and clean.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Land where all the people have been cleansed and purified is the Pure Land of Buddhism.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Purify water to change it from being dirty. This is called purification. It's important to purify water before you drink it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What's the city of flat soil? Pyongyang in North Korea. Which is pretty misleading, it's got more than a bunch of flat dirt, but back in the old days before the illustrious Kim Jong line built it up, that's all that was there.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It can also be pronounced the way we say it in English sometimes too. That's ピョンヤン, if you're wondering, and these kanji are used for it too.

meaning.explanation: If there is only semi criticism on a law ratification is still possible. It's only if everyone criticizes it that it won't be ratified.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A scarlet colored carp is called a red carp and sometimes a golden carp because sometimes people don't understand colors.

reading.explanation: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

meaning.explanation: If you have a surplus surplus it's a little redundant and you end up having a surplus of surpluses!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What indicates that you've been enlightened enough to reach enlightenment? A revelation! That's the only way you can know you've been enlightened enough.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Jasmine child is one way to write the girl's name Riko. Imagine fashioning a child out of jasmine, and calling her Riko. Examples of people named Riko include pop star and singer Fukumoto Riko (福本 莉子) and idol and actress Nakayama Riko (中山 莉子).

reading.explanation: You learned this reading for 莉 with the kanji, and I bet you're very familiar with this reading for 子 by now. A lot of Japanese girls' names that end in 子, too.

meaning.explanation: If you only comprehend one guy, make that guy Ryoichiro. The name 諒一郎 isn't very common, but it's worth learning because the kanji 諒 is used in lots of names, and both 諒 and 一郎 are names in their own right. So by learning this name, you should be able to read a whole lot of other names, too.

reading.explanation: You learned all the readings in this name with the kanji. What could be easier to comprehend?

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 巻く means "to roll?" Well the thing you roll up around your collar is a scarf!

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A seedling tree is still a seedling.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you purify your self you are performing self purification.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that you won’t actually see this used as a standalone word very often, except in the phrase 舗を構える (to open a shop), but even that is fairly rare!

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: A shop shop is still a shop.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When barbarians sit they only sit cross legged. Sitting on your feet hurts and they don't care how they look, so they're going to be comfortable and cross their legs.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you're sitting cross legged lots of people will think you're a grouch (あぐら). Back in the day sitting like this was thought to be really manly, and if you were a woman who did it they'd call you a grouch too.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well when your skin is sick, you have a skin disease. You should probably go to a dermatologist right away.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Soil soil is still soil.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: South latitude is south latitude or southern latitude.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The child of a cell is a spore. They're just as tiny and they're floating all around you right now.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Throw your draft at people to post it on their Facebook wall! Wait, that's not how it works? Hush, yes it does, just throw it harder.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Tall inflation of prices means that there was a sudden price jump and it's waaaay more expensive than it used to be.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sudden inflation results in a sudden rise of prices, aka a sharp rise or a jump in prices.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Violent inflation causes a sudden rise in prices. It sucks.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means summit and this word means summit, peak, top and crown, most often in reference to mountains.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You should already know this reading from when you learned 頂く. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the place you take a bath in is the bathroom!

reading.explanation: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 場. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 偏る, so you should be able to read this one too!

meaning.explanation: A space as empty as the sky is a blank space. You're probably supposed to fill that in with something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Tray planting is bonsai. It makes sense because that's exactly what you're doing: planting a tree in a tray! 盆栽 refers both to the art of cultivating these miniature trees in small trays (or pots), as well as to those bonsai trees themselves.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Who works for peace and is held in high esteem? A Buddhist high priest. They work harder than anyone else to reach world peace so they're held in very high esteem.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 和 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing you ever hear the Buddhist High Priest say is "Oooooo" (お). It must be some kind of Buddhist humming or chanting. Every time you think about him you hear that o sound in your head.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Describe someone's merit at a ceremony for the conferring of decorations. That's when medals are given out to people who deserve them. Usually in the military or something.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, and that is its most common reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In your mind, the only person who can wear a crown is Bill Murray. He asks you, "Can I wear the crown?" and you say "Yes you can, Murray (かんむり)". Murray goes ahead and puts on the crown. He's movie royalty, after all.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of a man who is cruel. Doesn't matter who, but pick one that you know of that is actually cruel. He can be a real person or someone in a movie or on TV. What does this man do? He do (ひど) cruel things.

meaning.explanation: A cruel cool person is more cruel and coldhearted than just a normal cruel person. It's probably because they're cold all the time and it makes them mad. You should stay away from people like that.

meaning.explanation: If it looks like a silver apricot, it's probably a ginkgo. Ever seen a ginkgo nut from a ginkgo tree? They really do look like little silver apricots. (Go ahead and google it if you don't believe me.)

reading.explanation: This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out: Before you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ぎんこう but that's wrong. Stop that now. When you think of the ginkgo tree meaning, think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for eagles (い), but evil Mrs. Chou (ちょう) likes to eat eagles AND whole ginkgo trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND STILL ALIVE. So いちょう. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And ginkgo trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo. The other reading is for the ginkgo nut meaning. The nut tastes like 銀 (ぎん) naan (なん). Mmm, soft and metallic — but still not a jukugo word. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.

They make your body more efficient overall, which includes your metabolism, so make sure you’re always wearing a tie for that metabolism boost!

While it might sound a bit old-fashioned, you can still use it to describe something heavenly. For example, if you're soaking in a cozy, relaxing hot spring, you could say, "Ahhh…極楽!"

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. 極 has two on'yomi readings, though. So here's a mnemonic to help you remember which one to use: In paradise, you meet Goku (ごく) from Dragon Ball Z. He grins and tells you he's taking a break from extreme battles and enjoying the extreme comfort of this heavenly paradise.

So your mama would baa (まば) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!

meaning.explanation: This is a combination of the words 貫く meaning "To Go Through" and 通す meaning "To Let Pass." So when you're trying to go through an area and also let someone pass with you, you start to follow them. Not intentionally, but you're both trying to go through at the same time so you decide to stick with them.

reading.explanation: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start to grow senile. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you start to grow senile you'll make a new friend. It's Bobo (ぼ) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.

meaning.explanation: If you're stupid when it comes to sounds, then you're tone deaf.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect and lazy, so the verb version is to neglect or to be idle.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You decide to neglect everything. Your school, your family, even your own name (なま). You've managed to slack for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wholesale, so the verb version is to sell wholesale.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deviate, so the verb version is to turn away or to avert.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to turn away from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just so-so (そ). But that's not enough to keep your interest.

meaning.explanation: The sky has an air of neglect about it and makes it seems like everything you're doing is in vain. Why even bother? The sky doesn't even believe in you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already learned that 犠牲 means "victim," so when you add someone to that, it still means victim.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  A whale is actually gojira's (godzilla) cool cousin kujira (くじら). Godzilla mutated from a whale, so they're still related. That's where he gets his name from!

meaning.explanation: Whale meat is whale meat.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you catch a whale you're whaling, and that's illegal now so you should probably put the whale back.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sell something at the wholesale price and it's... well it's wholesale.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes it's spelled 卸売り too.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: When you sell something at wholesale value it's being sold at a wholesale price.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Accumulate and accumulate make accumulation!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What do you wear to heal a really serious injury? An adhesion. Okay, so you don't actually wear these, but your body makes them for your insides to wear so you can heal. Nice job insides!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Erase one part of your feelings and you'll only feel a little bit of them.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A soldier only lays herself down when she's about to ambush the enemy! If you see some soldiers laying around, it's not that they're lazy, it's because they're getting ready to pounce!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: All you can do is consider your grief and how it's ruining your life. That's called anxiety, and it can be a real problem. You end up being concerned about everything, but don't worry. There are ways to combat it. You'll be okay!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Dedicate yourself to doing the best at school by having perfect attendance! That's how you can show you're really dedicated to learning.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Dedicate your life to what you believe in and you'll have really strong belief and faith in whatever that thing is. Just try to dedicate yourself to something nice.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Connect a bunch of things laying in a line. Something's happening here. You can't put your finger on it, but you're pretty sure this is foreshadowing for something else.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You've got a combination of China and 揚げ, meaning "fried." That makes this Chinese-style Fried Chicken, or as you'll probably also know it, karaage. While 唐揚げ most often refers to fried chicken, it can technically also refer to other deep fried meats, fish, or vegetables. As it's the most common meaning, remembering this as "fried chicken" will be just fine, though.

reading.explanation: You know how to read the 揚げ part, but this uses the kun'yomi reading for 唐, which is new. You'll likely be able to remember this reading by associating fried chicken with Japanese karaage, but in case you're not familiar with it, here's a mnemonic to help you: To make this kind of fried chicken, you have to first give it one strong からて chop. If you fry it up without that からて chop, it just comes out terrible no matter what you do. So just remember that next time you make it for me, kay?

meaning.explanation: A VIP comes to your door. They're your guest! I hope you aren't going to make them sleep in the couch.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A VIP guest is a guest of honor. They're even more important than a normal guest.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A healing cure will be great for healing sick people.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When something is not equal is of course unequal. It's an inequality. You'll usually see this word in technical contexts like math and engineering, but it does pop up in more general formal writing, too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You’ll need a heavy dose to tranquilize yourself enough to be a leader. It can pretty stressful to be a leader so most of them are sedated. Tranquilize yourself too and you'll be just like them!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Nearby there is a beautiful view. Look on as the sun sets and the sky changes color. You would give up anything to be able to spectate this kind of thing all the time.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your team was about to win the game but you decided to be frugal with your shots near the end and it resulted in defeat, making it a loss of a close game. If you had just taken those shots your team probably would have won. What a regrettable defeat.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: At dawn what's the first thing you're supposed to see? Your master. He wants you to wake him up and bring his slippers.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Erase your need for normal tea by drinking matcha. It is far superior to all others and you'll never turn back once you've had a taste.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Only accept new people moving in nearby once you've finished properly monitoring them! Tapping into their phones will probably help too, but don't tell anyone I told you to do that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Follow people who grieve by mourning with them. You don't want to be the only one who doesn't seem sad.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading with the word 追随, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You're mourning the loss of your pet bird. You can't help but yell TWEET (つい) to the sky, hoping she'll come back to life. It doesn't work so you stay in a state of mourning for the rest of your life. She was your best bird friend, after all.

meaning.explanation: Proceed to a new place to do your duty. That's just a fancy way to say you're about to move for a different job. This is usually a job at the same company you're already at, it's just a different position for you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something nearby is near to you. It's very close.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  There is a restaurant near your house that only sells dishes with soba (そば) noodles in them. They're delicious, but it's so close to your home that you can smell them all the time. Sometimes it feels like that's all you'll ever smell anymore.

meaning.explanation: The origin of dawn can be found on New Year's Day. That's when the new sun is born and rises above the earth for a whole year until it dies. And that's the origin of dawn, children. Don't let your teachers tell you otherwise.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 元 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who's always there on the dawn of New Year's Day welcoming the new sun? Gandhi (がん). He sits on the edge of the earth and makes sure the sun feels welcome. What a nice guy.

meaning.explanation: A valuable VIP is a noble visitor. They're probably a queen or a diplomat or something. So you better treat them really well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To erase or kill something results in total obliteration. This word refers to the erasure, denial, ignoring, or killing of something's very existence. It can even mean murder in some cases.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You must not consider this a theory, because of course it's a fact. Needless to say, this is the way things are. This word is often written in kana, but it's worth knowing the kanji version too.

reading.explanation: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. Needless to say, you should be able to read this on your own!

meaning.explanation: An elderly shop is an old shop.

reading.explanation: This reading is an exception, so here's a mnemonic: You go to an old shop and come across a sheep knee sale (しにせ). When you ask what a sheep knee sale is, the clerk tells you quite matter-of-factly that it's a sale on all the sheep knees. You've never seen this in newer shops, so it must be a pretty old practice to buy and sell sheep knees.

meaning.explanation: You only have time to do one thing at dawn once. Dawn is really short so you can do whatever it is for a moment, but that's it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Trace the enclosure of a wheel on paper and you'll have drawn its outline.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you ask me to tell the truth I'll say your face is shaped like a melon. No no, it's not a bad thing! You just have a really oval face!

reading.explanation: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 瓜 and 顔, but in the middle there, 実 has a bit of an exceptional reading. You certainly haven't learned this weirdness before, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know who has an oval face? Zayn (ざね) formerly from One Direction. When you think of handsome oval faces, picture Zayn's.

meaning.explanation: Tranquilize your pain with a strong dose of painkillers! Yum yum. Don't take too many though!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Whenever something bad happens to your country to feel an exceptional amount of grief for your fellow country people. This is some serious patriotic concern you've got going on. Let's hope you use those concerns for something good and don't get too carried away.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A pleasant pleasant person is super pleasant! They're happy and nice to everybody all the time!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Catch a captive and he'll be a prisoner of war. Or, if you're not in a war, just an ordinary captive.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Overgrown prosperity is still prosperity. Why, it's even thriving. Nice!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Melons from the south are lumpy and orange, sometimes orange and green because they try to look like the hot sun. Wait, those aren't melons, they're pumpkins and squash. Or... kind of a mix of the two, if you already know what kabocha tastes like.

reading.explanation: The reading for this is an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Japanese pumpkins don't taste like American pumpkins. They taste more like canned boiled chocolate (かぼちゃ). Oh, you don't know that either? Well then just taste the pumpkin and you'll know what that tastes like too. This word is also sometimes read なんきん, especially in the east of Japan.

meaning.explanation: If you leave behind something and it makes you feel remorse it's a really regrettable situation. You should probably go back for whatever it was so you won't lead an unsatisfactory life.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: To tranquilize souls you have to a have a mass repose of souls. Then their souls will move on to the next life and stop hanging around here, haunting umbrellas.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your home is out in the middle of a coarse looking field. Whenever you bring friends over the only word they say to describe your dirt and grass home is that it's rustic. That's pretty rude of them, you love your dirt home! Even if it is kinda small and stinky and in a field.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Distant fat makes up the Japanese given name Ryota. Imagine soccer player Noguchi Ryota (野口 遼太) kicking a fat soccer ball into the distance while voice actor Asari Ryota (浅利 遼太) commentates.

reading.explanation: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You haven't learned this particular on'yomi for 太 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ryota's diet consists only of tacos (た). Tacos, tacos, tacos for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Yum!

meaning.explanation: Dedicate yourself to the public by doing community service!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: People made from simple elements are also pretty simple. And they can be naive too. But that's just how they're built.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your pudding congealed and is all hard. How on earth did it solidify like this? It shouldn't freeze unless you put it in the freezer. Unless, did you? Oh...

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Marrow that gives you stature is inside of your spinal cord.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Freeze and look at me. Your stare is giving me the creeps! You can move now. Hey. You can move now. Stop I said!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A VIP from another country is a state guest.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A father you've inherited isn't your original father, he's your stepfather.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. This word can also be read as ままちち, because 継 can take the special reading まま when it's used as the prefix "step," as in "stepfather."

meaning.explanation: Accumulate enough of a good reputation at your company in advance and you'll be able to have successive promotions. You'll be boss in no time!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Tranquilize pressure with medication that helps with its suppression. Then you won't have to feel it anymore.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Bow as you descend into enemy territory. This is how you have to surrender if you want to live. Keep your head nice and low and descend into their ranks.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Note that this is almost always written in kana in modern Japanese.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tranquilize, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's to appease or to suppress.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You want to appease her because she's (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how to calm her down!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grieve, so the verb version is to grieve or to be anxious.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Your aunt starts to grieve really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "Ooh, Ray (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start to be distressed like that in public.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frugal, so the verb version is to be frugal or to be sparing.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You should try to be frugal when you go to the ocean (おし). There are lots of things to buy, like delicious food, sun hats, and tofugu dolls, but you really shouldn't spend all your money there. Try to plan on spending less when you head to the ocean next time, okay?

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means congeal or freeze, so the verb version is to grow stiff. Remember 肩こり (shoulder stiffness)? This is where that こり part comes from. 凝る also means  to be passionate about something. Think of it this way: your passions are freezing onto one thing, so you're going to be into that thing.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What have all your friends started to be passionate about? Their 子s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.

meaning.explanation: The prefecture with lots of horse chestnut trees is Tochigi prefecture.

reading.explanation: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 栃 and 木 and the on'yomi for 県, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that き is changed to ぎ here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bow or lay, so the verb version is what when you try to cover or to hide something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Who's that you're trying to cover up? It's your fool (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying to hide him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.

meaning.explanation: This is a combination of the words 据える, meaning "to install," and 付ける, meaning "to attach." Put them together and you're still going to install something or to equip something. There's just more hands on work happening.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Wake up, now lay yourself down, now wake up again, okay now lay again. What you're doing is called undulation. If your emotions do it it's called ups and downs. Everyone goes through stuff like this sometimes.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: A leap of likeness is when something that's not real takes a big leap towards the likeness to reality. This happens when something is vividly depicted or clearly expressed. This word is generally used in the phrase 面目躍如たる, which functions as an adjective to exemplify someone’s honor.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you dig up hollyhocks in the mountains, and grind up their roots, you'll have wasabi! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off.

reading.explanation: This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!

meaning.explanation: You already learned that 披露 means "announcement" or "display," so add a banquet to that and you're at a wedding reception! Or if no one's getting married but they're showing off something at a big place with food and stuff it's a just a normal reception.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Life in Japan was increasing at its fastest rate during the Yayoi Period. It's one of the earliest periods of history in Japan that we know about! You should look it up, if you don't already know about it.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception but it's the same in Japanese as it is in English. So if you just remember it's Yayoi (やよい) in English, you'll remember the Japanese too!

meaning.explanation: Having a furthermore renewal means things become all the more... good, bad, cute, ugly, whatever it is you’re talking about! Or, on the opposite side of things, still less.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone keeps saying furthermore and also over and over again. Just when you think they've stopped, they turn around and say "and yet," before going back to repeating furthermore and besides again and again. It's driving you crazy.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Hands beating together is actually applause. Though... you might be doing it wrong if you're actually beating them together.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

So when you think back to the first things you learned in addition to your own family name, think centigrade! Of course, in reality, these kanji were simply chosen for their pronunciation rather than their meaning, but hopefully that mnemonic will help you remember which kanji are used here!
