It's true, you don't know this clownfish, but you want to. I guess all of them are afraid of strangers though... how will you know me if you don't give me a chance, clownfish?!

meaning.explanation: If you're only blind to color then you have color blindness.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Spread out a needle in a tray of water after rubbing it with a magnet and you'll have made a compass! Try it at home kids! It really works!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Accept a child into your womb with conception. Now there's a baby in there!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Express your unique idea of condolence by offering your condolences and sympathy to people who are going through hard times.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Membranes that wrap around at an angle are in your eye. Eyes are round and the membranes have to bend around the front part at an angle. It's called your cornea.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Fall into the life of a degenerate and you'll probably get involved in lots of corruption. Stealing, stabbing, money laundering, that kind of stuff.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you spread out some netting enough you'll be covering everything. But you can only do that if you spread it out really far.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: This is the adverb version of the kanji daring, so it means dare to or daringly.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're about to daringly jump off a cliff and you shout, "AAAHHH (あ)!" to get your courage up! You always have to yell AAHH before you dare to do daring things!

meaning.explanation: Put a thick drop of navy blue paint on a canvas and it will look like an even bolder dark navy blue.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You use your daring and just go! You made a decisive action by just going like that! It was go or not go and you chose go!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A fat drum is still a drum. This word can be used for any type of drum, but a common one in Japan is the taiko. There are lots of different types of taiko, and most of them are big and fat, and make a lovely deep sound. They're super cool to watch and play! If talking about taiko drums specifically, you can also say 和太鼓 to be clear that you're not talking about any old drums.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You can hear something beat because of a membrane in your ear called an eardrum. Make sure you don't stick your fingers too far in your ear or you could really hurt it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A child that's still in a womb is a fetus.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Spread out a complete row of numbers in the right order and you have enumeration!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The one element you need to ferment something is an enzyme. That breaks whatever you're trying to ferment down in just the right way.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Equal out your equilibrium and you'll have solid equilibrium.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It’s a universal truth that we are the continuation of our experiences and history. The original meaning of this word is journey, or travels, in the literal sense of the word, but nowadays you’d usually use it more abstractly, to talk about things like your past experiences, or perhaps your spiritual journey.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you ferment something it makes a departure from what it originally was and transforms during fermentation into something new.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you're involved in a daring struggle you need to be strong and fight bravely. Even if you might get hurt, you should do your best!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A tank of water can be used as a fish tank or a water tank for drinking. It really only depends on you and how many fish you have.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sprout that sprouts can thank germination for being able to sprout nice and big and strong.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 芽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When a plant sprouts out of the ground it's still a baby so all it can say is goo goo ga ga (が).

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, but wait! It's not an adjective, it's just a noun (tricky, tricky). The kanji means grief, so this word means grief or distress.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 憂える. Remember that and you'll remember this!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: What do you hit to make a sick beat? A cool little hand drum.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You like to use your hand drum when two dudes meet (つづみ). You drum and tap it and it as they high five and it makes them super uncomfortable which makes you super happy. That's why you love your hand drum so much.

meaning.explanation: What's universal? How many times do you think that question's been asked throughout time? Probably a lot of times.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes べん here.

meaning.explanation: The beat makes you want to dance. It's the inspiration you need to dance. The beat gives you encouragement to dance all night long. And without such a rockin' beat you would have lame dance moves.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you intercept trade and cut off a country from the rest of the world they'll be stuck in a state of isolation or if they have some kind of disease like zombie-itus, it's a quarantine.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The big intestines are called the large intestine, or the colon. It's where your poop goes and comes from!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Press uneven carvings into paper to make the newest edition of your magazine. What you're using is a letterpress. This made mass printing nice and cheap(ish) in Japan!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because はん becomes ぱん here.

meaning.explanation: Blood flows through your veins, carrying the stories of your lineage, your bloodline. Note that this word is quite formal and literary.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: Fell trees and gather them up. That's called lumbering. Or if you cut them all down and take every last one, it's deforestation and you should be ashamed!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you can dedicate yourself to going to a bunch of meetings and dealing with everyone's problems you'll make a good magistrate.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned either of these readings yet. Sorry! Here's a mnemonic to help you: The magistrate is the only person who's allowed to drink booze and eat gyoza (ぶぎょう). If you see someone simultaneously drinking booze and eating dumplings in Japan, you'll know that person is the magistrate!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Maple sugar is maple sugar!

reading.explanation: This word is more often read as ふうとう. You can figure out the reading by looking at the 風 portion of the kanji, remember its reading, and apply it here (ふう).

meaning.explanation: If you follow the law of rotation while you play music you'll end up with a lovely melody. If you don't, you'll miss all the cues on beat that rotation gives you and it will sound like crap.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: When someone quits living you need to offer your condolences during their memorial address. Let it all out and tell everyone what you thought about that dead guy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: One universal event can only happen once. It's too rare to happen more than that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because へん becomes ぺん here.

meaning.explanation: Imperial tea the color of a crow's feathers can only be the famous, delicious Oolong tea. It came from the imperial people of China to Japan (probably) and there are lots of different variants. But the leaves are all that blackish/grey crow feather color.

reading.explanation: This word takes the on'yomi readings except for 龍 which is an exception (sorry). You haven't learned the on'yomi for 烏 yet either, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves Oolong tea more than anyone else? Oooo Ron (うーろん) Weasley from Harry Potter. He's British, so of course you'd think he loves tea, but Oolong is his jam. Just picture him and think, oooooh it's Ron, when you drink this kind of tea. And make sure you remember that, because this is also a written in katakana when the kanji isn't used, to type out the long mark ー when you enter your answer.

meaning.explanation: If you're pale white, you're pale, or pallid. This word is usually used to talk about the pallor of someone's face.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word and uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned those readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Robbers who sail on the high seas are pirates! Arrr!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something comes out of a womb and is then put on a tray. It's the afterbirth. Yeah, yeah, eww. Grow up, it's a word you should know.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A ravine in a valley is still a ravine. It can also be a gorge or a canyon. They're usually really big. Like the Grand Canyon!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 谷 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're going to travel through a huge ravine you have to stay hydrated. The best thing to bring is some taste, cold Coke (こく). Nothing quenches your thirst from sweating through a long, rough ravine like delicious Coke!

meaning.explanation: A public building where you welcome VIP guests is a reception hall. Or a guest house if they're staying the night.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of frugal? It's regrettable or precious. If you're too frugal to buy something your actions are regrettable later when you realize you wanted that thing. If you're so frugal you only buy one single thing, it's very precious to you.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You made a regrettable decision. You didn't buy that clock you wanted and now it's been discontinued. The salesperson tells you this and all you can say is, "Oh..." (お) really really quietly. How disappointing.

meaning.explanation: A daring fruit is very resolute and bold! She's going to go out and be a fruit superhero or scientist or something.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The nerve netting in the back of your eye is made up of membranes called the retina. It's what lets light in to help you see!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An inspection you make of your homework before school is a revision. Sometimes proofreading will help you find mistakes before you hand it in too. Just make sure you look everything over.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It doesn't matter how many times a rotation goes around, it's still a rotation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your boss says she's going to decrease your salary with a company-wide salary reduction. You should probably start looking for a new job that won't do salary cuts like this.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

meaning.explanation: If you want to find some coarse salt just dive in the sea and collect sea salt! The pieces are nice and big and lumpy, so you really taste it when you're cooking.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If something is the latter, it can't be first, it has to be at least second. This works for lists too. So if you have A through D, it's going to be B. This word is also used as slang for おつかれさま, which is where the thanks meaning comes from. It can also be used as a prefix to mean chic.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Look in the sea and you'll see what looks like a crow moving under the water and it's a thief! It's stealing from all the fish. As it comes closer you see that it isn't a crow, it's a squid. Or a cuttlefish? One or the other.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is completely irregular, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You call the fish police to arrest that thieving squid, but it jumps into it's eagle car (いか) and makes a swift getaway. In case you didn't know, an eagle car is an eagle moonlighting as a car. The eagle car is zooming up into the sky, so there's no way the fish police can catch it now.

meaning.explanation: Intestines and stomach make up the stomach in your body.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The cultivation of a question mark is something that only people called Takuya can do. Imagine a famous Takuya, like actor and singer Kimura Takuya (木村 拓哉 a.k.a. キムタク), or a Takuya you know, cultivating a huge field of question marks. Rows and rows of question marks. I wonder what he's going to do with all those question marks once they're ready to harvest. Other people who must have an abundance of question marks are pro baseball player Kinoshita Takuya (木下 拓哉 a.k.a. キノタク) and actor, model, and K-Pop star Terada Takuya (寺田 拓哉).

reading.explanation: You learned both of these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this name on your own.

meaning.explanation: A robber who steals is a thief. And still a robber, I guess.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means brew, so the verb version is to brew or to distill.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to brew up some beer but not the regular boring stuff. You're going to make it from the water in the hump of a camel (かも). Camel beer is definitely not a horrible idea, right?

meaning.explanation: The kanji means healing and the verb version means to heal something, to cure something, and even to quench a thirst, both literally and metaphorically. As you can probably guess, this last use has a poetic feel to it. Like many verbs ending in す, this verb is transitive, meaning it's being done to something. So you can use it when you cure an illness, heal a broken heart, or quench your thirst for adventure!

reading.explanation: To heal something it's sometimes necessary to do something いや (gross). Even if you dislike it, even if it's gross, you do it anyway, because you want to heal whatever it is.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means intercept, so the verb version is to intercept or to interrupt.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you want to interrupt and to intercept is your roommate's sighing guitar (さえぎ). He keeps playing it and all it does is make these horrible, long sighing sounds. You want to interrupt it any cost.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means condolence, so the verb version is to mourn for or to condole.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You seem to mourn for things you really care about. Well then you would mourn for your toe mural (とむら). You had a mural made for your favorite toe so if anything were to happen to it, you would want to mourn for it.

meaning.explanation: You already learned that 鎮める means "to appease," but this one is what happens after they've been appeased. They start to quiet down.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you're in the library the librarian is always telling you to quiet down. She's (しず) so mean! She never lets you talk in the library. Who's mean to you? She's mean to you!!

meaning.explanation: Fell trees in intervals, instead of all at once, and it's called tree thinning. That way there's still some forest there, but you get your wood to use for other things too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: A surface covered in convex and concave parts is going to be really uneven and rough.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something normal and universal is still universal. Normally.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already learned that 愉快 means "pleasant" or "happy," so add not to that and you're unpleasant and unhappy.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This not writing law is a law that hasn't been written down. It's an unwritten law, like taking your shoes off and showering every day.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning.explanation: You already know that 循環 means "circulation" or "cycle," so adding bad to that makes it a vicious cycle.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You're only nearby while you are nearby, that's it.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you live as a normal human citizen you also have another life as a cutter walrus (かたわ)! That's a walrus that cuts fish up while eating. It's your secret double life. You do it at night while you are a human by day!

meaning.explanation: A rotation of wind forms a whirlwind, in both the physical and figurative senses. On the figurative side, it can also mean commotion and sensation.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out because ふう becomes ぷう here (hehe).

meaning.explanation: The mother of good fermentation is yeast! If you want to bake a pie or bread you have to have the best. And if you don't have any, maybe your neighbor has some extra that you can borrow?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Help and aid someone and you will help and aid them! Good job, you're a good person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Pardon someone out of the kindness in your heart and you'll have granted them amnesty. How kind of you.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You resent someone so much that you sigh with anger whenever they're around. Everything they do makes you feel really strong resentment.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Divide a body and untie its organs to perform an autopsy. You have to cut it all up and untangle the parts to see why this person or animal died.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Break down a beat into all of its children and you’ve got more than just a single beat. You’ve got an assortment of beats, making a rhythm, and setting a tempo. Additionally, this can also refer to the moment something happens. You’ll usually encounter this in the form of ~した拍子に. Have a look at our context sentences to see this usage in action!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of its kanji. However, 拍 uses its secondary reading, which you haven’t learned yet, so here’s a mnemonic to help you: You get the beat and the rhythm going in your body. You can't help but sing out loud, "Heyo (ひょう), heyo!" Feel that rhythm and sing with me! HEYO HEYO!

meaning.explanation: What is lapis lazuli glassy color? It's bright blue. If you've never seen the rock lapis lazuli, look it up and you'll see why this means bright blue! This word is generally used in literature.

reading.explanation: You learned all three of these readings when you learned the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If a mediator touches people the right way, they will become a catalyst for change. This could be good or bad change depending on what they stuck their hands in.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  A chicken is a 庭 (garden) 鳥 (bird) (にわとり). It's a bird that you keep in your garden, after all!

meaning.explanation: A chicken egg is a chicken egg.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 卵 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who loves chicken eggs? Randy (らん) Savage! Especially when he eats them with slim jims. Mmm eggs and slim jims. You should give it a try.

meaning.explanation: Foster a bunch of chickens and start chicken farming! They will be your best friends! Your only friends.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Chicken meat is chicken meat!

reading.explanation: This word uses a kun'yomi reading for 鶏 that you haven't learned yet (とり), plus the usual on'yomi for 肉. Sounds tricky, but remember how 鳥 is とり? Chicken meat is basically just bird meat, so think of it like that when you're trying to remember this reading!

meaning.explanation: Write down the years of your genealogy in order and it makes a chronological record of your life. Look back on it when you're old and sigh about the old days.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: At night you are served an evening drink. It's okay to have a strong drink with dinner every now and then.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The master of a fiefdom is the feudal lord. We also call them Daimyo.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: You give your congratulations to someone a few times because they seem so fresh and vibrant. You feel like you should because it must be nice to be like that still. Someday it will be gone, so make sure you say it a few times right away.

reading.explanation: The reading is just the kun'yomi reading (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

meaning.explanation: You play and play all day! What do you play? A game! Or a sport! Which are technically games!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Write down the scores people get from taking all of their opponent's chess pieces and you'll be writing down game records. This is usually only used for old-fashioned Japanese games like go and shogi. Let's see who has the highest score at the end!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your lineage and genealogy make up your genealogy, also known as your family history.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 紳士 means "gentleman?" Well when two men determine that the best thing to do is cooperate they form a gentlemen's agreement.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you're trying to be graceful and polite you have to keep your secret sheep toe (しと) under wraps. You're kind of fond of your sheep toe (it's unique after all) but you're careful to hide it when you want to be all modest and gentle and all that.

meaning.explanation: You want to lock this criminal's hands up so he won't go punching anymore grandpas. You need some handcuffs to make sure he doesn't go around being a criminal anymore. Then you can lock him up good.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for one kanji and the on'yomi reading for the other. You know them both, so this shouldn't be too hard to remember!

meaning.explanation: Remember how 縛る means "to tie?" Well if you tie something around someone's neck then it's called hanging. They'll probably die from it too, so it can also be death by hanging.

reading.explanation: This is a combination of the words 縛る and 首. Both use the kun'yomi readings, so just change the る to り and it's pretty simple!

meaning.explanation: If you look back in history and see someone of exceptional greatness, they're probably a hero. Not just a normal person, but an extraordinary person like Hercules or Mae Jemison.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who's shocked at everything all the time will seem like an idiot. At this point, putting your drinks in a glass shouldn't be surprising. I mean, come on. Only a fool lets himself be shocked by everything he sees.

reading.explanation: Remember when you learned 呆ける? Well just cut the る part off the end and it's exactly the same! If you can remember that, you'll remember this reading as well.

meaning.explanation: If it does not rot then it's immortal. It will live forever!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mediator jammed in the middle of a group of angry people ends up becoming the intermediary between them. The mediator can't just ignore what's happening around them, and they have the tools to fix this.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you cleanse a lapis lazuli rock until it goes glassy, you can use it in a joruri performance. In case you haven't heard of joruri, it's traditional Japanese chanted storytelling, sort of like a ballad, that's accompanied by shamisen music, and often puppets.

reading.explanation: You learned all these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Who is going to accompany the judge in deciding the results of the trial? The jury! They're the only other people besides the judge who can decide someone's fate in court.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A graceful woman is a proper, fancy lady.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: If you serve someone a certain quantity of understanding, you're making allowances. You're taking into consideration all extenuating circumstances.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You learned these readings with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Something you make that oozes with greatness is your masterpiece. The very best work you'll ever make in your entire life.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A mediator who works with someone who doesn't have a body has to use some kind of mortal media to record what they're saying. Print media? Sure. Electronic media? Alright? Ghost media? No! Humans can't read that stuff!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A muddy stream is a muddy stream!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A comforting score is a musical score. Music is really relaxing, and so is reading sheet music. You should try it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A spicy win is a narrow victory. Kind of makes sense, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already know that 弦楽 means "string music," so add some pipes to that, like trumpets and saxophones, and you'll have orchestral music. You can't have a whole orchestra with just the string section!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: An excuse and a pardon is a pardon or amnesty.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Form a pardon with your mouth and actually pardon someone. Show your forgiveness with the words "I'm sorry."

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A company requests consignment work and you take it to become a part time employee.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You take a dose of medicine but it gets locked in your throat because it's the kind of pill you chew, not swallow! You need to pay attention to which one is which or it won't help at all.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If the air is muddy and dirty it's because there is too much pollution in that area. You should wear a mask and be careful of contamination.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When art resembles the image of a person, it's a portrait. And it doesn't just resemble them, it captures their image perfectly. Now that's what I call a portrait.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you serve someone, you're pouring alcohol or pouring sake for them. You're filling someone's glass.

reading.explanation: You learned this reading with the kanji. Cheers!

meaning.explanation: This is the noun version of the kanji resent, so it means resentment.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You feel some pretty strong resentment toward your roommate because you had to touch their icky door (いきどお) today and it was covered in what you hope was glue. Or frosting. UHG what an icky door. This is an outrage!!!

meaning.explanation: You renew and alternate certain positions or people, making this a reshuffle, or dismissal. 更迭 generally highlights the dismissal of someone from a position for replacement. You’ll often see this used in political contexts, like the reshuffling of certain ministers or other offices in a cabinet or diet; or just in general for important positions in other fields as well.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: When you give up and just try to enjoy the view, that's resignation. You know things aren't going well, and you know you can't do anything about it now, so you resign yourself to what's to come.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 諦, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In resignation, you throw all of your tater (てい) tots onto the ground. Look at the tater tots at your feet. Now they're lying scattered there, a symbol of your feelings of resignation.

meaning.explanation: If you bustle and run around all day from being busy you end up running about to get them all done. You'll be busy getting it all done, but your efforts won't be in vain!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you sail in a ship you can't forget to bring a garden hoe (ほ). If you lose your sails or your paddles, you can always use a hoe to paddle your way back. Or if you wreck on an island you can use the hoe to garden so you won't die of starvation! Hoes are very handy!

meaning.explanation: A sail runs boats along the sea by sailing! You can't run along the water unless the sail is out and catching the wind.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 縫う means "to sew." Well the only way you can see if a pair of jeans has been sewed with your eye is if you see a seam. If your eyes can't spot the stitches, then it probably wasn't sewed at all. Maybe it was superglued together.

reading.explanation: This is a combination of the words 縫う and 目. Both use the kun'yomi readings so just change the う to い and it's easy! You'll also see this word spelled 縫い目 too. They're exactly the same!

meaning.explanation: The score on a surface is your sheet music or musical score.  譜面 often refers more specifically to a music score’s pages. For a more general term for musical score, go with 楽譜.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word isn't limited to animal shells though! It covers seed shells, or husks, too.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Shells are a good defense against からて chops. You can't get hurt if you have a nice strong shell to protect you from that からて-chopping weirdo who just showed up out of nowhere.

meaning.explanation: A silk thread is silk thread!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned these readings for 絹 and 糸 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who only uses clothes made with silk thread? Ken's sheep (し)! Ken's sheep is very particular, and only wears clothes made from silk thread while it's waiting for its wool to grow back.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 縛る means "to bind?" Well, in Japanese being bound by gold means you're experiencing sleep paralysis, or temporary paralysis. Just imagine that you're waking from a dream where you're bound up in gold thread, and it's stopping you from moving.

reading.explanation: This is a combination of the words 金 and 縛る. Both use the kun'yomi readings, but 金 becomes かな instead of かね. If you can remember that exception, this should be easy!

meaning.explanation: Your stature's spine is really just your spine, when you think about it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You already know that 楽器 means "musical instrument" so adding a couple of bowstrings to it will make it a stringed instrument.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Feelings that make you sigh out loud are really strong feelings. You wouldn't sigh if they didn't move you so much.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sedge field is both Sugahara and Sugawara, the Japanese family names. Sedgefield is a family name (and a place-name) in English too, so that might help you with this one! This is a very old surname, said to have originated with Nara period scholar Hanishi-no-sukune (土師宿禰) who changed his name to Sugawara-no-furuhito (菅原古人). Historically, the name has been associated with scholars and writers, including prominent Heian period statesman, scholar, and poet Sugawara-no-michizane (菅原道真) and noblewoman, writer, and poet Sugawara-no-takasue-no-musume (菅原孝標女), also known more simply as Lady Sarashina in the English speaking world.

reading.explanation: The only reading you haven't learned for this name is the irregular わら reading for 原, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Sugawara-san went to war a (わら) long time ago, but these days he enjoys a quiet life tending to his sedge fields.

meaning.explanation: Mix sulfur and acid and you'll get sulfuric acid! That's how science works! How simple!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Aid and foster someone to show your support for them.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well the jury has a tenacious grip on the idea of trying to let you go and they request an extension, so they give you a suspended sentence until they can figure out how to do it properly. You might be set free! E... eventually.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 猶予 means "extension?" Well you wake up ready to sue people when you're told there has been an extension, meaning there was a suspension of indictment on your case. What the heck, you woke up ready for this! Now you have to wait to try and sue them.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You decided to steal... and then you steal again a few minutes later! Now you're wanted for theft. Stealing is wrong, you should have known better!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a combination of the word 呆れる meaning "to be amazed" and 返る meaning "to be returned." You're so amazed at something that it keeps returning to your mind. It means to be utterly amazed!

reading.explanation: This is a combination of the words 呆れる and 返る. 呆れる becomes 呆れ and you just add 返る to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decay, so the verb version is to decay or to die out.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The entire world would start to die out if there were no cookies (く) left! Can you imagine your life without cookies? The trees and animals would all die too. Because they love cookies. Not just us humans.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to keep out.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means muddy, so the verb version is to make muddy or to make cloudy.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you want to make muddy, meaning make yourself muddy, you should have your knees go (にご) first. When you have your knees go first the mud splashes all over you but you don't hurt your hands or your butt doing it.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means serve, and the verb version is to scoop or to serve. It can also mean to take into consideration someone else's feelings or opinions. Kind of like you're scooping up the person's feelings and considering them!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What do you decide to scoop out for your guests? Cookies (く)! But not just any cookies. Cookie smoothies! They're delicious and you won't serve anyone anything else. They must drink your delicious cookie drinks.

meaning.explanation: I'm so bored. On top of my boredom is くまでも. If you took this separately, it would mean "even as a bear." So it's like you're saying I'm so bored, even if I was a bear. If you're so bored that you'd be bored even as a bear, you're going to be bored to the last or to the end. Nothing will please you, you bored bear person.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already when you learned 飽きる so you should be able to read this one too!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play, so the verb version is to play with or to toy with someone.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Everyone always seems to yell at you when you start to toy with your towel and your towel moves (たわむ). Just because you don't have anything on under it doesn't mean you can't play with it! Right?!

meaning.explanation: You must not use your body for anything wasteful, because that would be a waste. You're too good for that! This word is used in all kinds of situations where there's a feeling that something is going to waste, including food, money, time, talent, and opportunities. You can also use it to say that someone is too good for a job, or even for another person. While it's usually written in kana, you'll see it in kanji too.

reading.explanation: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji, except that もち becomes もっ.

meaning.explanation: If you're bored all the time it makes you tired and the weariness you feel will show on your face.

reading.explanation: Remember how you learned 飽きる? Well just take of the る and it's the same thing. If you can remember that, you'll know this no problem!

meaning.explanation: Some day you'll run around, released from the world and its troubles and you'll end up running wild. All your actions will be completely uninhibited when you aren't tied to your school or your job. It will be great!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because ほう becomes ぽう here.

meaning.explanation: A reef in the shape of a loop is an atoll. If you don't know what that is, it's a circular coral reef.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 一遍 means "once?" Well if you add に and make it an adverb, it becomes at once.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading you learned with 一遍 so you should be able to remember this too!

meaning.explanation: If you can congratulate someone for an occurrence in their life, it must be an auspicious event. You'll remember this happy event for a long, long time.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Japanese birch river is Azusa River or simply Azusagawa. Azusagawa is both the Japanese name for the Azusa River, and a Japanese family name.

reading.explanation: You learned both of these readings with the kanji. You just need to remember that rendaku turns かわ into がわ.

meaning.explanation: You should congratulate a person who speaks lots of dialects because they have to be a really strong person, just like Mr. Benkei was. You think learning Japanese is hard now, just wait till you hear Osaka-ben and Hokkaido-ben. It takes a really strong person — a Benkei — to learn all those dialects, so congratulate them and tell them how strong they are! 弁慶 is the name of a Japanese historical figure who was really strong, so Benkei is the Japanese equivalent of Hercules or Achilles in Western languages.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Grief shows in your eyes by making them look like you've gone through a lot of bitterness and hardship. You can always see it in someone else if you look them in the eyes too. You’ll see this word most often in 憂き目を見る and 憂き目に合う, which both mean “to experience misery.”

reading.explanation: This word uses one of the kun'yomi readings for the kanji. You haven’t learned this kun’yomi reading for 憂, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Why the bitterness in your eyes? You visited a famed uni (う) restaurant, only to find it closed and locked. Where is the key (き)? Your 目s scream of the uni missed. In a sea of misery, a missed uni is the hardest to swallow.

meaning.explanation: If you have really big guts you're a super bold and daring person. In fact, you might even be superman. That's how big your guts are. Don't worry, I don't tell anyone I know who you are. It'll be our little secret.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: If you want to create a cast you need to learn casting first. Then you can make lots of neat art, crafts, and counterfeit money. Wait, no, don't do that last one.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned both of them, so you should already know this word!

meaning.explanation: Change and transition mean change and transition! Nifty. 変遷 refers to historical or long-term changes. It’s often used when discussing the evolution or progression of entities over long periods.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: You congratulate someone and celebrate by saying congratulations and having a celebration!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you are saying congratulations and also giving your condolences then they are congratulations and condolences. Pretty easy, right?

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If someone is so dangerous that they deliberately hurt you, you're going to end up in critical condition. This wasn't an accident, they knew what they were doing and they didn't miss. Now you're on the verge of death. Hold on, kiddo.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 遮断 means "isolation?" Well the machine that isolates you from a train is a crossing gate. That way you won't walk, bike, or drive your car into an oncoming train.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Dairy farming is dairy farming!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The times when you are in mourning each year are for a loved one's death anniversary. They come around again every year. It's important you remember your loved ones at this time. You'll often see this used with a number before 回忌, indicating a certain anniversary. However, you actually start counting your 回忌 starting with the first period of mourning around the time of the person's death, which would be the 一回忌. Hence, 二回忌 would usually be translated as "first death anniversary", 三回忌 as "second death anniversary", and so on.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you compose something with a sigh, it's because you're experiencing a deep feeling. You might express this deep feeling with an exclamation, as you marvel at the wonders of the world. This word can be used for a range of deep feelings, good or bad, and can also be used for the expression of those feelings, so you'll notice that the English translation varies quite a bit depending on the context.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You should be able to read it on your own.

meaning.explanation: Usually if you're going to the left in Japanese, it's not a good thing. So if you transition to the left it's seen as a demotion. Going to the right is way better.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: It's such a leisurely day that everyone has scattered and left the area deserted. It's just you now. Lounging in the shade.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Your guts feel like they're falling when you experience a lot of discouragement. You know that sinking feeling you get in the pit of your stomach? That's your guts falling!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Use attire that imitates your surroundings to create a disguise. Or throw on some camouflage so that no one will be able to find you in Walmart.

Well if you're mourning one time like this a year, then it's because it's the first anniversary of death for a family member. Maybe it was the death of your mom, your grandad or your goldfish, this is the first year since they died.

You gotta get deep in the uni to the root of its sh*t and rub it into a paste to make the lacquer. Then rub that on wooden stuff! Yay! Uni root sh*t!

That means they share meanings as well. 峠 refers to a mountain pass, and often specifically the highest point of a mountain pass, where it passes between two mountains. When used figuratively, it means the worst, as in the toughest moment of a specific event, like the height of a health crisis or the hottest day of a heatwave.

reading.explanation: You climb along the mountain pass and see adorable little Tokyo geckos (とうげ) climbing all over the place. They're climbing with you now!

meaning.explanation: A young woman who is planting rice from early morning into the latter evenings is a rice planting girl. You'll see them out there all day long, from dawn till dusk, planting, taking care of, and picking rice. This is also a common family name, and on rare occasion, a given name as well. Some well-known people with this name include historical fiction writer Saotome Mitsugu (早乙女 貢), former pro-wrestler, model, and idol Saotome Miku (早乙女 未来), and stage and screen actor Saotome Taichi (早乙女 太一).

reading.explanation: This is a really weird exception, sorry. You've kind of learned these reading, but they're like... weird variations of them. Take the さ from 早速, the おつ becomes おと, and then the 女 kun'yomi め (hey that one's normal!). And you get さおとめ. You might need to just memorize this one.

meaning.explanation: A person who wanders because their lord was killed, is known as a ronin, or a masterless samurai. Now they're just like the rest of us, but they can't stop wandering because they have nowhere they belong. In modern times, ronin refers to those who failed their university entrance exams, waiting until for another chance to take the test again.

meaning.explanation: If sand is spread out you get the given name Sara. You've written your name in sand, right? Now imagine a Sara you know spreading out sand so that it spells her name. Or imagine a pro athlete, like wrestler Doshō Sara (土性 沙羅), judoka Asahina Sara (朝比奈 沙羅), or ski jumper Takanashi Sara (髙梨 沙羅) spreading out the sand. I bet they'd find some skillful ways to do it.

reading.explanation: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned those readings with the kanji.

You haven't learned this reading for 軽 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have more scorn and disdain for the KKK (けい) than any other group in the whole world. And I'm not going to argue with you, they're pretty hatable.

meaning.explanation: Despise someone and your scorn for them just becomes even stronger scorn.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you tasted the air at a recital the flavor would taste like scrutiny. That's really what everyone is doing when they watch. They don't really want to hear you, they just want to judge you.

You never really know when you start and then BAM! You made elephant slippers. That's just how it works and it shocks you every single time.

meaning.explanation: What is a sprout doing? It's sprouting and budding. A crush you have on someone can sprout too.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Think about that newly sprouting moe (もえ) character you have a crush on. Yes, this is the same moe. Congrats, you already know it!

meaning.explanation: Resident soldiers live in barracks when they've been stationed in another country. They have to serve their occupancy for a certain amount of time before they get to go back home.

meaning.explanation: A lowly person who yields to everyone is really subservient. They'll do everything people tell them because they don't have the nerves to speak up and just say no.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means compose, so the verb version is to compose.

reading.explanation:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You want to compose a poem but all you have for inspiration is what's in your pocket. You reach in and find a yo-yo (よ). Ah yes, this will do. So you compose a poem about your yo-yo: One string to rule them all,
One string to find them,
One string to- hey wait a minute...

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means despise, so the verb version is to despise.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Think of all the things you start to despise and to disdain. Now come up with some anecdotes (あなど) for each one of those things. Be sure to think in your head, "I'm coming up with anecdotes for things I disdain, why am I coming up with anecdotes?"

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means endure, so the verb version is to endure or to bear.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned the kanji!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means concave, but "to concave" doesn't really make sense. So the verb version is to get dented. Or, more figuratively, to feel down. 凹む is used in a physical sense when the surface of something is dented, collapsed inward, or features some kind of hollow depression. That can be anything from a dented car to even a fit, slimmed-down belly (sort of like the flab is "dented" in). In a figurative sense, 凹む is used when you're feeling down. Almost like your heart is dented, you know? We all have those days.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You feel like you've started to get dented when you have a head cold (へこ). Like all that sniffling makes dents on the sides of your nose. It's easy to feel down when you have a head cold too, but try not to let it get to you.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scorn, so the verb version is to scorn and to despise.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You start to scorn your boss because she's been wearing that same sage suit (さげす) for a month now. She knows you want to wear a sage suit too but you can't wear the same color as her! It's really making you start to despise her. Uhg!

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means spinning, so the verb version is to spin and to make yarn.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. Go on, two moos, right now. Hey, out loud, not in your head!

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 凹凸 means "uneven?" Well spin something uneven around and it's still uneven! Just kinda backwards, just like this word!

reading.explanation: However, just because the meaning stays the same when you flip it, doesn't mean the reading does. Doing that actually made the reading change from on'yomi to kun'yomi readings! You haven't learned either of these yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you have the convex parts first and the concave parts second in something uneven it ends up looking like a deco box (でこぼこ). An art deco box that is. They have lots of stuff stick out of them on the outside, but you can open them up and put stuff on the inside.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 普遍 means "universal?" Well when you add like it's still universal! Easy!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of mourning? It's unpleasant or disgusting. Nobody said mourning was fun.

You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Your mourning is especially unpleasant because it's your pet eagle (い) you're mourning for. Your parents wouldn't let you bury him so you're just staring at his week old, dead eagle body. It's super disgusting, actually.

meaning.explanation: Clumsy and immature people end up being really unskillful. You can't do your job if you're always dropping things and whining, can you? They're usually also really childish, if you didn't already guess that.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Wander from stream to stream and you'll get really used to vagrancy. You'll love wandering so much that you'll convert to nomadism. The open sky is your home!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. Since you haven't learned this particular reading for 流, here's a mnemonic to help you: When you think about it, vagrancy is kind of a loophole (る). No one ever knows where you could be, making it hard to track you down.

meaning.explanation: Someone who floats and wanders from place to place is a vagrant. They don't really have a home, but they keep hanging around yours. It's kind of annoying. (This word has a negative connotation, you wouldn't use it for someone who is just homeless, unless you're really mean.)

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 浮 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the vagrants you know are fools (ふ). They just left their homes and now they float around your city for no reason. You ask them why and they shrug. You've never seen a better definition of a fool before in your life!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

meaning.explanation: Release your worldly ties and wander the world. You'll get used to wandering and you'll spend the rest of your days roaming the world until you die. It's quite the life! But you can only do it if you let go of everything else.

meaning.explanation: One of the most evil things about war are the war damages that happen during it. Whole countrysides, cities, and lots of people can die. So I'd say the ravages of war are the most evil thing about war. Period.
