meaning.explanation: Red diarrhea means there's blood in there and you're probably dying of dysentery! Have you been playing too much Oregon Trail? Either way, get to a doctor!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 赤 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know what dysentery isn't? Sexy (せき). That's right. If anyone tries to seduce you by saying they have dysentery and they'd like to share it with you, tell them how NOT sexy that is and get the heck away from them!

meaning.explanation: It's kind of like you're saying say say, and it’s used in classical Japanese to get someone’s attention, so this is excuse me or hello. You would generally encounter 申し申し in dialogues set in older times, unlike its modern, shortened version もしもし, which is used for telephone greetings (and almost always written in kana).

reading.explanation: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji. You should know it already.

meaning.explanation: If you do something gradually for a long time, when you finish it gives you that FINALLY feeling. It took so long and you worked so hard and you're finally done!

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception, but you learned it with the kanji. Congratulations!

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 新年 means "New Year?" Well when you say humble congratulations on the new year, you're really saying Happy New Year!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The neck of the squad is the most important part of the squad, for if you lose the neck you lose the head (they're all one thing). This person is the head or leader of a group. This is a very formal word to refer to someone in a top role, especially a Prime Minister (aka the head of the cabinet).

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word so it uses the on'yomi readings. You learned the on'yomi for 首 in the words 部首 and 首位, and you learned the on'yomi for 班 with the kanji. Go you!

meaning.explanation: Hide and hide make hide! Lots of hiding going on around here. I think... I can't find anyone so I can only assume.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: The final bullet of censure is impeachment. You've already been publicly humiliated and now you're being impeached because of it. Yikes.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already, so you should know this too!

meaning.explanation: The lake shore is the lake shore!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Someone who has territory under their sleeve is the leader. They're the boss of all this territory because they say so, and because they shoved it all into their big sleeves. This is a very formal word often used in political contexts, particularly when referring to the leader of a faction or political party.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 袖, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: It's always hard to fill a leaders' shoes (しゅう). Leaders have big responsibilities and power. Just big shoes to fill! Picture these big ol' leader's shoes, like in a literal sense. Not only do they have big responsibilities, leaders have big shoes as well.

meaning.explanation: A long shamisen song is a long shamisen song! They're also called nagauta, and they're usually pretty epic too.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Buy something at bargain value and you'll be getting it at a really low price. Good for you!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The pillar the sail is attached to is called a mast. Without it the sail wouldn't do it's job and your sailboat wouldn't move at all.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned these readings with other vocabulary, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A stream that runs through a valley is a mountain stream. Valleys happen in between mountains, so just picture the river running through the middle of them in your head.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of annoy? It's annoying!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What's noisy? That uni's rude sighing (うるさい). It just keeps sighing loudly over and over. It's sooo annoying!

meaning.explanation: Remember how you learned that 管弦楽 means "orchestral music?" Well the group that plays that music is an orchestra.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Add a bridge to a jetty and you'll have a pretty cool pier. Put a ferris wheel on there and make some money!

reading.explanation: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 桟 and the kun'yomi reading for 橋. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too!

meaning.explanation: Remember how 戯れる can mean "to play" or "to flirt?" Well this is when you play flirt! Or just make a joke.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

meaning.explanation: The underworld king star is the dwarf planet Pluto. Since Pluto was the ruler of the underworld in classical mythology, this makes a lot of sense!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The underworld dirt is another word for the realm of the dead, underworld, or Hades. Like the word 冥界 (also in this level), it's rather poetic, and mostly used in written contexts involving spirituality, Buddhism, and ancient mythologies. There are a few set expressions that only use 冥土, though. One example is 冥土の土産, "a souvenir to take to the realm of the dead". It refers to something abstract that is so valuable, it's worth taking to the underworld, such as the solution to a great mystery, or a happy memory. Another expression is 冥土の旅支度, which means "preparations for the journey to the realm of the dead", and can refer to the preparation of the deceased before a funeral, as wells as certain preparations made by Buddhists while they're still alive. You'll also see this word written as 冥途 sometimes.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Remember how 容赦 can mean "forgiveness" and "mercy?" Well add なく (basically making it NOT that), and it becomes relentlessly and mercilessly. The exact opposite of what it was before!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji (with なく attached to it). You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A sail boat is a sailboat!

reading.explanation: This word uses the on'yomi readings. You know them!

meaning.explanation: Barbarians who live in fields, not even in huts or houses or anything, are called savage by people who DO live in huts and houses. They think if you live out in a field you're really uncivilized. But that's all a matter of opinion, I guess.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: What do you hear that is really ugly? A scandal. Scandals are the ugliest topics for gossip.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sea seaweed is still seaweed!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

reading.explanation: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Swim into a floating group of seaweed and shivers will go up your spine. It feels so gross and slimy that you can't help but moan (も) out in distress.

meaning.explanation: Part of you is starting to secrete some kind of secretion. It's kinda gross, so maybe you should go to the doctor to check if it's normal.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. But 泌 is using an on'yomi reading you haven't learned yet (ひつ), which also happens to get rendaku'd here, so use this mnemonic to remember it: The part of your body that produces the most secretions is… your pits (ぴつ). Yeah, it's a gross image, but next time you're walking around Tokyo in summer and "secreting" through your shirt, at least you'll have the vocab to describe all that 分泌.

meaning.explanation: Something with an ugly appearance is a shameful sight, or disgraceful behavior. You feel bad just looking at it. It probably feels bad too.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Tell a widow to shut up and she'll be silent for the rest of the day. That wasn't very nice. You're a mean person.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The kanji means certain, but when it's used as a standalone word, or after a family name, it means things like someone or other, you-know-who, or something. It's basically a vague way to refer to someone who's name you've forgotten, or you don't want to mention for some reason.

reading.explanation: This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji, and you haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You bump into someone or other, and just as you're wondering what on earth her name is, her nanny gashes (なにがし) her on the leg. It looks like it hurts. Poor you-know-who, whatever her name is. The nanny looks horrified, and is trying to patch her up.

meaning.explanation: A shamisen song is a shamisen song, yes. But did you know it's also... a song?! Oh, you did? Well okay then.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

meaning.explanation: Your daughter's groom will become your son in law. He's a great guy! Congratulations!

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Southern barbarians are called Southern barbarians! While it originally referred to the people of Southeast Asia, the term Nanban was used to refer to Western traders who began arriving in Japan in the 1500s. There's yummy food named after them too!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Measure that shape on the paper with your eyes. It's got four sides.. it's.. it's a square! Or a box from above maybe... But it's definitely the kind you fill in on a graph.

reading.explanation: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: Sulfur that's yellow is still sulfur. It smells like rotten eggs, which are also kinda yellow.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: This sulfur smells like an eagle's OOHHH (いおう)!! Oh no. Sulfur smells... it smells... like an eagle's... OH.. Oh eww no.

meaning.explanation: A bad kind of playing is when you tease or prank someone. It's mean and you shouldn't do it! Depending on the context this can sometimes have a far more negative connotation and mean lewd behavior.

reading.explanation: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you tease someone with a prank that makes them eat zoo rats (いたずら), you're a jerk. That's less of a prank and more like abuse. Cut it out.

meaning.explanation: I promise this will be a really thrifty place because it's a thrift store! They wouldn't lie about that!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means yearn for, so the verb version is to yearn for. But that sounds kinda old fashioned, so you can just use to adore too.

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You realize you're starting to yearn for someone way more than you used to. "Sh*t (した)... " you say to yourself. This wasn't supposed to happen. Anytime you start to adore someone like that you always know you're getting into a bunch of sh*t you don't want to deal with. Damn these emotions!

meaning.explanation: You already know that 濁す means "to make muddy," but this is when you're the one getting muddy. It means to become muddy.

reading.explanation: This has the same reading as 濁す. If you can remember that one, you should be able to remember this one.

meaning.explanation: The verb form of compose is to compose. This particular verb is usually used in relation to poetry, and can also mean to recite or to sing, though more in the sense of singing someone's praises than singing a song.

reading.explanation: This word shares the same origin as 歌う and 唄う, and they share the same readings as well.

meaning.explanation: 酌む means "to serve" and the kanji 交 means mix. What happens if you serve and mix together? You're going to pour each other a drink because you plan to drink together.

reading.explanation: You haven't learned this reading for 交 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: All the bars are closed so you and your friends are going to drink together in your car (か). You set up a little bar in the back of your car and settle down for some drinks. It's cramped but cosy.

meaning.explanation: Torture may be a problem but that doesn't stop people from using torture to get their way.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means Shamisen song, so the verb version is to sing.

reading.explanation: Remember how 歌う means "to sing" too? Well it has the same reading. If you know that one, you know this one. Yay!

meaning.explanation: A pit that's used as a road is called a tunnel. Or a mine, if they're taking valuable things out of it.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of ugly? It's ugly still!

reading.explanation: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The most ugly thing you've ever seen was a mini cookie (みにく). Why would any one want a tiny cookie? Cookies should be huge, and enough to fill you up. The more you look at the mini cookie it seems to become uglier and uglier to you.

meaning.explanation: Ugly, bad things are ugly, mean, and offensive.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The underworld world is the underworld, Hades, or the realm of the dead. This word is a bit poetic, and mostly used in writing, particularly in contexts like Buddhism, spirituality, and ancient mythologies. It's usually interchangeable with 冥土 (which is also in this level), but 冥土 is used more in certain set expressions, which we'll mention in the page for that word!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned those with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: The containers your urine secretes into are your urinary organs.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A valley in a valley is still a valley!

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: A widowed wife is a widow.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meaning.explanation: If you can't stop thinking about how much you yearn for someone, that yearning can drive you crazy. Try to keep it in check, and enjoy how you can hold such deep affection for someone.

reading.explanation: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
